PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes attempts by the government to raise the pension age for women from 60 to 65 years.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate oppose this proposed change.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Kernot (from 62 citizens) and Senator Lees (from 103 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Land Mines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senator in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned urges the Government to press for a total ban internationally on the production, stockpiling, trade and use of anti-personnel devices.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate urge the Government to provide financial aid for the de-mining of countries such as Cambodia.

PETITION.TITLE: Mifepristone
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned showeth:

(1) That the trials of the abortifacient drug Mifepristone (RU486) are against the public interest in that they use women as guinea pigs for trials of a drug which causes death to the unborn future citizens and adds undue risk to the health of women.
(2) That when RU486 is used with a prostaglandin it exposes women to a disproportionate risk of pain, bleeding and more serious complications.
(3) That when RU486 is used as a `morning after pill' its effect is abortifacient in that it stops implantation of a human embryo, a future citizen, in the womb.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will legislate to ban the importation and use of RU486 in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia asks that the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993 be amended with the application of common principles. To ensure that all parents with dependent children are treated equally, allowing maximum freedom of choice in child rearing.
These Acts need to be amended to take account of:

PETITION.PARA: 1.the fact that 60% of married women in the workforce who have children, would prefer to stay at home and mind their children, but for economic reasons can't afford to (Institute of Family Studies Survey).
2.the failure to provide for equitable choice for women and families in allowing parents the maximum right to choose the most appropriate form of care for their children.
3.that there be recognition of a parent at home as a formal occupation reflecting its economic value and worth to society.
4.the need for equal payment of any subsidies and allowances for the care of children, paid directly to the parent.
5.the recognition that a family with more than one child incurs extra expenses.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners request that the Senate amend the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: 22 September 1994
Senator the Hon John Faulkner
Minister for the Environment, Sport
and Territories
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Australian Sports Drug Agency Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1994 No 284, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 22 September 1994.

New r.32A(3) provides that where an accredited laboratory tests a remaining sample and confirms that there is the possibility of a positive result for the sample, it does not have to notify the competitor of the results of the test. This does not appear to rule out the possibility that the accredited laboratory may notify the competitor, if it wishes. On the other hand, where the laboratory does not confirm the possibility of a positive result, the competitor must be notified.
The Committee asks why a negative result must be notified, while the notification of a possible positive sample is apparently left to the discretion of the accredited laboratory.
Yours sincerely
Mal Colston
9 November 1994
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston
Thank you for your letter dated 22 September 1994 concerning the Australian Sports Drug Agency Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules No 284.

The new regulations were made to overcome the problem of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories (AGAL) being downgraded by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to Phase 2 testing status in June this year. Under IOC rules a Phase 2 status laboratory can test the A sample but cannot test the confirmatory B sample. Confirmatory analysis must be performed by a full accredited IOC laboratory.

The amendments provide for a laboratory that does not have full accreditation to forward samples to a fully accredited laboratory for confirmatory analysis. They have allowed AGAL to continue to analyse A samples collected by the Agency and, when analysis reveals the possibility of a positive result on the A sample, to forward the residue of the A sample together with the unopened B sample to a fully accredited laboratory for confirmatory analysis.
New regulations 32A and 32B apply to situations only in which a partially accredited laboratory forwards A and B samples to a fully accredited laboratory for confirmatory analysis.

New regulation 32A(3) prevents an accredited laboratory from notifying a competitor of the possibility of a positive test result. The laboratory is required by regulation 30(2) to notify the Agency of the result and, in accordance with the requirements of regulation 31(2), the Agency notifies the competitor fo the A sample result.

New regulation 32A(4) requires a fully accredited laboratory analysing the residue to an A sample to notify the result of the A sample analysis if it does not confirm the possibility of a positive test result. If this occurred the result would be deemed negative and the B sample would not be analysed. The laboratory is required by regulation 30(1) to notify the Agency of the result and, in accordance with the requirements of regulation 31(1), the Agency notifies the competitor of the A sample result. Reference to the accredited laboratory notifying the competitor of the test result is a drafting error.

Accredited laboratories are never given the names of competitors who provide samples. They only receive documentation identifying samples by sample numbers. It is impossible for laboratories to directly notify competitors of either positive or negative test results. The Agency is responsible for notifying competitors of all test results.
I have instructed the Agency to make the necessary arrangements to amend the Regulations so that it is clear that accredited laboratories notify the Agency of both positive and negative test results.
I thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
John Faulkner

SPEECH.PARA: 15 November 1994
The Hon Robert Tickner MP
Minister for Aboriginal and
Torres Strait Islander Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Suspension of a Regional Councillor from Office, No.1 of 1994, made under s.122A of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989.

The instrument advised that the suspension was based on convictions for a number of offences against the Social Security Act 1991. The instrument also suggests that the suspension was for an infamous crime.

The Committee would be grateful for your advice on the reasons why the crimes for which the suspended officer were convicted are regarded as infamous crimes. Also, if they were infamous crimes, what authority suggests that conviction for an infamous crime is misbehaviour?

In this context, ATSIC (Misbehaviour) Determination No.2 was made on 21 September 1994, commencing on gazettal on 28 September 1994. ATSIC (Misbehaviour) Determination No.1 was, however, apparently still in force when the suspension was made on 20 September 1994. Neither Determination appears to mention an infamous crime. Nevertheless, the offences under the Social Security Act for which the suspended officer was convicted appear to be punishable by imprisonment, which would bring those offences within ATSIC (Misbehaviour) Determination No.1. The present instrument does not indicate, however, that it was relying on that Determination.
The Committee would appreciate your confirmation that the present instrument was validly made.
Yours sincerely
Mal Colston
Hon. Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston

I refer to your letter dated 15 November 1994 concerning the Suspension of a Regional Councillor, No. 1 of 1994. This instrument was made pursuant to s.122A of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 (the Act).
Having consulted the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (the Commission), I am able to provide the following advice in response to you queries.

The instrument states, at para 2,: ". . . The convictions for the two offences under section 1347 involve dishonesty and having regard to the nature of the office of Regional Councillor and the role of a Regional Council constitute misbehaviour for the purposes of section 122A of the Act. The Commission regards misbehaviour as including conviction for an infamous crime, such as the two suffered by Malcolm Edward Champion under section 1347. . . ".
I am advised by the Commission that the word `infamous' was used in its ordinary sense; the Macquarie Dictionary defines it as "of ill fame; having an extremely bad reputation; . . . shamefully bad".

Section 122A of the Act enables the suspension and removal of a Regional Councillor from office because of misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity. Section 4A(1) of the Act provides that the Minister may make a written determination providing that specified behaviour is taken to be misbehaviour for the purposes of the Act. I made the ATSIC (Misbehaviour) Determination, 1994 No. 1 (the Misbehaviour Determination), on 25 February 1994 (published in the Gazette on 2 March 1994). The suspension of Mr Champion occurred on 20 September 1994. However, the suspension was in respect of conduct and convictions which occurred before the making of the Misbehaviour Determination. The suspension was not based under the Misbehaviour Determination, since the Determination could not be applied retrospectively.

Advice to the Commission from Special Counsel indicated that suspension for misbehaviour could occur regardless of the Misbehaviour Determination for the purposes of s.122A under the `ordinary meaning of misbehaviour'. Special Counsel stated: "You express the view that the determination may not be applied retrospectively. The determination expands the meaning of misbehaviour (see definition of `misbehaviour' in s.4(1)). Since the conduct and the convictions preceded the making of the determination, the determination is inapplicable. It is therefore necessary to apply s.122A on the basis of the ordinary meaning of `misbehaviour'." Special Counsel further advised the Commission that the two convictions under section 1347 "can, in my view, constitute mibehaviour for the purposes of s.122A. . . . I note, in this respect, that misbehaviour has always been interpreted as including conviction for an infamous crime."
Given that the suspension was not effected pursuant to the Misbehaviour Determination, the instrument correctly does not refer to it. I confirm that it was validly made under s.122A.
Yours sincerely
Robert Tickner
28 November 1994

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The government is opposed to the establishment of yet another select committee and the proposed inquiry. We see it as a political stunt because the government is already considering the report of the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing and its recommendations. We have indicated that we will be considering that committee's report early next year, and any Commonwealth initiative, any Commonwealth legislation, will take into account that committee's recommendations.

PARA.TAB: The reason we oppose the inquiry that has been proposed this morning is that it will not add one iota to the whistleblower debate that was well and truly canvassed in this place by the Senate select committee. The issues that Senator Parer in particular wishes to raise have already been investigated, examined and canvassed previously by that Senate committee in the committee process.

That committee and the Queensland CJC have canvassed the sorts of issues that Senator Parer has raised. We are going to embark upon another select committee process to investigate an issue which has only recently been examined in this place. The government will respond to the first committee's report early next year.

What we have before us today is nothing short of a political stunt. It is a stunt to try to embarrass the Queensland Labor government in the lead-up to the state election of next year. It has nothing to do with a legitimate interest in whistleblowing. If it did, those opposite would have waited until the government responded to the first committee's report before it looked at what the government has done. We are now going to embark upon another committee process which will be required to report back to this place in the middle of June next year. This will be after the government has considered the first committee's report.

This is about playing politics in Queensland. It is about propping up Rob Borbidge's leadership in Queensland. He is having a competition with Mr Downer to see how low they can go. The government recognises that the numbers are stacked against it today, but there has to come a time in this place when financial costs and workload costs, particularly those associated with senators and staff, are taken into account and senators are selective about the committee processes they set up. As I said, this is a duplication. It is premature. It is a political stunt and that is why the government opposes it.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) said that the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing investigated these claims. In fact, we did not investigate any claims. All the committee did was report on the matters raised. We highlighted some of the claims in Queensland and recommended that the CJC and the government revisit those matters. Both the Premier, Mr Goss, and the CJC have written back to the committee and refused to revisit those claims. What Senator Parer is trying to do is exactly the sort of thing the committee would have liked to have examined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of eight World Trade Organisation bills we are now debating cognately is a reflection of the legislative action that we in Australia need to take to have our laws conform with the new international trade arrangements that have been put in place as a result of the successful completion of the Uruguay Round of the GATT negotiations—which, as we are all aware, took many years and which have culminated in the opening up of an enormous prospect for the future, a new era of freer and fairer world trade.

PARA.TAB: The Industry Commission has modelled the long-term benefits to Australia from the freeing up of trade in manufacturing, agriculture and resources and has very conservatively estimated the benefits to Australia at $4.4 billion per annum in 1992. That is equivalent to $780 for each Australian household. More recent estimates would suggest that those figures are very conservative and that the benefits could be significantly greater.

From 1 January 1995 a new body will replace the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which has stood the world in such good stead and which has been one of the prime movers of the great liberalisation of world trade we have seen over recent decades. The GATT was one of the institutional arrangements put in place along with the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development—the World Bank—at the end of the Second World War to set an institutional framework for the world in the post-war era of economic and trade development. The GATT never really fully achieved what its initiators had hoped, which was to have a world trade organisation of the nature that is now proposed as a result of the conclusion of the Uruguay Round.

Although the GATT did not get 100 per cent of the way down that road, it did get a long way down the road and the GATT has been a major organisation and force for good and for liberalisation in world trading arrangements for the last almost 50 years. It is to be replaced by the World Trade Organisation, which is the product of the World Trade Organisation agreement which has been signed and which comes into effective force on 1 January 1995. This body will be charged with maintaining compliance with the new international trade rules agreed to by member nations.

To fulfil Australia's obligations in accordance with this agreement, which we supported, Australia must make a number of amendments to some of its own legislative arrangements which are contrary at the moment to the new trading rules. Changes are required to the following acts: the Dairy Produce Act, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, the Customs Tariff Act, the Customs Act, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act, the Anti-Dumping Authority Act, the Patents Act and the Copyright Act. Most of the amendments to these acts are relatively minor in nature, although there are some points of significance as well. In addition to the amendments to those acts, a new trademarks act will be introduced.

The coalition speakers on these bills will handle different bills between them. My comments today will be restricted to three of these bills, namely, the Patents (World Trade Organisation Amendments) Bill, the Sales Tax (World Trade Organisation Amendments) Bill, and the Trade Marks Bill. The Patents (World Trade Organisation Amendments) Bill amends Australia's current patent laws to make those laws consistent with the agreed terms of the World Trade Organisation agreement. It will increase the standard patent term from the current 16 years to 20 years. This will apply from 1 July 1995. As a consequence of this lengthening of time for patents from 16 to 20 years, current provisions which allow for special four-year extensions of pharmaceutical patents will no longer be necessary and are therefore repealed by this bill.

The bill also puts the onus of proof on defendants to prove that their products do not infringe patent conditions of similar or identical products. The bill will have a slightly positive financial impact due to increased annual fee revenue from the longer patents and lower administrative costs from the patent office. The coalition supports the World Trade Organisation agreement and does not have any problems per se with this bill and therefore we will be supporting it.

The Sales Tax (World Trade Organisation Amendments) Bill is another of the bills intended to make Australian laws conform with the World Trade Organisation agreement. It relates specifically to the special concessional treatment presently granted to certain fruit and/or vegetable juices from Australia, New Zealand or Papua New Guinea. At the moment, if juices from those countries have a juice content greater than 25 per cent, they are subject to 11 per cent wholesale sales tax, whilst all other juices are subject to 21 per cent wholesale sales tax.

The proposed amendment will remove the special concessional rate of sales tax which is solely applicable to the juice products of these three nations by putting all other countries on the same basis as these three. This is necessary because, under the new international trade arrangements, all member nations' products must be treated equally and without discrimination. The lower rate of wholesale sales tax of 11 per cent will therefore apply to all products with greater than 25 per cent juice content, whether they be products from Australia, New Zealand or Papua New Guinea or products of any other national origin. Those juice products with less than 25 per cent juice content will be subject to the higher rate of wholesale sales tax of 21 per cent, again without discrimination. This bill will come into force on 1 January 1995 or on the day on which the World Trade Organisation agreement enters into force, whichever is later.

There is concern amongst citrus growers in Australia that the removal of this last remaining protection for their industry will leave them in an unfair position vis-a-vis cheap concentrate imports from Brazil. The coalition fully understands and acknowledges the concern of those growers. Whilst Australia should not be prepared to flout the new world trading rules by maintaining the existing discriminatory tax treatment, there are positive measures which the government could take to assist the domestic citrus industry.

One area where the coalition has called on the government to act for our growers is to allow growers to claim depreciation of their plantations for tax deductibility. This is in accord with the treatment by other competing countries like the United States and New Zealand, and it follows a recommendation from the Industry Commission's report into this industry. The government has, in principle, heeded the coalition's calls on the depreciation issue, and we welcome that. We did announce some time ago that we would be in favour of and we would support, and in government we would introduce, depreciation arrangements along these lines.

The government, once again, has picked up the coalition's policy to some extent in this area and has now, through the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, announced just a couple of days ago on 29 November that the government has agreed to this measure as part of a broader horticultural package designed to allay some of the industry's concerns.

I note in that context, though, the recommendations of the report of the Economics Legislation Committee which has just been presented to the Senate. The first recommendation at paragraph 1.22 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the World Trade Organisation Amendment Bills and the provisions of the Copyright (World Trade Organisation Amendments) Bill be agreed to.
But then paragraph 1.23 goes on to note:

However, the Committee notes the concerns of the Liberal Party Senators representing the Coalition who have expressed their dissatisfaction at the inadequacy of the Government's response to the recommendations of the Horticultural Task Force and the problems faced by citrus growers.

In other words, we do not believe that the government's proposals announced on 29 November have gone far enough to meet the needs, the concerns and the requirements of the horticultural industry. The minister should have been able to announce more details of the government's proposals but, unfortunately, he has not apparently been able to do that.

PARA.TAB: My colleague the shadow minister for primary industry, Mr Anderson, has described the package, quite rightly, as `miserly' for failing to address serious issues affecting this very important industry. We would have expected the minister to have responded to every recommendation of the horticultural task force. He has not and there are quite a number of outstanding matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a pretty poor package.

—As Senator Boswell says, it was a pretty poor, measly, miserly and ill-thought through package, which is typical of the way this government goes about its legislation. The government has not responded to each recommendation of the horticultural task force. There are quite a number of important outstanding matters, for example, the 150 per cent tax deductibility for ISO 9,000 series quality certification and additional funding for the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation to examine export market quarantine barriers. No action has been taken on harvest labour shortages. There has been an inadequate response to industry concerns about superannuation. There has been no abolition of part X of the TPC Act which exempts certain shipping from the act and, as a consequence, imposes additional costs on exporters.

PARA.TAB: The coalition believes that the government must continue to do more to assist the restructuring of this industry to ensure that it can be internationally competitive. The fact that it has not done what is required to be done is very much in line with its inability to assist industries to take the necessary restructuring that is required if we are going to be the internationally competitive nation that we need to be if we are going to maintain and build on our living standards in the years ahead. Having said those things, the coalition will not be opposing this bill.

The third bill that I wish to comment on is the Trade Marks Bill 1994. This bill introduces new trade marks laws which are consistent with the principles and requirements of the World Trade Organisation agreement. The new regime will replace the 1955 Trade Marks Act. The new regime, which mainly makes simplification changes to the existing system, brings Australian trade mark law into conformity with Australia's obligations under the agreement on trade related aspects of intellectual property rights, known by the acronym TRIPS.

The bill provides for the registration of trade marks and sets out and protects the rights deriving from such registration. There are new provisions dealing with the `association' of trade marks which will place the onus of identity on trade mark owners rather than on the Registrar of Trade Marks. The use of the term `owner' replaces the old language `proprietor' of trade marks. The estimated establishment cost of this new regime, including retraining staff and computer systems upgrading, is $4 million. Other than that, the trade marks system operates on full cost recovery.

As I understand it, and as already outlined in the other place by the coalition industry spokesman, Mr Moore, the government has acknowledged that there is a need for further considerations with respect to the new Trade Marks Act operating under the World Trade Organisation provisions. Next year, the government, as I understand it, may be bringing forward some further amendments to address various matters which have been raised with it. The coalition accepts the government's word that it will look at these matters closely and return to the parliament with amendments, if necessary, next year. We will hold the government to that review and monitor its progress on that. We look forward to further consideration of those matters in due course. In the meantime, though, the coalition will be supporting this bill as well.

My colleagues later on in the debate, as I foreshadowed at the start, will comment on other aspects of the package. As I say, it is a package of bills required to enable Australian legislation to accord with the new World Trade Organisation's agreement. We hold, as does the whole world, great store in the opportunities that the new agreements will present to us all for a new era in world trade liberalisation and a faster rate of growth and improvement for living standards in all countries right across the spectrum from the most developed to the least. It is a major step forward in world trading arrangements. We fully support that. Therefore, we support the necessary amending legislation required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

I am speaking on this industry because, as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), I chaired the horticultural task force which spent some considerable time on the citrus industry.

PARA.TAB: On Monday, the cabinet determined a package for the horticultural industry with a primary focus on assistance to the citrus industry because of the fallout of the effect of the changes to sales tax. TALK.START.PARA: —I think the fundamental point that needs to be made in this debate about the citrus industry is that any assistance provided to that industry through the sales tax mechanism, which is the area from which the industry sought its relief, in effect would not have greatly assisted the growers themselves. It would have effectively assisted consumers, it would have assisted manufacturers of juice, but it would not have assisted growers to any great extent.
—The growers did not tell you that.

—I will come to that point in a moment. It is the growers who wanted the assistance. However, the reductions in protection in overseas markets as a result of the GATT Uruguay Round outcome, as well as the government's support announced in the package, will increase citrus exports, which will be a much more effective way of improving growers' returns. I will refer to export statistics and why it is so important that that is the way in which the industry heads for its future.

PARA.TAB: There was another option available under the GATT negotiations, and that was to so-called `tariffy' the protection that is currently provided by sales tax provisions. In fact, the government did consult with the industry, the Australian Citrus Industry Council, and it agreed with the government's assessment that the domestic price paid for oranges destined for juice concentrate was close to the import parity price for imported frozen concentrate orange juice. Thus, no tariff value could be attributed to the local content rule. Even if one could, it would require a tariff of the order of 100, 200 or 300 per cent to protect the Australian citrus concentrate juice industry from Brazil. And why? It is not because of cheap labour. That is a great myth. The Brazilian industry is not based on cheap labour. The Brazilian industry, which is the largest in the world, produces—

TALK.START.PARA: —How much do they get paid?
—I am just getting to that, Senator Boswell. The Brazilian industry is founded on three fundamental factors: firstly, very large production units, very large farms, with hundreds of acres—
—Owned by?

—Owned largely by way of investment from the US. Secondly, it is technologically very advanced. In Brazil, oranges are picked through mechanisation; they are not picked by hand. They only grow for one market: the citrus juice concentrate market. They do not grow for the whole fruit market. The third factor which makes the Brazilians much more competitive is that they do not require the more expensive irrigation that at least three areas in Australia require. So for those three reasons Australia cannot compete in the citrus juice concentrate market, and the growers accept that. They know they cannot compete dollar for dollar against Brazil.

PARA.TAB: There are two areas in which the Australian citrus industry can compete: the whole fruit export market and the fresh juice market. Unfortunately, in Australia, particularly in the three southern regions—New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria—a significant proportion of their production, and for most growers the majority, goes to juice concentrate. The tables which I have just incorporated show that those who grow for the concentrate sector receive $90 a tonne and their production costs are $150 a tonne. Clearly, growers cannot make any profit in the concentrate area. However, with regard to fresh juice products, growers receive $176 a tonne. So they make a small profit in that area. With regard to domestic fresh orange sales, they receive $200 a tonne. Obviously, they make a reasonable profit in that area. With regard to export sales of fresh navel oranges and valencias, the figures are $324 a tonne and $224 a tonne respectively.

In the last six years, Australian exports of citrus have grown from 32,000 tonnes to 100,000 tonnes last year and are valued at $89 million. Interestingly, the proportion of production of citrus for export has risen from six per cent to over 14 per cent last year. That is clearly where the future lies, and the industry certainly knows it.

I also want to mention the Queensland industry; I am sure that Senator Boswell is aware of it. The Queensland citrus industry is, by comparison with its southern counterparts, relatively successful. Why?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it gets the market opportunity.

—It is successful because it has a market opportunity, which is due to its strategic geographical and climate position. But there are two other reasons why the citrus industry in Queensland is much more successful than its southern counterpart. I have visited the growing area in southern Queensland. The farms are much larger and the production units are much more efficient. Senator Boswell is nodding; he agrees.

PARA.TAB: The second, and most critical, factor is that in Queensland the growers hand-pick their oranges. Eighty to 90 per cent of the fruit in Queensland is of such good quality that it is sold as whole fruit either domestically or for export. Only the waste—10 per cent of the product—goes to juice. In the southern areas, only 30 per cent of the oranges goes to whole fruit production, while 70 per cent goes to juice production. For the citrus industry to survive in southern Australia—and the growers accept this—the growers have to increase their pack-out rate from 30 per cent to at least 60 or 70 per cent. There is no survival for the citrus industry in juice concentrate. It is not a pleasant message, but there is no absolutely no way that it can compete in that sector.

The government's package is aimed at ensuring that the citrus industry develops in both the fresh juice market and the export market. I will outline a couple of areas. The industry says that the $9 million package over five years is not enough. Unfortunately, it is never enough. We always get claims to government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nine million dollars!

—Senator Boswell says that $9 million is not enough. How would he fund it? He keeps saying to the government, `Reduce expenditure.' We are increasing expenditure by $9 million outside normal budget allocations, yet he keeps saying to us, `Reduce budget expenditure. Make cutbacks.' Where would he make the cutbacks or increase the taxes to fund the increase in this area? Where would he increase taxes? He cannot give us an answer. His problem is that he is stuck for an answer.

PARA.TAB: The second area of assistance the government is providing is a write-off of expenditure on all new horticultural plantations. The details of that will be released shortly. What sort of programs will be considered in the context of the $9 million?

TALK.START.PARA: —Very little, for $9 million.

—Senator Boswell has not heard. I am just about to run through some of the programs. We need to look at a quality program; export marketing; product identity, because we do not have good product identity in the international marketplace; citrus promotion; research for new markets; and fresh juice promotion. Those are the sorts of areas that the $9 million should be devoted to. The industry will have a major input into how that money is spent. A citrus group, of which I understand I will be a member, will be charged with the responsibility of developing those programs for the industry.

PARA.TAB: I want to revert back to the sales tax issue. The industry's preferred approach was a sales tax option of zero on fresh juice beverages. What would that have returned to the growers? We need to help the growers; we are not helping the processors or the consumers. The economic modelling that the government has done shows that that would have returned only $0.5 million to growers' pockets, which would have returned only $162 to each grower.

So the industry's preferred position in playing around with the sales tax regime would not have given any great assistance to growers. That is why, aside from the fact that it would almost certainly have been GATT inconsistent with the fiddling around of the sales tax regime, depending on which sales tax package was picked up, it would have cost the government significant millions of dollars in revenue. That is why the government decided that the sales tax approach was the wrong approach. Unfortunately, the citrus industry has become a little obsessive about the sales tax issue, but it is not the solution to its problems. A solution for the growers does not lie in that area.

The citrus industry is a great Australian industry, valued at $320 million. There are 3,000 citrus growers in Australia. As I said earlier when I tabled statistics relating to the citrus industry, the unfortunate fact is that growers in New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria are not able, and never will be able, to compete in that juice concentrate area. It is just not possible.

There is a range of fundamental problems that growers face in the southern states. Many of their properties are too small. The traditional five- or 10-acre blocks are just too small a production unit to make a sustainable living. They are just not big enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your rationalisation for the reconstruction process? Tell us.
—I have already outlined our approach. There are significant problems with water resources and water allocation and very significant irrigation problems in the three—
—Where is the money for that?

—I am not going to go into that. We have made significant contributions to upgrading many of those properties, for example in the Riverland. It is primarily a state government responsibility, Senator Watson, which the states have grossly neglected. For example, state governments put soldier settlers in the irrigation areas and did not upgrade the infrastructure. If one were to go to the Murrumbidgee area, one would see open channel irrigation. I feel great sympathy for growers who are put into these areas where governments do not upgrade the irrigation and make sure that there is effective, modern and cost effective delivery of water.

PARA.TAB: I have already outlined some of the other problems of the citrus industry. This government is very well aware of the problems the industry faces. That is one of the reasons why there was a specific task force to look at the problems. The Queensland industry—and Senator Boswell is here—shows the way in which the industry has to develop. It has to look at the fundamental advantages and the fundamental criteria that the Queensland industry has and it has to model itself largely on that approach. There is not any other option. We have got to move those export figures as quickly as we can because that is where survival lies. The figures over the last five years have been very good and, with the sort of package we have designed, they should continue to increase.

Under the GATT, there will be significant progress in market access, in getting our citrus industry exports overseas and breaking into those markets where there is unreasonable protection. For example, apples and citrus are two of the target commodities to break into the China market and GATT gives us the opportunity to make those breakthroughs. I have concentrated my comments on the citrus industry because I know it is a matter of deep concern to many senators. It has been mentioned by Senator Short and I am sure it will be mentioned by others in the debate. The government package is a responsible one. It is correctly targeted and it really was the only way in which effective assistance could have been provided to the citrus industry.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I open my remarks by saying that I am speaking on behalf of Senator Sandy Macdonald, Senator McGauran and Senator O'Chee, who have recognised that five minutes would not be a suitable amount of time to address these bills. So we have combined our contributions and I will be speaking on behalf of those senators.

PARA.TAB: Today we are cognately debating bills which represent the government's response to Australia's Uruguay Round obligations. The changes introduced by these bills are scheduled to come into operation on the commencement of the World Trade Organisation agreement scheduled for 1 July 1995 or some later date as declared under these bills. Five bills being introduced under this package relate to the areas of copyright, patents, dairy produce and new sales tax regimes for fruit juice and cheese, and there are two bills with amendments to our anti-dumping and countervailing laws.

The Uruguay Round of GATT has been under negotiation since 1986. For the first time agriculture was considered within the GATT round. Australia through the Cairns Group played a major role in encouraging an outcome to the ultimate benefit of our primary industries. Our internationally efficient primary industries have suffered and continue to suffer from years of savaging from the high subsidy practices of other developed nations—in the main, the Economic Union, the US and Japan. As a consequence, Australian primary industries will benefit from the outcome of the Uruguay Round. It must be said that our wheat, beef, sugar and rice industries will benefit from these reforms but not to the full extent that they should. At the same time, some primary industries will have to undergo adjustments to their present arrangements, which has necessitated these present bills under debate today.

A further consequence of the Uruguay Round agreements is that other primary industries which receive no assistance at all, such as the pork and egg industries, will be thrust into a new marketing scheme where trade is opened up for imports into Australia while at the same time tariff levels will still be very high for competing countries thereby thrusting Australian industries into a most unfair international trading situation. At this stage it must be pointed out that Australian primary industries played an integral role in attaining a successful outcome to the Uruguay Round. They led by example and selflessly took enormous cuts in tariffs, deregulated domestic markets and gave up other assistance measures at enormous cost to primary industries and individual primary producers. They are the real, unsung heroes of the Uruguay Round resolution. Sadly, they form a long line of casualties as they have been forced to adjust rapidly to free trade which other competing nations were not practising.

Under the Uruguay Round agreement, tariffs will be cut by an average of 36 per cent with a minimum for individual items of 15 per cent, volumes of subsidised exports will be cut by 21 per cent and outlays on export subsidies will be cut by 36 per cent over a six-year implementation period for developed countries and 10 years for developing countries. Overall, the value of domestic support for agriculture is to be reduced by 20 per cent from the base level in 1986-88. ABARE predicts a $1 billion benefit to Australian rural industries from the liberalisation of world trade resulting from the resolution of the Uruguay Round. However, particular rural industries which will be severely hurt by the outcome will have to face a future of changed circumstances and new threats to their continued survival. These industries involve the smaller primary industries of citrus, tobacco, pig farming and egg producing.

There are two ways that some rural industries will suffer hurt rather than benefit from the Uruguay Round agreement: firstly, from the domestic changes reflected in these bills and, secondly, from the remaining unfair trading situations that will still exist even after tariff and other subsidy reforms have been implemented in competing countries over the six-year implementation period. For some countries with enormously high tariff levels at present, a 35 per cent reduction will still leave them with very high tariffs and a trading advantage over the unassisted Australian industries. For example, even after a 36 per cent tariff reduction, rice tariffs in Japan will stand at a massive 700 per cent. Canadian tariffs on egg products will only reduce from 196 per cent to 167 per cent—a reduction from 94c a dozen to 80c a dozen. The unassisted Australian egg industry has been receiving 84c a dozen from the consumer for the last five years. So the subsidy for Canadian eggs is as much as the Australian producer gets for the sale of his eggs.

Let us look at where other citrus producing countries will be in the year 2001, at the end of the six-year implementation period. At five per cent, Australian producers will effectively have no tariffs. The US will only go from 47 per cent to 40 per cent, Brazil from 105 per cent to 35 per cent, Israel from 142 per cent to 120 per cent, Japan from 35 per cent to 25 per cent and Spain and Italy from 44 per cent to 38 per cent.

I point out again that Australia is at zero tariffs. This will be the new trading environment Australian producers will have to compete in—still against high tariffs. Also, Australian industries enjoying no tariff protection at the same time will have to adjust to liberalised quarantine requirements opening up an influx of imports of highly subsidised products.

The bills being debated today contain changes to present schemes which are considered contrary to GATT. Australia, in its lonely and hard path over recent years, has ended up with one of the least assisted primary industry sectors in the world. Accordingly, there are very few schemes which require amending by means of domestic legislation to comply with GATT. The exceptions are the dairy export scheme, the local sales tax regime for fruit juice and the local content scheme for tobacco.

As the National Party Leader in the Senate, I would like to address these bills as they affect the citrus, tobacco and dairy industries. The Dairy Produce (World Trade Organization) Amendment Bill provides for the termination of the market support payments to the dairy industry. The export subsidy scheme is to be terminated from 30 June 1995 and a new domestic market support mechanism is to be introduced from July 1995. At the moment, levies are imposed on the industry on the milk fat content of whole milk and its products. These levies go to a market support fund for payment to all exports of dairy products. This bill brings forward the termination date of the scheme from 30 June 2000 set by the Crean plan.

On the eve of the Senate being asked to pass this legislation, the government has declared its new dairy scheme, which in effect replaces present arrangements with a scheme of the same benefit but which is GATT legal. With the qualification that the government should have and could have announced its dairy plan earlier than the day before this legislation, the coalition supports the bill.

ABARE predicts that the dairy industry will benefit from the implementation of the Uruguay Round reforms through four per cent world price increases for butter, 12 per cent for cheese and 16 per cent for milk powders. Also, Australian production will have a one per cent increase in volume, worth $320 million, and a 10 per cent increase in exports, worth $210 million a year.

I commend the industry, particularly Pat Rowley, on its restructuring and management of the industry and on the development of a highly successful export industry. Under the Sales Tax (World Trade Organization) Bill, the concessional sales tax rate that currently applies to fruit and vegetable juice products from Australia, New Zealand and Papua New Guinea will be terminated, with all juice and fruit products from all countries that contain greater than 25 per cent juice being taxed at 11 per cent.

The effect of this bill, in particular on the citrus industry, will be to introduce major changes to be encountered by growers. These industries have been structured on and have operated on the current sales tax system for 60 years, and new sales tax arrangements will impact immediately as reduced sales and reduced demand for their product.

The government conducted an inquiry into the citrus and horticultural industries and sat on the report for over a year, creating great uncertainty for industry planning. On Tuesday of this week, two days before the Senate was meant to vote on major industry changes, the government brought in a most inadequate industry support package. I would describe it as absolutely pathetic.

The government, despite its horticultural task force recommendation, decided against introducing a zero sales tax rate for pure fruit juice and mixed juices, currently at a rate of 11 per cent, despite the fact that other beverages such as milk, tea and coffee enjoy a zero sales tax status. Since the government will not act, it has to face up to the continued survival of the Australian citrus industry, which the government has given a mere $9 million package. It is a poor way to treat a viable but smaller Australian primary industry. It is the same with the tobacco industry; it has also not been given its promised package, and I have taken this up with Senator Collins.

The Mareeba-Dimbulah region of North Queensland has supported a thriving tobacco industry since the government set up an import replacement industry in the 1930s. Even in its present rationalised position, tobacco growing is the mainstay of these regions, providing $50 million a year to local economies. As I mentioned earlier, the tobacco industry is one of the smaller industries that, in the overall interests of free trade under the Uruguay Round agreement, have become a victim of the agreement.

Under the Uruguay Round schedule for tobacco submitted by the Australian government, a tariff quota for imported tobacco has been set at 11.184 million kilograms. This large quota was based on the base years of 1986-88, when much higher quantities of tobacco were being manufactured than at present. It is interesting that all sectors of the industry—the growers, the manufacturers and the government and its trade officials—agree that, because the new import quota level is based on a very high base level, the resulting tariff quota is incorrectly based. The new quota leaves the local industry with only 20 per cent of the market to supply, on top of a 35 per cent reduction in quota last year.

Certain basic facts are relevant to the present plight of the tobacco industry. Tobacco growers are like all other farmers—growers of a legal crop. Over the last 10 years, tobacco growers have faced the problems in their industry and have rationalised with 50 per cent of the growers leaving the industry. At the same time, the government has received great windfalls from the industry. Last year excise duties amounted to $1.4 billion, which is up from $189,000 in 1964. State licence fees were $7.348 billion. All in all, total government revenue amounted to $8.7 billion.

The industry now needs time and help to restructure. Government injection of direct assistance to the tobacco industry is needed as a necessary consequence of the major adjustment demanded by the harsh GATT schedule on the industry. It appears that the government is virtually deserting these smaller industries adversely affected by the GATT commitments. The tobacco, citrus, egg and pork industries are all in that category.

By comparison, overseas governments have acted on compensating their industries that are being damaged by the new GATT requirements. In Japan the government has committed $83 billion—not million—to help its protected farmers adjust to foreign competition, with an extra $16.3 billion to help rural regions develop new businesses. The US has made trade-offs to assist its farmers. These vital industries such as the tobacco and the citrus industries, although small, should not be left to wither and die without adequate and comprehensive industry adjustment support.

Another important aspect following from the Uruguay Round agreement relates to the changes that will be made to our anti-dumping and countervailing legislation by means of the customs legislation, including the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill. It is an area of particular interest to me.

To the credit of the government, during former Senator Button's term in the industry portfolio, important reforms were introduced for primary industries which reflect the recommendations of the Senate inquiry that I initiated. These included the extension of actions to farmers who suffer from the presence of dumped and subsidised processed imports in Australia.

I refer to the government's 1991 March industry statement which was described by former Senator Button in a December ministerial statement as the `changes to our anti-dumping and countervailing laws intended to provide better access to the system for Australian producers'. This was further reflected in the March industry statement which said that legislation would be drafted along the lines of that in place in the United States to ensure that the injuries suffered by agriculture and horticulture as a result of dumping or subsidisation of processed products will be taken into consideration in dumping and countervailing actions. This will give agricultural and horticultural producers, when they are truly integrated, an avenue for redress when they fall victim to unfair trading practices in the processed products part of their industry. However, the bills being debated today, which formalise the GATT requirements, make changes which will affect the 1991 reforms for better access for farmers to anti-dumping and countervailing actions and better avenues for redress.

For the first time formal standing requirements are being introduced before an applicant can bring an anti-dumping or countervailing action. Under proposed new clause 15D an applicant must now have the support of persons producing 50 per cent of the total production of the like good in Australia. Of this 50 per cent support, the applicant must account for 25 per cent of the production of the like goods in Australia.

This differs from the present position where any person may initiate an anti-dumping or countervailing action. There is no legislated standing requirement and whether or not the applicant is supported by the wider part of the industry concerned is not legally relevant. Under the amendments only support from the processing industry can be used in the calculation.

Unless farmers can get the support of the majority of processors they will be prevented from launching an anti-dumping action. Customs pointed out to the Senate committee hearing that the present form has a section to be filled in stating that the application is supported by a majority of the industry—this being an administrative requirement rather than the formal legalised requirement it will now become. It appears that the industry is fairly disillusioned with our anti-dumping scheme—it is extremely costly and unpredictable.

With increasing trade liberalisation, Australian industry needs a fair and effective anti-dumping and countervailing system. I was pleased to be reassured by the government at the Senate committee hearing that the Australian industry, for the purpose of determining material injury, will still include the closed processed agricultural industry. But, in the case of dumping and subsidisation, it is the farmer who suffers from the loss of sales and reduced prices from the presence in the domestic market of dumped and subsidised processed goods. These amendments, in making it harder legally for farmers to initiate actions, can only make a hard path even harder for the farmer in the uphill battle against dumped and imported subsidised goods.

I support these bills in the interest of ensuring that Australia fulfils its Uruguay Round obligations. But in doing so I criticise the government severely for forcing the opposition to vote for these bills when the dairy package and the inadequate citrus package were only announced within days of the vote, and there is no tobacco package at all. I strongly emphasise the need for an effective anti-dumping and countervailing system for Australian industries and register my concern about the even more difficult path that will face farmers who are now real victims of dumped and subsidised imports.

The coalition finds itself between a rock and a hard place with these bills. We have enormous sympathy for the position that some of the smaller industries find themselves in, particularly the citrus industry. (Extension of time granted) But the benefits and the gains of changes in world trade for the winning industries cannot be put under threat.

Certainly the NFF has spoken strongly on behalf of its rural industry members, who want these bills to go through unamended. It has also called for periods of managed change for its industries that will suffer, which we have wholeheartedly and continually called for. The Uruguay Round agreements have tied Australia to certain formal requirements. The gains that will be made for primary industries are welcomed and the farmers are to be congratulated for their contribution to the efforts. However, the pain felt by some smaller industries could have been lessened by a more generous and far-sighted approach by the federal government.

TALK.START.PARA: I would like to speak on the anti-dumping provisions in the Customs Legislation (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994. The Customs Legislation (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994 proposes to amend the Customs Act 1901 and the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988 to bring Australia into line with the Uruguay Round Anti-Dumping Agreement and the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Agreement. Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing measures regime is very similar to the existing codes. Many of the amendments in the bill would as a result enact procedures that are already followed at an administrative level.

PARA.TAB: The most important amendments proposed in the bill would alter the methodology of determining whether dumping had occurred. Dumping is actionable when the export price of the goods concerned is less than the normal value of the goods and material injury to an Australian industry producing like goods has been or is being caused or threatened or the establishment of an Australian industry producing like goods has been or may be materially hindered.

Clause 10 of the bill clarifies the procedures for determining the normal value of a good. In some cases the price of a good in its domestic market is not an appropriate measure of its normal value. For example, a product might not be sold on the domestic market. If such a situation exists, the value of the good is determined on the basis of its price in the third country or by assigning to it a notional value. The bill sets out criteria for selecting an appropriate third country and details the factors that have to be taken into account in constructing a normal value.

The existence of dumping is currently determined by comparing the export price of a product with its normal value on a transaction by transaction basis. Clause 11 of the bill adds two new methods of determining the existence of dumping which may simplify investigations in some cases. Clause 15 of the bill proposes to require that an anti-dumping application be supported by, firstly, producers that represent more than 50 per cent of the total production or output of that proportion of the industry that indicates its support or opposition to the application and, secondly, producers that represent not less than 25 per cent of the total production of goods in Australia.

Anti-dumping applications are currently required to be supported by producers who represent a major proportion of the total domestic output, but major proportion has never been precisely defined. Clause 12 proposes to amend the system for assessing the material injury to industry due to dumping or to subsidisation. Section 269TAE of the Customs Act lists a number of indicators that can be used to assess the injury. Clause 12 adds the size of the dumping margin if relevant or the particulars of the subsidy concerned to the list. The bill adds to the section a list of factors such as contractions in demand that must be considered as possible alternative causes for the injury and tightens the definition of a threatened injury by limiting it to foreseeable and imminent threats.

The opposition supports the World Trade Organisation package. We nonetheless have a number of concerns about the government's administration of the anti-dumping and countervailing system. I foreshadow that the coalition will be moving a second reading amendment to the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill and the Customs Legislation (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill.

The thrust of those amendments is to urge the government to significantly reduce the inquiry period for anti-dumping and to ensure that the administration of the anti-dumping system, and particularly the material injury provisions, is no more stringent than the comparable policies adopted by other members of the World Trade Organisation. The purpose of that is for the administrators not to take a harder line than that which other countries are taking, because that is really pretty stupid. So that is the basis of the amendment that has been or will be circulated in my name and will be moved at the end of the second reading stage.

The inquiry period for anti-dumping and countervailing cases is still too long, despite the government's reforms to the system in 1991. The inquiry period could be reduced to as few as 155 days if the Customs Service and Anti-Dumping Authority investigations were carried out concurrently.

For some years now Australian industries have pointed out that the government's administration of the anti-dumping system is significantly tighter than that in overseas jurisdictions, such as the United States. In the Thai tuna case, it was impossible to obtain accurate information about the normal value of Thai canned tuna exports because none of the 12 exporters answered Customs' questions; nine of the 12 refused access to their premises and records; and the three who did provide information provided highly selective material.

The information submitted to Customs by the Australian industry revealed that the dumping margin for Thai tuna was about 52 per cent. The Australian Customs Service based its constructed values on the inadequate and unrepresentative information that was supplied by the three cooperative tuna exporters. In short, the uncooperative foreign exporters were favoured at the expense of the Australian industry, in contrast with the US system where uncooperative foreign exporters were penalised.
The World Trade Organisation bills mark the end of a protracted and difficult series of negotiations. Subject to the provisos I mentioned, the coalition supports the bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The `World Trade Organisation bills'—what is wrong with that title? The main thing wrong with it is that we are not actually considering whether we want to belong to the World Trade Organisation, what it might mean for us, what it might mean for all Australians, what it might mean for Australian law or the democratic process we have in this country or in this place. We are not asked to consider who might win or who might lose.

PARA.TAB: We might get some vague reassurances of generalised wellbeing. This will mean so many million dollars in extra trade. Is this a good thing? Even economically, it depends on the ratio between imports and exports. Trade by itself is not an advantage.

Even when we talk exports, there are questions. This will mean so many millions in extra exports. Which industries will that affect? How will that affect jobs? How will it affect the capacity to develop in the future? Economically, questions arise like: how much value added is there in these exports? Are we talking low value added tonnage increases? In that case, will X million in exports translate into much real good for the economy? Will it translate into investment if part of the package is to deregulate investment and money transfers so that there are no multiplier effects and the profits simply all vanish into the international market?

I am asking some general questions, although they do not appear to be in the context of these bills. The major rationale for what we are doing in these bills is that the changes are required for the World Trade Organisation. There is no good reason, no independent reason, being put for any of these measures. Nowhere in the explanatory memoranda or second reading speeches from the House do we hear, `Our present dairy support arrangements are no good because they hurt our industries or they have this negative effect.' No. The only reason on offer is that our laws are World Trade Organisation inconsistent. So, if the only reason on offer for these changes is that we need them for the World Trade Organisation, questions about why we need the World Trade Organisation are completely in context and in order.

There are general assurances that freer trade will have benefits. It will have casualties too, but we will skip that for the moment. In other cases, we could make general assertions. Foreign aid will have great benefits for both donor and recipient. Yet I do not see us rushing out to increase our aid budget or even to bring it up to the recommended level of 0.7 per cent. Development of energy efficiency and energy conservation will lower ecological costs, lower imports, create jobs, stimulate high-tech innovation and stimulate appropriate technology that can be exported. I do not see any push for the development of energy conservation or efficiency. We will not even meet our greenhouse targets. This target—World Trade Organisation consistency—is one which we have to meet. That this assurance—that regulating nations to assure trade is unregulated—is good for us we do not question and we act on with urgency.

We will debate the bills extensively in committee. The Greens have amendments to all of the bills, and there are other amendments also. There will be plenty of chances to look at those issues. There is almost no chance to look at the real issue—the WTO, Australian membership in it and what it will mean. The cognate debate on all these very different pieces of legislation is the only opportunity parliament will ever get to consider the WTO and the actual implications of membership.

I have been told from time to time that there is no reduction of sovereignty under the WTO, that it is not an issue. We are told parliament will be responsible, will have power, that all our changes of law will have to be considered and passed in this place. If that is true as far as it goes, we will have to pass the laws here in both senses of that phrase. The laws are made here, but we will also be required here to make them WTO consistent. Just look at the panic now to assure that these laws are changed, and changed straightaway—and the WTO does not even exist yet.

Once the WTO does exist, we will be required to change more of our laws because of WTO agreements and regulations or because of challenges under existent WTO laws. How realistic is the option to say no? We can back out of WTO altogether, but what would that mean, especially after we as a nation lose more and more manufacturing and become increasingly dependent on imports for our society to run, and on exports to pay for the imports? Theoretically, it is possible to back out, but how practical and realistic is it?

People here may be surprised that I am not calling for us to back out of international trade. I do think there are problems with trade dependency and I think greater self-reliance is a good thing. But what I am really calling for is responsible trade. If national and subnational governments, and the people they represent, are to be stripped of their powers to regulate any aspect of the economy, then there must be some other mechanism to regulate the economy, to bring some form of law, some level of responsibility and accountability, in relation to economic actions. Economic might does not mean economic right any more than `might makes right' works as a principle of social regulation. International monopoly or oligopoly power is not more attractive than national monopoly.

The World Trade Organisation is a body that will have substantially more actual power than the United Nations or any other international panel or organisation. Admittedly, on the odd occasion, the United Nations can organise troop movements or impose sanctions but, generally, it is singularly ineffectual. The situations when it acts require general support by all members and strong support by the dominant powers. The situations need to be something like Cambodia or apartheid in South Africa. Even so, if some nation breaks the sanctions, the United Nations generally does little except say `Tut-tut' and pass resolutions that get ignored.

The International Convention on Human Rights has been in place for decades and signatories still do pretty much what they want to. As signatories we followed the White Australia policy with impunity. If we look closely, there are many laws and practices which do not conform to the convention. Even the privacy bill does not really address the question of rights of gays and lesbians. But the United Nations does not have any program to demand consistency with the human rights convention. It is an undertaking of the signatories. The United Nations might point out cases brought to its attention as flagrant violations and might chide nations, but it actually does nothing. It has no power in relation to any but the worst abuses—quasi-slavery, genocide or invasions—and even then only when member nations are individually willing to take action.

By contrast, the World Trade Organisation has in its charter that all member nations must make their federal and subfederal laws WTO consistent. By the way, even local government laws can be changed. The WTO can and will take action. It can and will impose economic sanctions. The options are to conform with the WTO or, if it gets up, which looks probable, to be outside it. Once the WTO gets up GATT disappears, although if the WTO does not get up GATT continues.
Is there a difference between GATT and the World Trade Organisation? Yes. The GATT was less powerful and nations had to sign on

SPEECH.PARA: to various agreements on trade. Not all agreements were signed. Once GATT disappears, the World Trade Organisation will have powers to establish regulations that apply to all members on the basis of a two-thirds, or occasionally a three-quarter, vote of members. All member nations then need to make their laws conform, unless they want to leave the WTO or face sanctions. So we could, in the future, vote against a new regulation and we would still have it imposed on us. What kind of sovereignty is that?

PARA.TAB: How democratic is this? Who is the representative of the Australian people in an organisation which sets the framework for Australian law? How is that representative chosen? People may not know that our ambassador to the WTO, Don Kenyan, serves a three-year term and is now finishing his first year. He is not elected; he is appointed. He takes direction from the minister. The position he takes does not need to be consistent with Australian law, or any position of the parliament, or any position of the people, nor does he need to consult with anyone except the minister and the department. He effectively has the power to push for WTO rules, admittedly at the direction of the minister, which the WTO will then ask Australia to make its laws consistent with.

Must we, the parliament, then change our laws? Not technically; we can always leave the WTO or face sanctions. I ask those in this chamber to answer honestly to themselves whether that is likely. I ask them to look at what we are currently doing: we are pushing through changes of law without much real reason to make them consistent with the WTO. I ask them to look at the panic that is whipped up if anyone suggests that we would not change any of these laws in a way that is WTO consistent, no matter what reason is offered for non-WTO law in terms of its effect on Australian people.

We are told that there are only two options: we can shut up, join up and take orders or we can lose out on the WTO-Uruguay Round goldmine. Is it really that simple, that stark a choice? I do not believe it. There must be some options. Is there any way of making this thing more accountable? Is there any way of assuring that the Australian people actually get some voice and that legitimate social concerns can be addressed? Is there any way of granting greater latitude for national regulation which may affect trade but is primarily pursuing valid social goals? Is there any way of assuring that the benefits of the WTO actually go towards improving the lot of the majority of people, and specifically those most in need?

If the consequences of the WTO regime are a race to the bottom, to the lowest standard of public and environmental protection, to the most exploitative practices, to increased concentration of economic power, is there any way of monitoring that, of turning it around? Today we see that the ones who will survive in the citrus industry will be the big ones, the ones who use most water and most inputs. Just think of what we have said. I would suggest, and I know I do not get much support in this place on this, that it is imperative to ask these questions now and do what we can to ensure that some options, some accountability and some responsibility are built into the WTO before it is set up. If we do not do this, we will be left with the stark choice: comply or suffer the consequences.

The opposition has made great running on the issue of treaties. It whips up fear about the loss of sovereignty in relation to the human rights convention, the desertification convention and other agreements that really have little power or teeth, very little effect. The only thing these conventions really do is provide a basis for federal government to act if it decides to. There are no enforceable requirements besides a few treaties that might generate real action like the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, and even that is enforced haphazardly. Here we have a case where we are required to change our laws, including state and local laws, whether or not federal government agrees. If another nation says that they are not consistent with the WTO, attempts will be made to force us to do so. We can refuse to change our laws, but there will be penalties. We can leave the WTO, but there will be penalties for that too.

The Greens will put up amendments in respect of these bills to ensure that, at the very least, if we get into this organisation, our representative respects Australian law or takes direction from federal parliament as the democratically elected body representing all Australians. I understand the Democrats will support them. They can go ahead with the support of either of the major parties. If the coalition does not support these amendments, it will be shown up as a sham which does not care a fig about real issues of sovereignty and which only raises the issue to undermine efforts to ensure human rights and prevent environmental damage. If it does not support the amendments, it would be shown up as being ignorant of the real implications of this package. I would remind the government that, while the prospect of not having to deal with real democracy and conflicting viewpoint might please it, at some point it might be a coalition cabinet which gives direction to our representatives. But then maybe neither big party worries because their economic policies are virtually identical.

The Greens are deeply concerned that throughout the long process leading up to the formation of the WTO there was no effort to accurately communicate to the public the nature and structure of this organisation. There was minimal communication about the position Australia takes and has taken in the negotiations on establishing the WTO, or on issues such as the social clause, or positions taken within the trade environment subcommittee of the WTO.

There was no public consultation or any mechanism set up for public comment or input. There was no discussion in the parliament, apart from the opportunity to ask questions or debate motions. As a consequence, there are few people who are at all clear on how the WTO will work, what powers it can exercise, how it could have been set up, what options are available and what requirements it actually makes.

For example, we are told that the intellectual property bills, the patent amendment and the copyright amendment are required. Why are they required before the WTO is actually set up? What measures are actually required and which ones fall under the one-year transition period? What other measures will be required but which are not immediately required, so are not before us?
