Where do we see a presentation of the whole cost of the WTO, the whole impact on our legislation and the impact on people's lives and enterprises that are affected by this legislation?

When we ask whether the parliament will be party to a decision to accept the WTO, the reaction we get is that there is no need; non-membership is unthinkable. In such a situation, how realistic are claims that sovereignty is not affected because we do not necessarily need to conform to WTO regulations? Yet we are not presented with what it means. Whatever legitimate questions are asked, we are met with bland reassurances or disdain.

It is easy to say that the WTO is obviously good because trade is good and it will increase trade. I have my doubts, and I have my doubts about the billions of dollars that are claimed as the benefits of the Uruguay Round, or the even more billions claimed as the outcome of the APEC summit. Some figures published by ABARE indicate that non-resource extraction manufactures will decline in income by over 20 per cent under GATT and by 40 per cent under APEC. This is not just unskilled labouring; this is most moderately technical, higher-labour production. It probably includes a range of elaborately transformed manufactures. There may be a range of very high-tech research-intensive or niche market items which will not be affected. But, realistically, how many people will work in these industries? Will the job compact take the unemployed and turn them into research scientists, skilled engineers and designers, and top-level computer programmers?

On the other hand, we have the extractive industries—the areas that are supposed to do well from WTO. We will sell a lot more coal. Okay, but will this mean that coal prices will increase? Coal is high volume, low labour, and this means low value added. We do not get much return from the huge tonnage we sell. Will GATT, the WTO or APEC act to increase those prices? There are claims that increased demand will cause prices to rise. If we look at the evidence, with increasing freedom to trade primary commodities, demand has increased, so has supply, and prices have been steadily dropping.

There is more demand for aluminium than ever, yet nations had to get together as a cartel and restrict supply. This benefits the companies, and maybe the nations, but it is the opposite of free trade. It does not seem that free trade has resulted in higher primary commodity prices, and that is what we are set to export more of. Primary commodities is the area in which ABARE says we will export and that is where we will increase our trade. It is not an area that holds many jobs and it is not an area that brings much return. Low profits on zinc and other minerals mean low tax payments. Low labour content means that not much money goes out into the community. Domination of production by internationalised companies under free investment means that reinvestment does not follow and investment does not necessarily occur in Australia.

As we lose our manufacturing under the World Trade Organisation and APEC, our imports will increase. People keep expressing surprise that, whenever the economy recovers a bit, imports shoot up. I cannot understand why there is surprise. We do not make anything much here, so if people buy a video, a toaster, a computer, a CD-ROM drive, a shirt or a tool they will probably be buying imports. And let us face it: the myth that developing cheap-labour nations specialise in simple, low-tech goods is just that—a myth. Chinese textile factories use the latest computer knitting machines. Their factories use computer lathes. Electronic parts are churned out in Indonesia and the Philippines. Chinese TVs and stereos are displacing Japanese and Korean ones. Vietnam is the site of a number of factories for domestic appliances. We are not just talking about textiles, clothing and footwear here; we are talking about virtually all normal non-food consumer items.

Many of these jobs are going or have gone. Where will the benefits be? How many farmers and design engineers does Australia reasonably expect to have? How many people do we reasonably expect them to support? If most profit here is invested somewhere else, what will we do? It is happening, and what are we going to do? These are all questions in relation to the World Trade Organisation.

The World Trade Organisation will set the framework by which these trends are accelerated. Our commitment to the WTO will lock us into this process. What does it mean, and how will we cope? These are questions that have not been answered. We believe that the issues should be examined by Australia's democratic representative and that the questions should be answered before we go much further.
I was wondering whether people are interested in who our new masters will be. I have a diagram of the World Trade Organisation ministerial conference. I seek leave of the Senate to table it.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It tells us which people will now and in the future be deciding laws. We are talking about accessions, the balance of payments, trade and development, budget finance and administration working parties, including tariff related investment, tariff concessions, technical barriers, agriculture, subsidies, countervailing measures and anti-dumping practices. We have heard them mentioned during the debate today. We have even heard that members of the coalition are deeply disturbed by some of the inferences and the running over that is being done by individuals who have expressed concern.

PARA.TAB: The majority of people who spoke at the hearing about these bills expressed deep concerns. This report is not even here in this chamber at the moment; I certainly have not received a copy of it. We are debating legislation, the report on which has not been given to the people who are involved in that process or discussed in any way. We are at the second reading stage, and the information available has not been circulated to the people in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994 and the Customs Legislation (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994, and on behalf of my colleague Senator Parer, I move the following opposition amendment to the motion that these bills be now read a second time:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate urges the Government to:
(a) significantly reduce the inquiry period for anti-dumping and countervailing cases; and

(b) ensure that the administration of the anti-dumping system, and particularly the material injury provisions in the legislation, is no more stringent than the comparable policies adopted by the other members of the World Trade Organisation".

The motion has been circulated to honourable senators. The Liberal members of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee inquiring into the World Trade Organisation amendment bills were moved by the sincerity and concerns expressed, particularly by the citrus growers and the problems that they will face. The package the government has offered does not address the fact that the losers in this game are essentially small people, particularly small citrus growers, and small people in most of the other areas that are covered by this legislation. The Liberal Party members were so moved that they had included in the report this statement:

. . . the Committee notes the concerns of the Liberal Party Senators representing the Coalition who have expressed their dissatisfaction at the inadequacy of the Government's response to the government's recommendations of the Horticultural Task Force and the problems faced by citrus growers.

I listened very carefully to Senator Sherry, but he did not mention compensation for reconstruction. The small people just have to cop it sweet. That is all very well, but at the stroke of a pen people's livelihoods have suddenly been destroyed.

PARA.TAB: This bill is deceptive in appearance. Its brevity disguises the significant impact it will have on the livelihood not only of Australian citrus growers but also of their employees, such as pickers and packers, and others involved in the communications industry. The amendment will have effect from no later than 1 January 1995 or the day the agreement established by the World Trade Organisation enters into force for Australia.

Whilst it is conceded that the world trade agency will reap Australia significant benefits—we often hear this from the government—which have been estimated to be $2.6 billion per year, we cannot and must not lose sight of the devastating effect that this bill will have, particularly on the citrus industry. The losers cannot simply be ignored because there will be winners arising from this package. The package is completely inadequate.

The government seems to have finally seen the light. It recognised part of this fact, I think, when Senator Collins admitted on Tuesday that the termination of the local content rule will place adjustment pressure on industries currently benefiting from this measure, particularly citrus growers. But I put to the Senate that adjustment pressure is a bit of an understatement. The leadership should come from the government, but the government has failed to provide a proper recompense, failed to live up to the hopes and aspirations of all the people who attended the meetings and who made such a significant input. Senator Sherry, in his speech, virtually wrote off the future of the citrus growers in Victoria and South Australia. Where is the reconstruction focus?

What has the government offered to alleviate the negative impacts of the bill on fruit growers? First, we have the bill here before us. At least the Liberal Party members held up the report until the thrust of the government's response was provided. This Senate is entitled to the details of the package before we pass the legislation.

Firstly, let us look at the concept of taxation write-offs on expenditure on all new horticultural plantations. Details of the extent of the write-offs are extremely vague because the government has yet to resolve a number of complex issues. This is just not good enough. The government has had plenty of time. It procrastinated, for good political intent. I ask—and I ask the minister to respond—how long the provisions are designed to apply for. Will they be of short duration?

In addition, the write-off actually implies an expenditure recognition or deduction during the period in which the expense was incurred. Is this correct or are we looking for a write-off in terms of an allocation over a number of years? If this is the case, we have to make sure that that write-off is at least as generous as that provided for other countries, such as New Zealand and the United States. We must ensure that our tax treatment for new plantations is not to be less generous than that given by our competitors. After all, we are now players on the world stage. If we are players on the world stage, we have to have the downside—the expenditure side—adjusted to recognise what other people are doing and what we are entitled to do. Nothing less.

The second part of the package concerns a market diversification program which is to cost $9 million over five years. The package is aimed at providing assistance to support the industry in its efforts to reduce its reliance on the juice concentrate sector and to increase sales of fresh fruit and fresh juice, with a focus on export. This is great, but it is a bit hard to expect small family organisations, people on small acreages of 10 or 20 hectares, suddenly to have to travel around Europe or Asia.

The industry has been asking for sales tax recognition. Why did the government not do what other countries have done in having a phase-down? Surely this would be logical. If the package is to go over five years, why can there not be compensations in relation to sales tax phase-down on a comparable basis? We are expected to have a cut-off point where suddenly people's livelihoods are affected in a very significant way, but the adjustment is over a long period of time, so there will be intense suffering in the meantime before all these so-called government assistance packages are forthcoming. The assistance which is offered is therefore disappointing. The final comment in Senator Collins's press release announcing the measures states:

SPEECH.PARA: The onus is now on the horticultural industry to take up the challenge.
Yes, the onus is still on it, but surely the onus is also on the government to provide better than it has done in attacking and destroying this industry.

PARA.TAB: My colleague in the House of Representatives Neil Andrew pointed to the problems that citrus growers face in breaking even and the grave problems this bill will create for those growers and their employees. The Senate Economics Legislation Committee, as I mentioned earlier, heard evidence at its public inquiry about the adverse effects on the industry. The government, in its haste to try to ram these bills through the parliament, has not taken enough time to consider that evidence.

I remind the parliament that the citrus industry has survived strong competition from other countries, including that posed by frozen orange juice concentrate from Brazil. The government seems to have just written off the future of this segment of the industry, particularly in South Australia and Victoria, because the whole of Senator Sherry's remarks were directed to the industry in Queensland. I point out that this industry has survived many challenges and will continue to provide jobs for Australians and export income. Not enough recognition was given in Senator Sherry's speech of the adjustments that have already taken place to make this industry very much more efficient. The industry will adapt to the challenges arising from this bill, but it will be costly and time consuming.

I draw attention to the very valuable contributions made by my colleague the member for Wakefield, Mr Neil Andrew, and by his National Party colleague in a neighbouring electorate, Mr John Forrest. They have identified the problem with the 10-year lag between tree planting and economic production. We just do not turn taps on and off. Mr Keating feels we pull levers to make things happen. It does not happen that way in the real world.

The government package has ignored the recommendation of the horticultural task force that 100 per cent fruit juice be sales tax exempt, and rejected outright the proposal. This bill is going to have a very severe impact. I urge the government to give more consideration to the assistance package that it has so far offered the citrus industry. We ask that it give further consideration to the concept of a sales tax exemption for pure fruit juice, given that fruit is a natural food. It seems ironic that there is no sales tax on a pure orange, but as soon as it is squeezed and made into juice it becomes subject to sales tax.

There is something wrong in the government's thinking in allowing a situation of this particular nature. We need a clarification of the depreciation write-offs so that, as soon as possible, the guys can decide whether it is worth continuing and adapting to the new environment created by this bill or whether they should actually close the gate. I call on the government to give these matters its very urgent consideration, giving weight to the fact that the citrus industry provides significant employment and export opportunities. It needs a fair go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on this important package of world trade amendments which promise to boost Australia's agricultural industries in the long term. In particular, I am pleased to reflect on the discussions I have had with the Deputy Leader of the National Party, Mr John Anderson, who is also the shadow minister for primary industry.

PARA.TAB: This package, based on last year's breakthrough in GATT negotiations, heralds a new era for Australia's farmers, processors and manufacturers. The promise of fewer import restrictions, new market opportunities and renewed hope for Australia's agricultural industries means we can look forward to GATT benefits potentially worth $900 million a year. This is the chance efficient producers have been waiting for.

Under the new arrangements, producers will be free to unlock new markets, to develop their export potential and to enhance Australia's good reputation overseas. The federal government also has an important role in this new era. It must do everything in its power to give exporters a fighting chance on international markets. By that I mean lowering costs on production.

On that note, I wish to turn to the legislation. The Dairy Produce (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994 terminates the market support payments to the Australian dairy industry in order to comply with GATT. Currently, dairy farmers pay a levy on all milk. This acts as an incentive to export through payments on export products and effectively discourages producers and manufacturers from dumping product on the domestic market, causing the price to crash. The success of the levy is reflected in the industry's export performance. I am pleased that the government has announced plans to ensure that a GATT legal type of assistance will be available to the industry in the future. Figures show that the dairy industry exports more than $1 billion worth of product a year, a significant contribution to Australia's balance of trade, the national economy and employment.

I turn now to the horticultural industry and the impact of the Sales Tax (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill on the citrus industry in particular. I note the comments Senator Watson has just made. Before GATT, a product containing 25 per cent or more by volume of Australian fruit juice had a sales tax rate of 11 per cent. By contrast, a product containing less than 25 per cent Australian fruit juice had a sales tax rate of 21 per cent. In light of Australia's commitment to new trade arrangements, this preference for Australian product cannot be sustained. Therefore, all juices or drinks containing at least 25 per cent actual juice, regardless of origin, will be taxed at 11 per cent.

Obviously, the citrus industry is disappointed by this development. Over the years, the industry has survived a variety of threats from Brazilian frozen orange juice concentrate and now, as a result of this legislation, stands to lose its home-grown advantage. Brazil is a frontrunner in world juice production mainly because of its climatic conditions, specialisation in the citrus industry and efficient labour force and labour costs. On the world stage, Australia is not regarded as a significant citrus producer. We supply just over one per cent of total world production. Yet the industry is significant to the Australian economy through the domestic market, export income and regional employment opportunities.
Finally, I note the report prepared by the Senate Economics Legislation Committee on this legislation. It states in part:

Representatives of citrus growers expressed concern that abolition of the local content arrangement would remove a stabilising influence on markets for juicing oranges in Australia. Other witnesses confirmed that the industry was efficient in production and use of technology. These advances were threatened by the potential loss of farm income and the loss of some varieties of citrus.

In response to concerns that removal of the local content sales taxes would adversely affect the industry, the Minister advised the Committee that a submission by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy concerning transitional arrangements would be considered by the Government on 28 November 1994.

On 29 November 1994, the Government announced a package of reforms affecting the citrus industry which deal with, among other things, the removal of the local content sales taxes and the promotion of a market diversification program.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the shadow minister for primary industry, John Anderson, has since described the package as miserly and an underestimation of the industry's potential and its need for restructuring. Turning to the recommendations, the committee noted:

. . . the concerns of the Liberal Party Senators representing the Coalition who have expressed their dissatisfaction at the inadequacy of the Government's response to the recommendations of the Horticultural Task Force and the problems faced by citrus growers . . .

The gains brought about by GATT are expected to be significant. While efficient producers can look forward to such gains, the onus will be on the government to restructure the domestic taxation regime so that any hard won benefits are not eroded by existing taxes and imposts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill, the Dairy Produce (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill, the Trade Marks Bill, the Patents (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill, the Customs Tariff (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill, the Customs Legislation (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill and the Copyright (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill are a part of the whole evolution of what is happening in world trade at the moment. This year signifies a turning point in the global approach to trade barriers. The world is finally realising the follies of erecting high tariff walls in order to protect industries.

PARA.TAB: I support all the points made by Senator Short in leading this debate for the opposition. He put the issues very succinctly so I will not take the time of the chamber for very long. The challenge is to make sure that all participating countries subscribe to the provisions they have signed themselves into. This assurance will demand a great deal of diplomacy, especially from those countries that have entered into the GATT with a little reluctance.

This legislation is an indication of Australia's determination—I stress `determination'—to be at the forefront of world trade liberalisation. But being a leader in this area will take perseverance on the part of our political and industry leaders. However, as my colleague Mr Tim Fischer said in the other place, it is imperative that our leaders do not put Australia in a position where we are giving too much away in our bilateral trade negotiations. I am quite sure that, considering the pressure that will be put on the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), who is sitting at the table at the moment, he will make sure that happens. Everyone in Australia will be mindful of what he does about it.

Senator McMullan, the Minister for Trade, has said before that Australia will need to adjust to a much lesser degree than more protected countries. Given that fact, we must be careful not to place ourselves well ahead of the pack and suddenly find ourselves exposed to those who have not quite played the game as far as the GATT is concerned. The success of the GATT in a worldwide sense will depend on global cooperation and the ability to cross the finishing line together. Everyone has to be mindful of that and no-one wants to be left behind.

What has been rather disappointing in my view is the relatively slow response of other countries in ratifying the establishment of the World Trade Organisation. We received the good news yesterday that the United States House of Representatives passed the GATT bill with a substantial 288 to 146 majority. The real test, however, will be the vote in the American Senate tomorrow. Let us hope that sanity prevails and that the seven years of the Uruguay Round negotiations are not wasted because of a negative vote from the United States Senate. There is not much that I can say at this late stage that might influence those good people in the American Senate, except that I hope the bill will receive the same level of support there that I expect this chamber to give to our corresponding legislation today.

There are concerns within the citrus industry with regard to the changes in the sales tax regulations that this bill will impose. Senator Sherry made some points about that. Senator Short also made some very good points about that. Hopefully, people will understand the problems that some of those industries face. The coalition believes that the citrus industry can be compensated by taking note of the Industry Commission's recommendations in its report on the horticulture industry last year, something I believe the government has not done. It has blatantly failed to make sure that that industry is looked after. This is evident from what I said about Senator Sherry's speech.

It is the government's responsibility to look into tax concessions for this industry so that new plantations receive more favourable tax treatment, as is enjoyed by investment in farm plant and equipment. I note the recommendations of the Economics Legislation Committee report, which was presented this morning by Senator Childs:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the World Trade Organisation Amendment Bills and the provisions of the Copyright (World Trade Organisation Amendments) Bill be agreed to.
The report also said:

However, the Committee notes the concerns of the Liberal Party Senators representing the Coalition who have expressed their dissatisfaction at the inadequacy of the Government's response to the recommendations of the Horticultural Task Force and the problems faced by the citrus growers.

I think it is very important that the government take those recommendations on board. In the last decade the Labor government has shown that primary producers are one of the government's favourite milking cows when it comes to raising revenue. I hope that ceases in the future so that we can all—especially the farmers in Australia—get onto an even playing field.

PARA.TAB: ABARE has suggested that the value of exports will increase as a result of GATT by about $330 million in beef, $210 million in dairy products, $320 million in wheat, $50 million in coarse grains, $30 million in rice, $10 million in sugar, $1 billion in coal and something like $3 billion in industrial manufactures. Basically, if those things come through it will be an absolute boon to Australia.

There is no doubt that this legislation is vital to the future viability of Australia's primary industries. It will be of benefit to Australia's primary industries if this Labor government does not slug all industries with increased taxes and higher interest charges and nullify any advantages which this legislation will bring to the Australian economy. I support the legislation but with the proviso that the government understands that if it is going to have a vital and viable primary industry in Australia it cannot now slug it with higher interest rates and with the extra taxes it is now contemplating, because that will nullify any advantages we get from the World Trade Organisation legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Sales Tax (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994 and related bills. These bills amend Australian legislation to make it compatible with the GATT provisions which the Australian government has agreed to—without debate in parliament—in contrast to the very detailed debate that has been and is still being carried out in the United States.

PARA.TAB: If ever a treaty needed the approval of parliament and careful examination of its implications, it is this one. The Australian Democrats are very conscious of the benefits that these bills will bring for agricultural industries in particular in Australia. It is not before time that our farmers will be able to enter world markets so far closed to them due to the subsidy arrangements and other strategies employed by other countries. However, that advantage comes at a cost.

It is the Democrats' position that these bills should be deferred until full, careful and detailed discussion of the consequences of these amendments has taken place in this parliament, and indeed in the community. It is for that reason that we will vote against the second reading of the bill. This is not to be taken as an expression that we do not support the advantages that will flow to our primary industries. What we are objecting to is the lack of debate on the consequences of the types of agreements that the Australian government has made on our behalf without careful and detailed consultation.

Concerns about these bills are raised at three different levels. First of all, there are the broad implications of the WTO agreement—for instance the impact on the Third World; the transparency, accountability and democratic processions of the new WTO, the implications for Australia's ability to promote international standards in the environmental, labour and human rights areas in the region, and the pressures which will be generated on Australia to lower its own standards in these areas under threat of greater unemployment; the direct injury to industries and groups arising from implementation of Australia's commitments under the WTO where those commitments are not embodied in the WTO legislation package which is now before the Senate; and, finally, the direct injury to industries and groups arising out of the WTO legislation package.

The World Trade Organisation will be a powerful institution. Those senators who worry about the sovereignty argument because an Australian citizen has gone before the United Nations Human Rights Committee to lay a complaint should look at this organisation. Australia will be unable to pass laws which discriminate between imported products on the basis of the production process used. It may well be `illegal' under the WTO agreement for Australia to place restrictions on imports produced using exploited child labour, despite Australia being a signatory to the ILO convention which calls for the elimination of such practices. It may well be illegal under the WTO agreement for Australia to give preference to imports which use environmentally clean technology, despite Australia's participation in any number of international environmental agreements.

Support for Australian ownership of important Australian assets or Australian cultural industries could also be challengeable under the WTO agreement's foreign investment rules. Rules against foreign domination of the media, support for the Australian film industry, and local content rules for Australian television may all end up being challengeable through the WTO. I see that the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), who is at the table, shakes his head. I will be very glad of a refutation of that and an undertaking that it will not be the case. I did say `challengeable'; I did not say that it will be stopped.

In addition, Australian standards could come under threat. Any quarantine or food standards in excess of the minimum common standards defined under the WTO agreement would be challengeable as non-tariff barriers. Even steps taken to implement commitments under other international agreements could be challenged. It is even possible that a greenhouse targeted carbon tax could be challenged by oil or car exporting countries as a non-tariff barrier.

Given these sovereignty issues, it is of concern that the Senate is being asked to pass this legislation enabling the government to sign on to the WTO agreement when no framework for ensuring transparency, accountability and democratic processes within the WTO—and in Australia's relations with the WTO—have been specified to the Senate.

International social justice aspects of the WTO agreement were also raised as a matter of concern before the Senate Economics Committee. By far the greatest share of the estimated benefits from the agreement accrue to richer countries. The elimination of agricultural subsidies, much as that will benefit us, is likely to push up food prices, hurting food-importing African countries. The TRIPS agreement restricts Third World access to technology transfer, while the WTO agreement guarantees easy access by the developed world to Third World resources and—through TRIMs and its relaxed foreign investment regime—to cheap Third World labour. We all know how many of our companies are transferring their operations offshore, depriving Australians of jobs and exploiting cheap labour in countries such as the Philippines, Indonesia, southern China and so on.

Within Australia, we have free trade between states and regions and cities without internal tariffs or barriers to that trade. In that sense, it is indeed free trade. But it is not unregulated trade. We insist that production in Australia conform to certain minimum standards. We insist that workers are paid a basic living wage. Workers' health and safety is protected by regulations. There are stringent environmental standards and practices.

Such regulation represents an imposition of values on otherwise amoral markets. The WTO agreement does not include any social clauses on labour or environmental standards. It is well documented that free trade regimes can lead to a `race to the bottom' as countries compete to become low cost producers by relaxing such standards. It can lead, and has led, to appalling worker exploitation and environmental disasters in Third World countries, and we are becoming part of that exploitation.

As a result of these trends, American Professor Paul Romer has pointed out that free trade between countries at different stages of development can lead to uneven and inequitable growth. Resources are diverted towards chasing cheap labour instead of being invested in new, sustainable, knowledge based industries, which Romer's new growth theory argues are the source of improved wellbeing. Equity and fairness demand that these issues be investigated and considered by the Senate prior to passing the WTO legislation package.

Let me turn to the specific area of losers under the WTO agreement as far as Australia is concerned. The government has claimed that the World Trade Organisation agreement will yield benefits to Australia of over $4 billion. If this claim is correct—and I trust and hope that it is—then simple fairness demands that no Australian should be allowed to be made worse off by the implementation of that agreement.

Examination of the issues by the Senate Economics Committee revealed that there are a number of groups within the community who will lose out as a result of the WTO agreement. They include, amongst others, fruit growers, in particular citrus growers, vegetable growers, egg producers, pork producers, tobacco growers, video game rental businesses and consumers, and compact disk rental businesses and consumers.

Several of the negative impacts of the WTO agreement are not embodied in the package of legislation referred to the economics committee. Among these are the likely devastation of Australia's tobacco by GATT related changes to market support arrangements. Clearly, the tobacco growers must be assisted in switching to different products. We are living in an age where we are extolling the virtues of giving up smoking and of stopping the advertising of tobacco. But the people who have derived their living from that industry must be assisted to work in other industries and to grow other products.

Increased risks are faced by the egg, poultry and pork producers due to the likely relaxation of Australia's quarantine standards, and workers and businesses in the textile, clothing and footwear industries will continue to suffer from the excessively fast reduction of tariff protection which the government has already foreshadowed. Not only will many manufacturing industries go, but small agricultural producers and producers of fruit and vegetables will be affected by the trade related investment measures which will give transnationals and other large companies increased control over diversified markets.

Only the large monoculture sectors of agriculture are likely to see any real advantage, although, if commodity prices fall, that advantage may not be great. This will also work against ecologically sustainable agriculture by making diversification less attractive. In each of these cases, we urge the government to take steps to ease adjustments, to compensate or to introduce safeguards to protect these and other industries adversely affected by Australia's implementation of GATT agreements. Senate consideration of the WTO legislative package, I repeat, should be deferred until details of the government programs to assist WTO agreement losers are available, and available at reasonable levels.

Of the WTO bills referred to the Economics Committee to investigate, we have particular concerns with four as a result of listening to the people and the industries affected by them: the sales tax bill, the copyright bill, the patents bill and, to a lesser extent, the customs legislation. Turning to the sales tax bill, it is clear that the abolition of the sales tax incentive for local content in fruit and vegetable juices and drinks will have a crippling impact on Australian citrus growers. Even from submissions and witnesses supporting the legislation, it was apparent that the effect would be to drive down prices for juicing oranges on the domestic market, hastening industry rationalisation as the government drives citrus growers off the land.

This price pressure would be likely to have flow-on effects on the domestic whole fruit and export markets. Hundreds of currently marginally viable citrus growers will face likely bankruptcy. The witness representing Women in Horticulture attested to the likely social impacts in the citrus areas of the Riverland and Sunraysia. She spoke of likely increases in family breakdown and separation, suicides, domestic violence, the risks to rural children, the lack of job opportunities, the loss within communities of the spirit of helpfulness and assistance, and the threat to the level and quality of services provided in those communities.

In the drafting of the bill, too much emphasis has been placed on GATT consistency and, clearly, not enough has been placed on these social costs. No convincing argument was put to the committee that Australia's sales tax regime should provide an exemption for milk, tea and coffee but not for fruit and vegetable juices. The Australian Democrats favour exemption for the superior, fresh style `not from concentrate' product. A tax exemption for `not from concentrate' juice is clearly justifiable in encouraging nutrition and providing better access for low income consumers to the higher quality product, both allowable under GATT. The incidental price support that it gives to Australian fruit will help to ameliorate the impacts described above and pales in comparison with support provided to similar industries in the United States, Brazil and Japan, as described to the committee.

The government's position that the Democrats' exemption would not be GATT consistent on the basis that reconstituted juice and fresh style juice are like products is a symptom of the government's overzealousness in wishing to appear lily white in international trade fora. If the position we adopt would have to be challenged by others, why do we not go in to bat for our growers?

The products are clearly different. They have a different flavour and texture, they are customarily labelled to enable consumers to distinguish between them, and the distinction between the products is a major marketing point. The higher quality product is sold at a premium, which would not be possible if the products were not significantly different. In any case, there is no reason in my view not to move towards the protection of our own industries and let others challenge it. The Democrats recommend that the Sales Tax (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill be amended to exempt 100 per cent `not from concentrate' fruit and vegetable juices from sales tax.

I turn briefly to the next most important bill: the Copyright (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994. As called for by the TRIPS agreement of the GATT, this bill provides an exclusive right to enter into commercial rental agreements to the copyright holders on sound recordings and computer programs. This is laudable in so far as it will help to ensure appropriate rewards to performers and programmers for dealings in their work.

However, there is also a drawback to such an exclusive right: it grants monopoly control to the copyright holder without any restrictions on the possible abuse of that monopoly power. It also avoids the question of whether the actual programmers and artists see any substantial benefit, and whether the monopoly prices companies can demand reflect actual costs and reasonable royalties or corporate superprofits. Evidence presented to the committee suggests there is a likelihood that, in the areas of video game cartridges and CDs, copyright holders will withdraw these products from the rental market, destroying the businesses concerned, but just as importantly will be withdrawing an avenue of cost-effective use by consumers from the market.

I believe that it is possible simultaneously to achieve the objectives of reward to copyright holders, protection of existing legitimate businesses and consumer access to a rental market. Rental operators should have a right to continue to rent out CDs and video games provided they pay a fair level of royalty. In the case of video game cartridges, legal technicalities raised in the Blockbuster Australia submission suggest that it would be possible to exclude video game cartridges from this copyright legislation by deleting certain proposed sections of the amendment.

In the case of CDs, the negligent failure by the government to set up a system of equitable remuneration to copyright holders prior to April 1994 means that it is too late to introduce such a compulsory licensing scheme. We urge that Australian law include an exemption for rental operators. If no such licensing scheme is put in place, it will then be up to negotiators to assure that there is no problem if we wish to join the WTO. There is no intrinsic problem since the United States, Canada and Japan have all had such compulsory licensing schemes. The matters I have raised are only some of those which cause concern which all add up to the main overriding argument that the government has made agreements on behalf of the Australian people without consulting parliament. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Margetts has already mentioned, this is the only opportunity for the parliament to discuss the principles underlying the organisation into which Australia is leaping. We are discussing the World Trade Organisation package of bills. The Greens (WA) want to express on the public record strong opposition to the way in which these bills are being pushed through, seemingly with bipartisan support from what is in danger of becoming a political monoculture in this country. Some members of the opposition—namely, from the National Party—are unable to express their perfectly appropriate concerns by means of voting.

PARA.TAB: Free trade substitutes one form of regulation for another. Regulated trade imposes massive costs both in terms of restricting the ability of nations and their citizens to determine their own affairs and in terms of subverting global ecosystems. The notion of free trade begs the question: free for whom and free from what? There is very little about free trade that is free. In fact, there are massive costs. Free trade is anything but free.

So-called free trade substitutes one form of regulation for another, as I have said. International regulation is replacing national regulation and regulation according to the principles of laissez faire supplants regulation according to democratically determined national interests, including, most especially, environmental and conservation interests.

Until now, the international community agreed, in a rather loose way, to conduct trade under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. No formal organisation existed to oversee these agreements. GATT operated in an entirely ad hoc way. The Uruguay Round of trade talks changed all of this. Participants—and they included most countries of the world, including all the main trading countries—agreed to formalise world trade according to strict rules. These rules derived from the ideas of laissez faire. Regulated trade, according to the principles of laissez faire, is still regulation. It is regulation in the interests of international corporations and the most powerful nations.

The new regulations permit corporations and large nations to impose their aspirations, their tastes and their way of life over the entire globe to an extent not possible when individual nations and their citizens determine their own affairs. I am really surprised and appalled that the opposition, when it continually raises concerns about international treaties, is seemingly going along with this trend so easily.

To ensure that trading countries adhere to the new regulations, the Uruguay Round established a multilateral trade organisation, the World Trade Organisation. Based in Geneva, the WTO's function is to decide what rules should govern world trade. The WTO does not exist to expand freedom; on the contrary, the new regulatory regime will fundamentally alter the relationship between citizen and state. Once in operation, WTO decisions will devastate sovereign domestic decision making. Every WTO ruling that affects Australia, for example, will be in effect a change to Australian law without reference to the people or the parliament.

The federal coalition has recently expressed concern that Australia's signature on international agreements usurps the democratic obligation of parliament to decide Australia's best interests. It has gone so far as to call on the federal government not to sign any more such agreements. We agree. We do not think we should be going ahead with these bills at this point. We do not want Australia's signature placed on these agreements.

In principle, we support some, but not all, of the opposition's arguments. But the international treaties that govern the opposition's concerns are minor and trivial in comparison with the obligation required of Australia under this Uruguay Round of agreements. The opposition and its media confederates are conspicuously silent on these very real and pressing threats to Australia's democratic institutions. In fact, they appear to favour the new international rules.

Let us ask ourselves why. Is it possible that the opposition and the media represent interests likely to benefit from the new international regime? Those benefits will be gained at the expense of the people and the land of Australia. Trade conducted under WTO guidelines will trespass on and override locally made decisions about life and our ecosystems. When far-off people and bodies make and enforce such decisions, local people and bodies can no longer affect them. Without direct participation in decision making, people's lives and the environment will suffer.

Deprived of the means to control our own trading relations, our nation and other nations are forced to compete for economic benefits by allowing themselves to be easily exploited. Under the new tailor-made arrangements, corporations will invest only in those countries that offer low wages and low tax as well as minimal labour, health and environmental regulation. Corporations will also favour those countries that subsidise power, roads and water. The net effect will be a ratcheting down of standards around the world.

Economists, businessmen and politicians all laud the virtues of reregulated trade. They believe that the application of laissez faire rules will break down trade barriers, increase global trade and benefit us all. But increased global trade can also be translated to mean increased pressure on global ecosystems. Increased global trade means higher levels of toxic pollution due to more manufacturing in areas with fewer environmental controls. Increased global trade means the production of cash crops for export instead of domestic consumption. Increased global trade means growing unemployment in countries that companies leave for cheaper havens. Reregulated trade allows transnational companies to operate wherever they can gain a greater profit. Profits depend on costs, and costs depend on wages, taxes, social security charges and environmental regulations. The highest absolute profit will be determined by the lowest absolute costs.

If companies can make things cheaper by, for example, employing child labour, companies will locate to where they can take advantage of child labour. If companies can make things cheaper by paying wages that allow bare subsistence in return for 12 or more hours work per day, companies will locate to where they can pay those subsistence wages. If companies can make things cheaper by leaving wastes untreated, by dumping them in a local river or outside the factory gates, and if they can get local communities to subsidise their arrangements, companies will locate to where there are minimal or no environmental standards. Their production and their waste disposal arrangements will then be effectively and exploitatively subsidised by the local community.

The new trading arrangements enable companies to site anywhere and sell anywhere, and send profits where they wish. Corporations will be able to buy labour in the low wage markets and sell their products in the remaining high wage, high income markets. The larger the market, the longer a corporation will be able to avoid the logic of Henry Ford, who realised that he had to pay his workers enough for them to be able to buy his cars.

When track shoes became a designer item, production shifted to Indonesia and the Philippines. Made for a few dollars a pair in one market, the shoes continue to be sold at over $100 a pair in another. The global economy enabled track shoe companies to separate production from consumption. Competition will not lower this price. Track shoe companies dictate prices through the control of market share. They market in supermarkets, department stores and specialty shops. They dominate advertising. If necessary, they can reduce their profit to rid themselves of competition from any but a few companies in a similar position.

Global corporations do not compete through price. They prefer to capture market share through product differential, styling and marketing campaigns. Not only do large corporations control market share; they also structure and control the market itself. Let us look at bananas and steel. Chiquita, formerly United Fruit, now controls Australian banana production. Queensland bananas used to be produced by locally based family businesses who grew a wide variety of bananas. Now, half of all growers produce one specialist variety for Chiquita. They have no choice. Chiquita is the dominant buyer and wholesaler of bananas.

The restriction and regulation of nations in their trade dealings will make them vulnerable to transnational manipulation. Corporations, not sovereign states, will decide what is best produced in any given country and at what price. For example, a few years ago steel producers told Australia that, unless it lowered iron ore prices, they would buy from Brazil. They then turned to Brazil and announced that, unless Brazil dropped its price, they would buy from Australia. The result was a ratcheting down of returns for ore producing countries.

In 1992 the price for iron ore dropped by six per cent. In 1993 it dropped by 10 per cent. Steel producers argue it should drop another 10 per cent in 1994. Brazil cannot afford another price drop. The country is burdened with a massive debt. It attempts to meet that debt through the ferocious exploitation of national resources but the strategy is not paying off. The price of commodities is low and falling. Other countries in Latin America and Africa are in the same situation, attempting to meet debt payments through the exploitation and export of national resources. The net effect is general impoverishment. Such are the consequences of re-regulated trade. Corporations benefit at the expense of nations and their citizens. This is not surprising. The new rules are designed precisely with that end in mind.

Increased corporate profit does not need to arise from investment in production. In fact, the most spectacular profit opportunities arise out of the new rules that govern the flow of capital between and within nations. As in other areas of re-regulated trade, new capital and banking rules restrict national democratic freedoms while simultaneously enlarging the possibilities for transnationals. Only a fraction, perhaps only 10 per cent, of the $1,875 billion exchanged each day on the world's currency markets is now used for facilitating trade. The rest is traded for risk management or profit. Speculative profits do, however, have real effects. Profits from speculation set the profit levels needed to ensure investment. Unless profits approach the levels generated by money market speculation, then there is no incentive to invest. Only lower standards, lower wages, taxes and environment regulation can guarantee profits from investment that will match those returned through speculation.

GATT proponents believe the new trading rules will stimulate more international trade. Yet more trade brings more of the problems the world needs less of—uneven spread of employment, widening gaps between rich and poor and degradation of global ecosystems. To deliberately increase trade is to add insult to environmental injury. Trade already degrades the planet. Regulation designed to increase trade would be an incentive to greater harm. By expanding markets, trade increases the polluting and toxic effects of extraction, production and disposal. In a country committed to competing in the international market, local and national endeavours to conserve resources and preserve ecosystems will fail. Pressures to compete will nullify and overwhelm efforts to conserve.

The world needs less, not more, international trade. There must be less physical transfer of goods around the world. Much trade is ecological madness. Ships traverse the globe passing others carrying similar goods or goods that could be produced locally going the other way. In 1992 the GATT secretariat argued that re-regulating trade according to the precepts of laissez faire would enhance environment protection. The less control individual nations have over trade, the greater will be the economic activity between nations. The increased wealth could be used to clean up the environment, which was necessarily damaged by the first burst of growth.

Such assertions are now part of the common wisdom. Their logic urgently requires questioning. Actually, there is not much logic to deconstruct. The defence of re-regulated commerce is not so much reasoned argument as a revelation of self-interest and ignorance, a self-serving misunderstanding, both of history and of biology.

Nowhere in the world, the real world of limits, has growth caused a lessening of ecological degradation. Quite the reverse. Growth increases environmental costs faster than benefits from production, thereby making us all poorer, not richer. Growth in income and growth in numbers put unsustainable pressure on a finite planet. Thus the real danger to the earth's ecosystem will come from the successful working of reregulated trade. The international movement of capital will globalise environmental problems that are local at present and are, at least theoretically, locally manageable. Reregulated trade will also globalise the Western consumerist way of life. It is this way of living that is overwhelming life on the planet. Do we really want to export this?

In summary, free trade and market economics are public relations terms. They are designed to conceal what they really stand for: the forced abandonment of local controls on development, ownership, trade, wages, prices and lifestyle in favour of centrally conceived concepts and interests protected by bureaucracies in Geneva or Brussels. The social benefits that people value—health, insurance, safety standards and a reasonable minimum standard of living for all citizens—came from national policies not from global economic integration. Free trade is a recipe for national disintegration and international environmental collapse.

The Greens urge our colleagues in this chamber to think twice about proceeding along the path that they seem determined to follow. We need to revalue the things that are of importance within our community that give our global ecosystem some remnants of integrity and protection. We urge people to strongly consider, amend, change these bills or, better still, defer them completely so that we can assess the more subtle implications and unintended dramatic consequences—at least unintended by some—that may ensue to the detriment of this country if we fail to study the impact of the legislation before us in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of World Trade Organisation bills is one of the most important to come before this chamber. It will have unforeseen ramifications. The package of bills is fundamental to the importance of Australia and is of fundamental importance to the whole of Australia, yet it is being rushed through this parliament. If ever there were a need to further consider the ramifications and implications of any bill, it is now with these bills.

PARA.TAB: The Senate should at least have a look at the minority report of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee and give further consideration to the matters that have been raised in that. I am sure that honourable senators will agree that this minority report has identified very key questions which need consideration. People come to these questions from different backgrounds, but very often they still reach the same conclusions. If fair-minded senators were to look at the propositions contained in the minority report, I believe they would agree on most of them. The minority report indicated the various concerns raised at the hearings and stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Concerns raised were at three different `levels':

(i)broad implications of the WTO Agreement, eg: the impact on the Third World; the transparency, accountability and democratic processes of the new WTO; implications for Australia's ability to promote international standards (environmental, labour, human rights) in the region; and the pressures which will be generated on Australia to lower its own standards in these areas under threat of greater unemployment.

I would have thought that was an essential question for the government to examine further. No doubt the government has examined that question, but I believe that the implications have not hit the consciousness of the trade union movement in general. Certainly, some people in the ACTU have been considering the matter for some time, but I do not think the implications have yet filtered through to the rank and file. The second concern in the minority report is:

(ii) direct injury to industries and groups arising from implementation of Australia's commitments under the WTO where those commitments are not embodied in the WTO legislation package before the Senate.
The third concern is:
(iii)direct injury to industries and groups arising out of the WTO legislation package.

We have had discussions about this matter in the chamber. Unfortunately, I have not been here for the whole of this debate because of the decision of the Senate to allow the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee, of which I am a participating member, to hold a public hearing.

PARA.TAB: Let us leave aside the trade union movement. What about the Business Council of Australia? The government appears to have made only a limited response to the calls by the Business Council of Australia for a genuine level playing field for exporters and producers. What we are allegedly talking about in this package is a world-wide level playing field. We all know that that is not the case. We are hopeful that it may ultimately be the case at some time in the future.

We know that other countries give tax relief to farmers, dairy producers, citrus growers, manufacturers and others with respect to indirect taxes on their costs of production. The Business Council has asked for similar tax relief for Australian producers with respect to indirect taxes such as sales tax and fuel excise, which is one of the problems confronting the citrus industry. I do not believe—nor does the Business Council—that the government has adequately responded.

There has been some suggestion that such tax relief for Australian exporters would be GATT inconsistent, but neither the government nor anybody else has produced any legal reason why Australia cannot give tax relief to exporters in order to achieve the level playing field enjoyed by countries with value added tax refund regimes for exports. The government has to consider that very carefully. I would like to hear the response of the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) to that question. It is of great importance to those of us, including those in the government, who are very concerned about Australia's industry.

The effect of the Sales Tax (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill on citrus growers has been canvassed, but I would like to put in my two bob's worth. As a consumer and as a person with a family, I do not believe there is any justification for increasing the sales tax on citrus products. Food is exempt from sales tax, so why is not orange juice? The justice of an 11 per cent sales tax on orange juice is dependent on whether fresh fruit juice is a food in the same grouping as tea, coffee and milk or a beverage with closer affinity to alcoholic drinks, et cetera. If it is a food and the tax is applied, it will stand alone as the only food bearing sales tax. This should be anathema to the government that denounced the opposition's proposal for a GST on all purchases including food.

There is no tax on fruit, but there is the intention in this legislation to tax fruit juice. It is illogical. A tax on fruit juice is a GST on food. That is no getting away from that. A GST, if it is applied to food, should not be selective.

The Australian citrus industry has experienced major reductions in government support since the May 1988 economic summit. The tariff on imported juice concentrate has been progressively reduced from 30 per cent ad valorem—25 per cent for developing countries, including Brazil—and will fall to five per cent by 1996 and zero for developing countries. The pace of this adjustment is not matched by other influences on profitability, for example, in transport and shipping.

Senator Sherry, the chairperson of the government's horticultural task force, recommended that juice bearing the label `not from concentrate orange juice' be exempt from sales tax to encourage the growth of the fresh fruit sector. This proposal was rejected on the ground that it would result in preferential treatment for Australian juice and was judged to be GATT inconsistent. The industry accepted that the exemption should apply to fruit from all sources.

The Australian government's fervour in interpreting the GATT is in sharp contrast to that of our major trade partners in Europe, Japan and the United States of America. Other signatories continue to defend their markets and support their industries to the maximum tolerance and employ effective non-tariff exclusion methods. I support the thrust of the efforts of the Australian Citrus Growers Federation to preclude this inequitable tax. I recognise the impact that this will have in setting a precedent and I recognise the flow-on effect it will have on Australian families.

I will now deal with patents. There are a lot of areas that I would like to deal with and there may be a brief opportunity in the committee stage for this to occur. The extension of patent protection contained in this package needs to be questioned. There is serious doubt whether patents encourage innovation or suppress innovation. Britain went through the Industrial Revolution without the need for patent laws, which were opposed by many manufacturers until their 19th century introduction.

Knowledge is not like physical goods such as clothes. Private property rights are not necessary to prevent destruction of the resource by overuse. On the contrary, knowledge grows by being shared. Isaac Newton said he could not have seen so far had he not stood on the shoulders of giants. The extension of patent protection is potentially contrary to the micro-economic reform which is directed at open access to essential infrastructure.

When we are looking at breaking down the public utility monopolies to encourage growth of industry and commerce, why are we creating stronger patent monopolies? On the one hand, we are suggesting that there should be a decrease in monopoly power and a breaking down of public utility monopolies to encourage industry and, on the other hand, we are creating stronger patent monopolies. Many of the benefits will flow into the pockets of United States companies and other multinational companies.

What rational basis is there for this? The Industry Commission has already pointed out how registered designs can be used to create a monopoly in the market for motor car spares. The field for abuse of patents is much greater. Why is it in Australia's national interest to give greater protection for foreign patent holders to levy royalties in the Australian community? Under this package that is what we are doing; we are giving foreign patent holders greater protection. What guarantees are there that technology or drugs will be made available to Australians at reasonable prices by overseas patent holders? It is a very important question.

Even worse—we will eventually be locked into recognising the growth of patents in areas touching life itself. Already patents have been granted for seeds. Patents are being litigated for diseases such as hepatitis C. It is absurd that any human being can claim right of ownership over such things. Why should the world have to pay a tax to anyone in the search for a cure for a disease? There needs to be an incentive for research in these areas, but should it have to rely so much on the patent area?

I must raise this question, too, which I ask the minister to respond to specifically. The Senate will recall that some years ago this chamber amended the patents legislation to provide that certain types of patents relating to certain human life forms would not be able to be patented under Australian laws. My question to the minister—and I hope that he responds to it—is this: what effect will this package have on the integrity of that law?

A whole range of ramifications and implications of this legislation have not been thought through. As I indicated in opening, the minority report has identified some of them. I invite honourable senators, with an open mind, to examine them and ask themselves whether or not we need a little extra time to consider this package of legislation. It is a very important package. I for one would be prepared to put aside a lot of the other matters that are causing pressure on my time to devote myself to this subject.

I acknowledge that the matter did go off to the Economics Legislation Committee, but only a very short time was devoted to it because of the pressure of business at this time of year. That is a problem—although not entirely the government's fault, I acknowledge. I ask the minister to consider whether we need to carry these measures now. I am not saying that there should not be the general thrust of a fair trading system; that is what we are all after. I do not know whether we will solve the question of whether it is a level playing field in the time for which I am suggesting that we delay this measure, but it is a question that we need to have a good look at.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I am talking now from Tasmania's point of view; I am sure you will appreciate this. Our dairy industry and other industries are substantially affected by taxes which industries in a number of other countries are not affected by. Off the top of my head, I mention payroll tax. I am not sure about that one; I will leave it hanging for the time being. Certain other taxes that I can think of apply to our industries but do not apply to industries in countries with which we are competing. Industries in a number of countries with which we compete have subsidies and supports which our industries do not have. I am talking about the situation which applies in Australia, particularly to the very important dairy industry in Tasmania. I would hope the government and the opposition will see their way clear to supporting a deferral of this package until such time as its ramifications can be thoroughly investigated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all senators who contributed to this debate on the World Trade Organisation bills. It is a debate which has significant implications and it was therefore appropriate that a number of senators raised the diverse views which they did. When we look at the detail of the legislation, we find that it is actually quite a modest package. The implications are quite major. But many of the things about which people spoke relate to changes that were made long since in Australia by other legislation passed in this parliament. People's concerns about what our level of tariffs should be in protecting various industries is all water under the bridge. People in this chamber have different views about it, but it is not affected by this package. So it is a relatively modest package in its immediate effect, although its implications are significant in terms of Australia's ability to fulfil the requirements to join the World Trade Organisation.

PARA.TAB: I will not have time to deal with all the detailed issues that senators raised. I attended the chamber for almost every minute of the debate and listened to the contributions people made but, in the time available to me, I will not be able to respond to all of the issues that were raised. I want to seek to deal with the key issues that people raised about whether or not the bill should be supported. Those issues go to the questions of why we have to do this now, whether we have had sufficient time and whether, on the balance of interests, it is in Australia's interests so to do.

This is not a new issue in Australian public debate. The debate about the extension of free trade, the move towards global trade liberalisation, has been an issue in Australian public debate at least since the inauguration of the Uruguay Round of 1986. Australia has been taking unilateral trade liberalisation initiatives for domestic reasons. This has not been driven by external imperatives, because there was no certainty that these matters would ever come to fruition in terms of the satisfactory conclusion of the Uruguay Round. Once again, not everybody in this chamber supports all those measures, but they were taken as matters of domestic policy by the Australian government; they were not matters driven by this initiative. So this has been going on for a long time. This legislation, in its detail, has been available for six weeks. It has been debated extensively in the House. It has been to a Senate committee and has been given extensive consideration. I do not think anybody can claim that they have been taken by surprise. It is quite clear from this debate that the overwhelming majority of senators—not all—have formed a view, on balance, about the merits of proceeding with this legislation, and they have decided that we should so proceed. Of course, I concur with that view. That is why the government has introduced the legislation. So it is clear that that is the prevailing view.

When we look at why we are doing this, I do not want to get into an esoteric debate about whether we should be exporting Western consumerism or whether trade degrades the planet. Those sorts of issues that were raised in a broad or philosophical attack on this proposal can be debated at some other time. It might be interesting, but it does not advance our debate about this legislation very far. I think what we need to do in thoughtful analysis of this—and people have raised thoughtful issues—is look at not only the consequence of taking this action but also the consequence of failing to take this action. What would happen if Australia did not pass this legislation? The benefits that could flow to Australian industry from participation in this freer global trading system would not necessarily be available to us because we would not be a contracting party to the Would Trade Organisation and there would be no obligation on people to extend to us the benefits that they do to contracting parties.

The most obvious problem then lies with our agricultural industry, which everybody acknowledges will be the big winner out of this. We should not forget that the tariffs confronting our manufactured industries will fall by 50 per cent as a result of the application of the Uruguay Round. That means substantial benefit—jobs for Australians—in many areas of this country. People would love to think that as a result of our reduction in tariffs our manufacturing production had collapsed and then all their conspiracy theories would be justified. The problem is that in the period we have been reducing our tariffs, notwithstanding a domestic and global recession, manufacturing output has gone up. I know some honourable senators wish that were not true because it does not suit their conspiracy theory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—I am not criticising Senator Watson. He knows exactly who I mean. I know that is not the opposition's view.
—Don't make general statements.
—I said some honourable senators. I do not mean those who are supporting the legislation; I mean those who are opposing the legislation.
—Name them.

—I do not want to do that. I am much too polite for that. This will have a significant impact on our coal exporters, who will be the big beneficiaries, our primary producers and our intellectual property owners. Senator Harradine raised some important issues about intellectual property. I cannot go into detail with him now about it. We have to remember that it is not only Australia doing things to protect the intellectual property and patent rights of people in other countries but also people in other countries doing things to protect the intellectual property and patent rights of Australians. There are Australians registering patents all around the world every day. It is a very good thing that they are, and they will get better protection as a consequence of this.

PARA.TAB: On balance, despite the range of issues and concerns that people have raised—some of them need to be validly considered or require further consideration—the clear majority will of the Senate, I believe, is to pass this package of legislation. It is overwhelmingly in the national interest to do so, although we will all have an obligation to continue to review the consequences and the steps we are taking. I would like to see this legislation voted on before the lunch adjournment. With that, I wish it a speedy passage.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Debate resumed from 9 November, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Pipeline Legislation Amendment Bill will make a number of technical amendments to the Moomba-Sydney Pipeline System Sale Act 1994 and the Pipeline Authority Act 1973. The Moomba-Sydney Pipeline System Sale Act 1994, which received royal assent on 10 June 1994, provided the legislative framework for the sale of the pipeline.

PARA.TAB: I wish to briefly revisit that debate. The sale of the $550 million Moomba-Sydney pipeline has been a long, drawn out and complicated process. Five years have elapsed since the government announced its intention to sell the Pipeline Authority, and it is now 10 years since the coalition first called on the government to take this course of action. The 1,300-kilometre Moomba-Sydney pipeline transports natural gas from the Cooper Basin in South Australia for the Australian Gas Light Co.—known as AGL—for distribution in Sydney, Canberra and regional centres in New South Wales.

After several years of discussion, conditional sale of 51 per cent of the pipeline to AGL was negotiated by the government in December 1993. The remaining 49 per cent interest was eventually sold to a consortium headed by Canada's Novacorp International and Malaysia's state owned Petronas. As stated in the bill's explanatory memorandum, at the time of the pipeline sale a number of ambiguities in the Moomba-Sydney Pipeline System Sale Bill were revealed. However, time constraints precluded these amendments from being made prior to the passage of the sale legislation through the Senate.

Concerns were then raised by both the New South Wales and the Queensland governments about the operation of state pipeline licensing laws. The New South Wales Solicitor-General held the view that the Commonwealth sale legislation, as it stood, could have acted to prevent state licensing laws from applying to private sector pipelines running in easements in which the Commonwealth had an ownership interest. In order to allay those fears and concerns raised by the states, the federal government agreed to introduce the necessary amendments, those contained in part 2 of this bill, to ensure that the Moomba-Sydney pipeline can be licensed under state law.

The second group of amendments contained in this bill relate to a pipeline project that will bring ethane for use as a feedstock to a plastics manufacturing plant owned by ICI. The Pipeline Authority is currently obtaining easements for ICI to support the construction and operation by ICI of a new pipeline to transport ethane from Moomba in South Australia, through Queensland, to Botany in New South Wales. The amendments will facilitate the transfer of certain easements from the Pipeline Authority to ICI.

The Pipeline Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 has no financial impact. The cost of obtaining the easements for the ethane pipelines are being met by ICI. All the interested parties—including AGL, ICI and the Australian Gas Association—are supportive of a quick passage of this bill. The coalition supports the Pipeline Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 and its swift passage through the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the support of Senator Boswell and, obviously, the support of all parties in the Senate. I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
