DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (1994 BUDGET AND WHITE PAPER) AMENDMENT BILL 1994SOCIAL SECURITY (NEW ZEALAND AGREEMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 18 October, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill will amend the Social Security Act 1991 by including in it the agreement signed by Australia and New Zealand in July of this year. Australia has had a social security agreement with New Zealand since 1943 and has similar agreements with no fewer than 10 other countries. New Zealanders enjoy a unique immigration status in Australia and are eligible to be paid full pensions by the Australian government. Australians travelling to New Zealand are, of course, entitled to reciprocal benefits in that country. However, there is a $500 million imbalance in this relationship each year to Australia's detriment, an imbalance which has become particularly marked since the mid-1980s.

PARA.TAB: It was against this backdrop that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) travelled to New Zealand in May last year. He was a man on a mission. The Prime Minister was going to be the sharp negotiator and win back $70 million or $80 million for Australia. Not surprisingly, the reality fell far short of those great expectations and provides further evidence of this government's flair for overestimating its own capabilities. Every time we get an estimate, especially from Social Security, it is way out. Again, in this case, it was way out and the Prime Minister's estimates were way out.

Under the agreement, New Zealand will reimburse Australia the pensions Australia pays to persons formerly from New Zealand who have spent less than 10 years—after the age of 16 in the case of the age pension—of their working lives in Australia and who arrived after 1 January 1983. This agreement takes effect on 1 January 1995, but we will not see full reimbursement for some five years after that.

Pensions paid after 1 January 1995 will be reimbursed in full, provided they meet the relevant criteria; but reimbursement of pensions paid between 1983 and 1995 will be phased in over five years. We will see only 15 per cent reimbursement in the first year, 40 per cent in the second, 60 per cent in the third, 80 per cent in the fourth and, finally, 100 per cent in the fifth.

The full amount of the pension actually paid will not always be reimbursed. To determine the rate of reimbursement for a given pension, a formula is applied which is intended to reflect the relative proportions of a person's working life spent in each country. The only benefits which are reimbursable under the agreement are pensions and additional family payments when paid to recipients of pensions. Unemployment benefits and basic family payments are excluded from the ambit of the agreement. Sole parent pensions are reimbursable only when they have been paid for 12 months or more.

The explanatory memorandum to this bill puts estimated savings in the first year at $2 million; the second year, at $16.7 million; and the third year, at $34.2 million. These estimated savings add up to $52.9 million, well short of the $70 million to $80 million the Prime Minister has led us to believe would be gained. What is more, we get this figure only after three years and not immediately.

At present, New Zealand contributes around $18 million of the $500 million Australia pays each year to former New Zealand residents. It is a perversion of the facts to state, as Mrs Crosio did in her speech during the second reading debate in the other place:
Reimbursements by New Zealand to Australia are likely to triple over the next three years and then rise to around $90 million a year. . .

SPEECH.PARA: If Mrs Crosio is to be believed, we should be expecting New Zealand's contribution to increase from $18 million to $54 million yet, even on the government's figures, savings of $52 million will occur only after three years and are cumulative over that period. The mention, I would suggest, of $90 million is equally shaky.

PARA.TAB: Apart from anything else, all of this raises serious concerns about the Prime Minister's clout in international relationships and negotiations. We do not oppose this bill, because it goes some way towards redressing the imbalance which unarguably exists, and it is, apparently, the best this government can do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to be able to speak on this legislation. Today we are cognately debating two social security bills. The first is the Social Security (New Zealand Agreement) Amendment Bill 1994. This bill amends the existing agreement between Australia and New Zealand relating to the reimbursement of pensions paid in the respective countries.

PARA.TAB: During the House of Representatives debate, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio) said that taxpayers would eventually be saving $60 million a year from these new arrangements. The Democrats certainly welcome this agreement because, for the first time since I have been in this place, a measure that is going to save the government money within the social security portfolio is not going to disadvantage any of the department's clients. That is a welcome departure from the norm.

The other bill before us is the Social Security (1994 Budget and White Paper) Amendment Bill 1994. As its name suggests, it introduces reforms that were announced in either the government's white paper on employment opportunities or in the following 1994 budget. Let me say at the outset that the Democrats will be supporting this bill. I would like to restrict my comments on this bill to just a number of its measures.

Firstly, I would like to look at the amendment which allows additional family payment to be paid for 13 weeks where the child's parent or parents travel overseas. At the moment, if a parent goes overseas, additional family payments can continue to be paid only if the child and the person's partner remain in Australia. Obviously, this provision discriminates against sole parents, who currently lose their entitlement to additional family payment as soon as they leave the country.

The Democrats are pleased to see these amendments brought on, because we feel that it is essential that any provisions discriminating against sole parents, be they in social security or any other legislation, must be removed as a priority. This amendment will benefit around 500 families, including both sole parent families and couples with children, and we will be supporting this change.

We are disappointed, however, that the amendments do not go even further and allow payments to continue even when the child travels overseas. In most cases, a family would travel together and the requirement that the child stay at home to continue to get its additional family payment seems unjust. This is particularly true in this the International Year of the Family, given that we are talking here about families whose incomes are low enough for them to be eligible for the additional family payment. I indicate that I will be pursuing this in the committee stage.

The second measure in this bill that I want to discuss is the extension of activities allowable under jobsearch and newstart activity agreements. At the moment, the Department of Social Security imposes very tight restrictions on the amount and types of activities unemployed people can undertake. The government's justification for this has always been that the unemployed should be primarily involved in undertaking jobsearch activities and that anything else is merely a distraction from that task.

The Democrats have always felt that, by restricting activities such as voluntary work, the government has taken a blinkered view of the way in which people can best re-enter the work force. I might add that my wife, who works in a nursing home, has encouraged many people to volunteer for work in the nursing home, and most of those people have subsequently been employed. That illustrates what we have been trying to get adopted.

The government, however, has simply assumed that the best a person can do is to front up to two employers each and every fortnight and ask for a job. Of course, enormous resources have been allocated to policing this policy, and there are hefty penalties for those who are deemed not to have fulfilled their activity test requirements.

These tight restrictions on allowable activities have totally ignored the very valuable role that something like voluntary work—as I have just illustrated—can play in maintaining a person's self-esteem, enhancing his or her skills and maintaining his or her links with the work force.

To further complicate things, there has been considerable confusion not only amongst the unemployed but also amongst some DSS and CES staff over just how much voluntary work is currently permitted. As a result of that confusion, many unemployed people have played it safe and have actually refused offers of voluntary work for fear of losing their benefit. That seems to me to be not only to the disadvantage of their future prospects but also to the disadvantage of the country as well.

At the moment, the activity test allows up to 20 hours a week, provided the work does not interfere with the unemployed person's jobsearch activity. This proviso has been interpreted in various ways by local offices. Indeed, I have been told that one of the Brisbane offices has been advising people that they can do only five hours a week voluntary work without interfering with their jobsearch efforts. Such is the confusion not only of clients but also of staff.

The Democrats believe, and we have long argued, that unemployed people should be able to undertake up to 32 hours a week voluntary work without risk to their income support payments. We also believe that a person doing more than 10 hours a week voluntary work with a DEET approved non-profit, non-government organisation should be exempted from the activity test for that week.

Finally, we believe an allowance should be paid to people undertaking voluntary work to assist them in covering the costs associated with that work. I need to stress that this would not be some sort of incentive payment to people over and above their jobsearch or newstart payment. It would simply be to offset the transport and other costs which are inevitably incurred when someone undertakes volunteer work.

The Democrats will be supporting the extension of allowable activities proposed in this bill, but I really think the government needs to give far more thought to the whole idea of activity testing and to the activities that are allowable under that test for all unemployed people, particularly in the current climate of what is still relatively high unemployment.

The third set of measures in this bill that I want to discuss are the changes to the operation of the liquid assets test that applies to jobsearch, newstart and sickness allowances. The most important of these changes is that the current four-week liquid assets waiting period will now have to be served only once in any 12-month period. The Democrats have been calling for the reduction or abolition of many social security waiting periods, including this one, for many years now. When we look at the liquid assets test, we need to remember that the average length of time a person is unemployed is currently over 60 weeks. For more than a year, unemployed people are forced to survive on a payment which is well below the poverty line.

Given that the 60 weeks is only an average, it means that a large body of people are having to survive much longer periods on income support payments. Under these circumstances, the $5,000 that single people are allowed under the liquid assets test and the $10,000 that couples are allowed would be eaten up pretty quickly. Of course, the other factor we need to consider with these waiting periods is how they interact with each other and with the social security payment periods.

Let me give a real life example. A constituent of mine got four weeks work and those four weeks crossed over into three social security payment fortnights. Because of that, his payments were automatically cut off. On reapplying at the end of his month's work, he was required to serve the ordinary one-week waiting period plus the four-week liquid assets test waiting period. All up, for four weeks work he lost 10 weeks benefit. As senators can imagine, he will not be keen to take on short-term work next time it is offered to him.

I want to mention one final aspect of the liquid assets waiting period. A person with $4,900 worth of liquid assets has to serve just the one-week ordinary waiting period while a person with $5,100 of liquid assets has to wait five weeks before receiving any payment. So an extra $200 in liquid assets means an extra month before a person receives any income support payments. That is another anomaly which should be looked at. I acknowledge the steps the government has taken to reduce the impediments to people taking up short-term work opportunities, but I feel that these other issues also need to be addressed.

The final initiative in the bill which I want to mention is the making of advance payments of unemployment benefits. Jobsearch and newstart recipients who satisfy certain requirements will be able to receive an advance payment of up to 14 per cent of their yearly allowance. These advance payments will be repaid by fortnightly deductions of 14 per cent from their allowances. It is important to note that the payments will be available only to help a person `participate in activities related to finding paid employment' or `to comply with a jobsearch or case management activity agreement'. They will not be available to cover any sort of personal expense.

The Welfare Rights Centre in Sydney has raised concerns: firstly, that a repayment of 14 per cent is too high; secondly, that if the government were genuine these payments should be made over and above the normal allowance; and, finally, that there exists a potential for clients to be pressured to take a loan in order to satisfy the Commonwealth Employment Service that they are complying with their activity agreements, for example, to buy new clothes for interviews.

The assessment by the Democrats is that overall this is a positive scheme, but it is one that does have some potential for drawbacks. It was my original intention to move an amendment to reduce the 14 per cent repayment level to 10 per cent. As some senators will know, a limit of 10 per cent repayments was recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in 1990. The committee's report said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to withhold 14 percent of a social security client's basic entitlement is, in most cases, unjustified, given the subsistence level of pensions, benefits and allowances.

As I said, I intended to move to lower the repayment level in the bill but, while I had some initially sympathetic noises from the minister's office, I have since received clear indications from both the government and the opposition that they would not support such an amendment. So I simply put on the record the Democrats' concern over the 14 per cent repayment level.

PARA.TAB: I also put on record our support for the notion that if the government were genuine on this issue—that is, genuine in assisting the unemployed to return to work—it would provide these payments over and above the unemployment allowance. If a case manager determines that some particular activity or purchase is absolutely necessary for an unemployed person to be fully prepared for a return to work, then I believe the government should be prepared to contribute to, if not completely cover, the cost of that activity or purchase.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to speak on the Social Security (1994 Budget and White Paper) Amendment Bill. I sat down before I realised I should have also spoken on that because we were debating the bills together.
—How long will it take?
—Not very long, if we do not argue about how long it is going to take, Minister.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security (1994 Budget and White Paper) Amendment Bill will give effect to a range of measures announced in the 1994 budget and white paper on employment and growth. Calling it a white paper on employment is, of course, something of a misnomer as the measures contained in the bill will ultimately do nothing to solve the unemployment crisis, which is a disgrace to this government. We will not be opposing the various measures contained in this bill.

PARA.TAB: This bill will enable the long-term unemployed to participate in group or cooperative enterprises, CES approved courses of study and training, a wider range of voluntary work and the development of self-employment opportunities whilst continuing to receive income support. It will enable recipients of jobsearch, newstart and the sickness allowances to obtain part of their benefits in advance, by way of lump sum.

After three months of receiving jobsearch or newstart, a person can claim up to $500 of his or her benefit in advance to assist in jobsearch activities. For the long-term unemployed, as much as $1,000 can be advanced in this way for activities approved by the person's case manager as assisting that person's return to work. The advance will be recouped by way of deduction from the person's future payments of the benefit.

We do wonder about the potential for abuse of this system, the manner in which it is likely to be administered and the costs of having to recoup advances from people who find work and cease to receive benefits from which deductions could otherwise be made. In such cases, legal action will be necessary to recover the amount in the ordinary way that debts due to the Commonwealth are recovered. One may well question the cost effectiveness of this exercise. We will be interested to see how it works in reality. The coalition is sounding a note of caution about some of the problems that we perceive may well happen.

This bill will also codify elements of the activity tests and agreements to which jobsearch and newstart recipients are subject. Currently such recipients are variously required to take reasonable steps to comply with an agreement or undertake certain activity and to actively seek and be willing to undertake paid work that in the secretary's opinion is suitable for the particular person.

Under this bill there will be a presumption that any paid work is suitable unless the secretary is of the opinion that it is unsuitable, having regard to factors such the person's skills, experiences and qualifications, pre-existing illness or injury that might be aggravated by the conditions of work and whether wages are at award levels. Similarly, a client would be deemed not to have taken reasonable steps to comply with the activity test or agreement if the main reason for the failure involved a matter within the client's control or if the circumstances preventing compliance were reasonably foreseeable by the client. These changes may well prove to be a boon for administrative lawyers.

This bill also modifies the liquid assets test, which defers payment of certain benefits for a specified period if a client's liquid assets exceeds certain thresholds. The test will now be applied to both members of a partnership and only once in any 12-month period. In addition, one-off lump sum payments of non-housing related debts such as clearance of a house loan or proceeds from the sale of a home where settlement occurred in the last 12 months and the proceeds are to be used to purchase a new home will not be counted for the purposes of calculating a person's liquid assets.These changes will allow the test to operate in a more equitable manner.

Residency requirements will be relaxed to enable refugees to claim social security benefits on the strength of their refugee status. This is a sensible measure as it is wholly unreasonable in the special circumstances of refugees to predicate the payment of benefits on the meeting of a five- to 10-year residency requirement.

This bill will enable the payment of additional family payment in circumstance where both parents are temporarily absent overseas for a period of 13 weeks, provided the child in respect of whom the payment is received remains in Australia. Consequently, some recognition is given to the plight of aid workers, overseas students, people overseas on government business or in a policing/peacekeeping role, and academics on study leave. It is recognition which the coalition recently pressed for in the context of the home child-care allowance but which, hypocritically, the government rejected out of hand.

The definition of fringe benefits, as it applies to the family payment income test and the parental income test for jobsearch and sickness allowance recipients under 18, will be broadened to include payments made by an employer to an employee to assist the employee in meeting the costs associated with a housing loan or rental payments. This will merely close a loophole overlooked by the government in implementing similar legislation to other classes of fringe benefit as recently as six months ago.

This bill also features a measure designed to prevent the unintended tightening of the income test treatment of pensions and annuities taken out on or after 1 July 1994, as a result of amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 which took effect from that date. This will ensure that social security clients with superannuation investment products purchased with eligible termination payments will be treated equally regardless of the date those products were purchased.

The blinding feature common to all these measures is that, despite their inclusions in a so-called white paper on employment and growth, they provide no evidence anywhere in the bill of policies which will generate more jobs than might otherwise be available. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio) has said:

SPEECH.PARA: The income support changes made in this bill are among those that will make the unemployment system responsive to the realities of the labour market of the 1990s.

I do not know whether it was a Freudian slip when the parliamentary secretary spoke of an unemployment rather than employment system, but the only labour market reality of the 1990s that the government has been either unable or unwilling to grapple with is the reality of long-term, entrenched unemployment. Clever rhetoric about labour market realities does not mask the fact that the white paper is fundamentally misguided.

PARA.TAB: The jobs compact is an excellent example of the fact that the government does not understand how to create more jobs. By its very design, the jobs compact is aimed merely at changing the perceived labour productivity of the long-term unemployed.

Under this Labor government there have been 11 long years of fancy employment programs and schemes, each more ambitious than the last. The government has been ingenuous in its window dressing—that is all that we can say this is. That is half of the government's problem: it has never been short of inspiration in coming up with all sorts of ways to reduce unemployment figures, but it does not have a clue about how to increase employment.

In August 1985 we were to have 100,000 trainees under the priority one program. Yet, after six months, there was not a single one—not one. Ultimately 20,000 places were eked out and a lot of the money spent on not much more than a lot of advertising. Jobstart was launched at the end of 1985, and by the end of that financial year a paltry 42 places were in existence, compared with the predicted 85,000.

In 1988 the government looked to a Canadian scheme with a 60 to 90 per cent success rate and created jobsearch training for young people. The government's scheme success rate was a pathetic 18 to 29 per cent. We could go on and on with these make-work schemes. Some honourable senators here will remember the one where the money was thrown at councils before the last election. Where are those jobs? They are the sorts of things I am talking about. All these make-work schemes are not creating real lasting, enduring employment.

As I have mentioned, we will be supporting the legislation. However, I point out that what we are looking at is another attempt by the government to create jobs which will not create the real long-term jobs that we need in this country to get us back on track.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senators for their contribution and, in view of the time, I commend the bill to the Senate.
