DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (PARENTING ALLOWANCE AND OTHER MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 November, on motion by Senator Sherry
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security (Parenting Allowance and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is yet another piece of legislation implementing the major changes to Australia's income support system announced in the government's white paper on employment opportunities, Working Nation. The measures contained in the bill represent perhaps the most positive aspects of that white paper.

PARA.TAB: We have the introduction of the parenting allowance, a payment specifically designed to recognise the valuable role people who are caring for dependent children play in our society. We have a long overdue reform of the income test applying to people's jobsearch and newstart allowances, a reform which will greatly increase the rewards to unemployed people for taking on any employment opportunities available. While it does not directly emanate from the white paper, we also have the introduction of the widow allowance for older women who are widowed, separated or divorced. The Australian Democrats are very pleased to see each and every one of these measures brought on. We will certainly be supporting this bill.

Looking more specifically at the measures in this bill: as I said before, the bill will introduce the parenting allowance. The Democrats welcome the introduction of this allowance. We acknowledge that, in terms of family income, for many unemployed families it will not mean any increase in their overall payment. It will, however, significantly alter the way in which that payment is provided to the family. In particular, the parenting allowance will be paid directly to the person who is actually providing the care for the dependent child.

This represents a very positive change by making payments directly to the carer and as such provides much greater recognition of the value of the caring role. It certainly is about time that the social security system recognised the valuable contribution to our society of caring for children and ceased to view some parents as simply another person's dependent spouse.

In addition, and this point is very important, the parenting allowance will make payments available to some very low income couples. This is important both from a social justice point of view and also from the point of view of ensuring that couples always remain better off by having at least one member of the couple in some form of employment. While it is true that for some couples the parenting allowance will simply mean a change in their payments title, it cannot be denied that it does provide a substantial increase in support to a significant number of low income families.

The explanatory memorandum states that the additional cost to government of the allowance will be around $350 million a year and some 117,000 families are expected to be nearly $60 a week better off. The Democrats see the introduction of the parenting allowance as a very progressive step and one which has our full support.

Next I want to discuss the changes in the bill to the income test applying to jobsearch and newstart allowances. Clearly, the current income tests need to be reworked to remove the existing poverty traps and to provide arrangements under which there is a greater incentive for a person to take up substantial part-time work opportunities.

Under the existing test, any income above $85 a week that a single unemployed person earns reduces the level of that person's unemployment allowance dollar for dollar. In other words, that person gains nothing from increasing his or her earnings from $85 right up to about $210 a week. Given this, it is no wonder that only 10 per cent of single unemployed people and 20 per cent of married unemployed people are currently reporting any income from casual or part-time work.

In reforming the income test, we need to ensure that people will always be better off by increasing their income. To do that, we need to abolish the 100 per cent withdrawal rate. What this bill proposes is that for single unemployed people there should be a $30 a week free area, then the next $40 a week in earnings will reduce benefits by 50 cents in the dollar and then 70 cents in the dollar after that. For couples, an income test similar to that which applies to Austudy would be implemented under which individual members of the couple would be income tested separately until the spouse's income exceeded $235 a week.

I understand that the government's aim in this exercise is to smooth out the income testing in such a way that there is always an incentive to earn extra cash, while at the same time maintaining the incentive for people to take on any full-time work opportunities. In that process of smoothing out the income test and in particular making it more generous at the upper levels, it is inevitable that some people will be worse off than they were previously. What the Democrats are keen to ensure, however, is that these people are not going to be substantially worse off.

In line with this, I indicate that I will be moving an amendment in the committee stage to reduce the lower taper rate of 50 per cent to 40 per cent. I intend to incorporate a number of tables at the committee stage which will clearly show that, if my amendment is accepted, the income test reform will be much fairer than the government is proposing. The Democrats certainly welcome the reform of the income test, but we do not believe the government should be removing the poverty traps by severely disadvantaging those with the least amount of access to employment.

The final measure I want to discuss is the new widow allowance. This allowance is going to be available to women aged 50 years or more who have been widowed, separated or divorced after turning 50 and who have no recent work force experience. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio), in her second reading speech in the House of Representatives, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . many of these women grew up in an era when it was not expected they would ever work outside the home after marriage and have no recent work force experience with which to confront the harsh realities of the job market.

I strongly agree with that sentiment, and indeed the Democrats have been pursuing the plight of older widows for some time now. I have had come to see me widows who have been out of the work force for over 20 years and, realistically, stood little chance of obtaining work. I want to pay tribute to the numbers of them who have pursued this issue for themselves. They have not just bleated about it and allowed politicians to do the work for them. There are numbers of widows in Queensland and, I understand, in every other state who have taken up the cudgels on their own behalf, and they deserve credit for pursuing this matter.

PARA.TAB: Many of these women, however, have been forced onto the unemployment queues and have been required to hit the streets job hunting only a short time after the death of their long-term partners. That is a pretty awful prospect. They have had not only to cope with the enormous loss of their partners but at the same time to jump through the hoops and hurdles put in front of them by the Department of Social Security. Consequently I was very pleased to see the government step back, take another look at the position of older widows and, in recognition of their difficult circumstances, announce the introduction of the widow allowance. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), after I made a speech in the Senate giving a couple of examples, did get in touch with me and certainly offered to pursue those particular instances. No doubt this measure that he has brought in is in recognition of his looking at those particular circumstances and illustrations, which were given not only by me but by many other people.

The position of these women was made even worse by the decision of the government, supported by the coalition, to increase the pension age of women to 65. The Democrats would prefer to see this payment made at the pension level and to have the associated concessions that go with the pension. Our priority, however, was that these women not have to go through what, for many of them, was a futile and demoralising exercise in job hunting. There are a number of areas where we believe the widow allowance can be improved, and I will be pursuing those in the committee stage.

Before I conclude my contribution to this debate I want to make a few comments about the overall changes contained within this bill. Some six months ago I gave a speech to the Senate in which I highlighted the incredible complexity that exists in our social security system. At the end of that speech I asked the government to take the comments I had made, and the comments of many in the welfare sector, into account in its future approach to this portfolio.

What we see before us today is a prime example of the piecemeal approach to social security that I cautioned against in my speech. For example, we have a parenting allowance subsuming the home child-care allowance. The home child-care allowance was introduced only in September this year, just three months ago, and was itself a replacement for the dependent spouse rebate for couples with children.

To add to the confusion, many unemployed couples received a letter saying that they might be eligible for HCCA and inviting them to apply for it. So they filled out the application forms and shortly afterwards received their first payment of HCCA. Within the next fortnight, however, they received a further letter informing them that their social security payments would be split and one member of the couple would be receiving a new partner allowance. Because of this, they were told, they would no longer qualify for HCCA by virtue of the income test. The government raised these people's expectations—and let us not forget that these are people who are relying on very low social security payments—and then within a fortnight totally dashed their hopes.

I received, as I am sure many others did, numerous letters from unemployed couples who were confused and disillusioned by this treatment by the Department of Social Security. I understand that it may never have been the government's intention to extend HCCA to unemployed couples, but the way in which the department went about this was unfortunate, to say the least. This is just one example of the constant state of major changes to the structure and titles of benefits to which people are entitled.

I acknowledge that the government is undertaking a comprehensive reform of the social security system. Most of those reforms are welcomed by the Democrats. But I think the point has to be made that the way in which those reforms are being implemented seems to be disregarding the stress and confusion that those reforms might inflict on people. Surely the transition to some of these new payments could have been implemented in a much smoother fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security (Parenting Allowance and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 introduces two new social security payments—the parenting allowance and the widow allowance. The parenting allowance is an income and assets tested payment which will be available from 1 July 1995 to partnered persons with dependent children under the age of 16 years. This payment will subsume the home child-care allowance, which itself came into effect only two short months ago but is yet to be finalised in this parliament. The confusion generated by the introduction of the home child-care allowance and the intended abolition of the dependent spouse rebate pales into insignificance when compared with this bill.

PARA.TAB: The parenting allowance will be structured to include a maximum basic component rate—which is, in effect, the HCCA component of $61 per fortnight at the top end—which will be neither affected by a partner's income nor taxed. Where the partner's income exceeds $763.43 per fortnight, the parenting allowance will be limited to the HCCA component rate. That basic rate can be further reduced only by the recipient's own income.

It was the coalition that argued long and hard that the HCCA discriminated against unemployed couples whilst assisting high income couples where there is only one breadwinner. The introduction of this allowance finally vindicates that argument, but the merging of these two payments is, quite frankly, a recipe for mass confusion at every social security office. In adopting this tack-on approach to family assistance measures, how can this government realistically expect people to know where they stand?

We do not oppose the introduction of this allowance, because it patches up some of the holes that government keeps leaving in the family assistance policies. But, had the government got the HCCA right in the first place, we would not be here wasting yet more time talking about yet another new allowance. I do not always agree with the Democrats but I have to agree with Senator Woodley that it is now a total mess. How people are supposed to understand what their entitlements are is beyond by belief or understanding.

The other new payment introduced by this bill is the widow allowance. It is a decidedly poor substitute for the widow B pension, which the government is intent on abolishing. Widow allowance will be available from 1 January 1995 to women 50 or over who lost their partners after the age of 50 and lack relevant work force experience. It will be income and assets tested, and set at the same rate as jobsearch and newstart allowances, but will not be subject to any activity tests.

Senator Woodley, when he was speaking, went on as though only the Democrats had made any noises about this pension and the problems associated with it especially for women who are widowed over 50. I have to add here that the coalition has also argued strongly that it was very difficult for women who were widowed after the age of 50—many of whom had not been in the work force for a very long time, and many of whom had not worked since they got married—to be expected to undertake job activity testing and to find employment.

Women already on a pension or benefit will be able to transfer to the widow allowance without having to meet the `no recent work force experience' requirement, provided they meet all other criteria and apply to transfer before 1 January 1995. In any event, no new claims will be accepted from 1 July 2005 except for women born before 1 July 1955. Widow allowance recipients will have access to the JET program and unemployment and education entry payments, but not the job compact.

Since the government decided in 1987 to phase out the widow B pension, the coalition has been vigilant in exposing the blatant discrimination Labor's policies have perpetrated against older single women. Here we are in 1994 with the white paper perpetuating this discrimination and the government introducing a new payment that is no more than a poor imitation of the one that is being phased out. There is a stricter income test, the allowance rate is less than that for a pension, and health care cards are not quite as generous as pensioner concession cards. This so-called new payment should therefore be seen for what it is: an about-face on a policy move the coalition has condemned.

The existing widowed person allowance will simply be renamed `bereavement allowance' with no other changes. To further exacerbate the confusion this bill will generate, the government is bringing in changes to partner allowance, itself introduced only a matter of months ago. Partner allowance will be restricted to persons over 40 with little or no recent work force experience and without dependent children under 16. Those with children under 16 will have to rely on the parenting allowance, whilst those over 40 without children will have to quality for income support in their own right. Those who no longer qualify for partner allowance after these measures take effect on 1 July 1995 and are at risk of becoming long-term unemployed will have access to newstart labour market programs and the job compact. Partner allowance will also be payable to partners of those receiving age pension, disability wage supplement, disability support pension, mature age allowance and rehabilitation allowance.

The other side of the coin is that the wife pension and the mature age partner allowance, as well as the special needs wife pension, are all to be phased out. Those who qualify by 30 June 1995 will have their entitlements preserved, but after that there are to be no new grants. After 1 July 1995 persons who would otherwise have qualified for these benefits will have to apply for parenting allowance, partner allowance, disability support pension or carer pension, depending on their circumstances. The savings from this exercise arise because allowances are paid at rates below those applicable to the pensions being phased out.

The education entry payment of $200, payable once in any 12-month period, will be made available to recipients of wife pension, partner allowance, parenting allowance and widow allowance. The extension may well encourage greater participation in education programs by certain social security recipients, but $200 will obviously only go so far in covering the costs involved in a return to education. Moreover, by diverting people into study the government will at least succeed in achieving a cosmetic reduction in unemployment by reducing the number of people actively seeking work.

The income test applicable to allowees is also modified by this bill. Currently the income test is joint, in that couples are treated as a single economic unit where the rate of payments depends on the combined income of both members. This will no longer be the case. Instead, a person's income will affect his or her partner's social security entitlements only if the income is sufficient to preclude the person from entitlements altogether.

The one-to-one relationship which currently exists between income earned over the income threshold and the amount of income support lost as a result is also abolished. Quite clearly, if each dollar of income earned results in a dollar of income support being forgone, there is very little incentive to earn that income in the first place. The bill introduces a new taper system which reduces the maximum rate from 100 to 70 per cent. So after a standard $60 per fortnight free area, a 50 per cent taper applies for income up to $140 per fortnight and a 70 per cent taper thereafter. To the extent that unemployed people can find the part-time or casual work the government hopes to encourage, then to some extent this modification may assist the unemployed. It does, however, presuppose the existence of those jobs without which unemployed people will not be able to take up these benefits. There are also several groups of unemployed people, who total in number around 57,000, who not only will not benefit from these measures but will be disadvantaged by them. Quite clearly, what the government gives with one hand it takes with the other.

The other substantive amendment contained in this bill is to repeal the sunset clause which would otherwise lead to a discontinuation of the advance pharmaceutical allowance from 1 January 1995. Repealing that clause will mean the allowance will continue indefinitely. The remainder of this bill contains amendments to the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act, the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Veterans' Entitlements Act, the National Health Act and the Health Insurance Act. I believe it is fair to say that these amendments are merely consequential to the changes wrought in the social security area, and we will not be opposing them. The coalition is not opposing the various measures contained in this bill, which will cost $249.7 million in 1995-96, $263 million in 1996-97 and $282.2 million in 1997-98. There are savings in some areas and costs in others, the major cost component being the parenting allowance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the bill in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for a later hour of the day.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook, is attending a function in Sydney for the launching of a $400 million agreement with British Telecom and will be absent from question time today. This engagement was arranged at a time when question time for today was set down for 9.30 a.m. During Senator Cook's absence, Senator Schacht will take questions relating to the industry, science and technology portfolio and Senator McMullan will represent the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Following Mr Willis's statement yesterday foreshadowing tax rises, this morning the Australian Democrats, which might be described as the fourth faction of the Labor Party, gave the green light to a carbon tax, higher taxes on superannuation contributions, taxes on consumption, an increase in company tax and a tax on speculative investment, a lot of which will impact severely upon low and middle income earners. As part of a government which at the last election promised that it would not increase taxes, will the minister now unequivocally rule out any or all of these new taxes?

—It is not to be assumed that any particular revenue policy will be adopted in the next budget or at any time between now and then. The government has not ruled out any particular fiscal option at this stage because of the need to adopt a responsible approach to the economy. The economy is obviously growing faster than what we could sustain at that level, although there is absolutely no reason to believe that growth cannot be sustained at a much higher level than has been the case in the past.

PARA.TAB: As Mr Willis said yesterday, there are a number of reasons why the economy can be expected to slow in the normal course of events without specific further measures of a fiscal kind. There is the expected slowdown of private consumption growth and the expected slowdown in private dwelling investment growth, in respect of both of which there are signs already clearly evident. The tax increases which have been legislated are yet to come into effect. They include the excise on cigarettes and tobacco, and the one per cent increase in the general sales tax from 1 July, which we legislated for but which is yet to come into effect. There is also the impact of the interest rates increases that have already occurred.

Mr Willis has made clear that all of those factors will need to be taken into account when the government assesses its macro-economic policy settings as part of the deliberations that will occur in the run-up to next year's budget. That remains the case. As Mr Willis said yesterday, we do not rule out any option at this stage because we are a responsible government. But it is clear that the revenue option is one that cannot be ignored. In that context, it is not inappropriate that some suggestion should be put into the public domain by other parties that will no doubt have an interest in the outcomes in this respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Two days ago, the minister said that we had misinterpreted the statements of both Mr Willis and Mr Keating and that there was no intention to increase taxes. He is now saying that tax rises should never be ruled out. My specific question was whether the Australian people can now see, as has been suggested by the Australian Democrats, a carbon tax, which will add to the cost of production, higher taxes on superannuation contributions, taxes on consumption, an increase in company tax or a tax on speculative investment. Will he rule out all or any of these tax options?

—I said only a couple of days ago that it was inappropriate and quite wrong to read into anything said by the Prime Minister, Mr Willis or anyone else that any decision and commitment had been made and that any acceptance of tax increases was evident. We have not made any such decision. It may well be the case that no decision of that kind will need to be made. We are already facing a situation where the deficit, as a proportion of GDP, can be expected to decline much faster than most comparable industrialised economies as a result of the fiscal strategy that we have already set in train.

PARA.TAB: The growth figures are high at the moment, which is excellent news from the point of view of those Australians who are still unemployed and from many other dimensions of the economy. As we said yesterday, the inflation rate is still at a very low level and has shown no sign of blowing out. So the basic fundamentals of the Australian economy are in good shape. Under those circumstances, it is appropriate to keep open options and not to foreclose them or make any of these assumptions at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. Is the minister aware of reports claiming that Australia has the highest rate of reported AIDS cases in the western Pacific? Is there any basis for this claim? As today is World AIDS Day, can she tell the Senate what the federal government is doing to reduce the level of HIV/AIDS in Australia?

—I thank Senator Zakharov for this question because it is important to acknowledge the excellent record Australia has in the management of AIDS. One of the consequences of that is the way the high reporting rate can be distorted or seen as a negative. There are a number of things to say about that rate.

PARA.TAB: First of all, it is important to recognise that the number of AIDS cases per 100,000 population in Australia reflects the age of the epidemic in Australia. The AIDS epidemic began in Australia earlier than in many other western Pacific countries, so more HIV positive people have progressed to AIDS here than in other countries. The other important element is that AIDS is legally notifiable in all states and territories in this country, and all notifications are reported to the National Centre for HIV Epidemiology and Clinical Research in Sydney.

The number of cases in each state also determines the Commonwealth AIDS funding to the states, which is acting as an incentive for full reporting and is clearly contributing to our very significant number. In fact, the rate of ascertainment, or the high rate of reporting, is testimony to our comprehensive surveillance system, particularly compared with many other countries where notification of AIDS has been low.

Indeed, in Australia we can take some pride in the success we have achieved in containing the epidemic. We have moved from a peak infection rate of approximately 3,000 in 1983 to about 600 new infections annually now. This is a good result but it is still 600 new infections too many. We aim to reduce that figure to 300 new cases per year by the year 2000.

I believe we also have some success that we can directly sheet home to the national strategy, which has been in existence since 1989, and that is where the Commonwealth government is working with the state governments and very significant non-government organisations—including gay organisations, drug workers, sex workers and so on—to make sure that all those people involved in the area are actually fully informed of, contributing to and participating in that strategy.

The Commonwealth's contribution has been over $30 million to the states and territories on a cost share basis and another $20 million for national education programs and priorities, particularly research and evaluation. A further $51 million has been allocated to states and territories for hospital based treatment and care of people with HIV/AIDS under the Medicare agreements.

This government has recognised all along that good government deals with problems by recognising reality, not by denying it. I believe that our education and prevention strategies, focusing on providing clear, factual information to individuals about risky behaviour, and encouraging people to take personal responsibility for sexual and drug use behaviour, has contributed very much to seeing that reduced figure.

Community education has been very important but we also cannot disregard the vital importance of anti-discrimination measures, and privacy and social justice safeguards, to the success of this strategy. Australia has embarked on a comprehensive program of legislative review, including specific legislation to make it unlawful to discriminate against people with HIV/AIDS, or people believed to have HIV/AIDS, in the provision of services, accommodation, sport and access to premises.

The government is also very committed to international efforts to fight the AIDS epidemic. This is clear from our increasing development assistance for HIV/AIDS to countries within our region and from our continuing involvement in an effective global response to the pandemic. It is very important to recognise that Australia is regarded by many people as a real leader in the management of AIDS. Indeed, other countries often seek support, information and advice from Australia to see if they cannot have the same kind of effect. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The minister did not answer the question. The question was: have we got the highest incidence in the world?
—The minister's time has expired. There is no point of order.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Now that the Treasurer has finally let the cat out of the bag by refusing to rule out tax cuts and a mini-budget, will he come clean once and for all and admit that the infamous l-a-w tax cuts are d-e-a-d—dead in the water?

—It would be quite inappropriate to make any such assumption. We have legislated for one significant round of tax cuts. We have brought them forward. The benefits have flowed through to and been enjoyed by the Australian community. There is another round still to come, as we all know.

PARA.TAB: On the subject of coming clean, I think the real question to be asked is: when is the opposition going to come clean on its extraordinary position that it has adopted so far as fiscal responsibility is concerned? The various tax and outlay suggestions that have been made by the opposition were costed recently by the Financial Review as amounting to somewhere between $10.5 billion and $12.5 billion. In addition, we had the absolutely extraordinary statement from Mr Costello yesterday that the opposition, if it had the chance, would in one year remove the entire anticipated budget deficit for next year of $11.7 billion. He was asked yesterday morning what the opposition thought should be the cut in the budget deficit. His answer was, `Well, it's got to be greater than the $11.7 billion this year and it's got to be greater than the deficit next year.' So the opposition, whichever way one looks at it, has to find a $20 billion—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—You have got a glass jaw.

—No, you can have your debate after question time. The question that was asked was: where do the l-a-w tax cuts stand in the light of Mr Willis's foreshadowing of new tax increases; how can the two be compatible? That is the question that was asked, that is the question that should be answered, and only that question.
—It is perfectly legitimate, it seems to me, to canvass options. But I would ask the minister to get back to the point of the question.

—Tax cuts that are not to come into effect before 1998 are not the subject matter of Mr Willis's or the government's preoccupations at the moment. Our preoccupations, our concerns, are with the management of the economy right now and with the demand that we can expect to arise and to be the situation over the next few months and over the next year or two. That is the management problem at the moment. It is a luxurious management problem because it occurs in the context of a growth rate of 6.4 per cent which has already produced over 400,000 jobs since April last year. A survey that has just been announced this morning—the Kelly national hiring intentions survey of 2,000 companies—estimates that 100,000 new jobs will be created in the March quarter 1995.
—Whose? Bill Kelty?

—It is the Kelly national hiring intentions survey of 2,000 companies—and only an ignoramus like the questioner would not be aware of the significance of that particular survey and the figures that have just emerged into the public domain. On top of the 100,000 jobs that have already been created, we are talking about, before the end of the March quarter 1995, another 100,000 jobs in the pipeline. Our expectation, of course, and our promise were that the 500,000 jobs would not be occurring until something like 1996. This is the rate at which the economy is growing. These are the benefits that have been generated by the government's policy in an effectively inflation-free environment over the last few months and which we can expect to continue in the future. Of course, we have a concern about the economy overheating. Of course, that implies responsible fiscal and monetary management. Of course, the country will get that, as it has in the past.

PARA.TAB: But at the same time, as these questions are being asked about the government, the only basis on which they can be credibly asked is if those asking them have the credibility of their own position. The truth of the matter is that the opposition has committed itself, by one statement or another in relation to tax exemptions of interest, health care rebates, tax and family payment system changes and capital gains tax changes, to somewhere between $7 billion and $9 billion worth of tax breaks—not increases in outlays, tax reductions—to the Australian community, plus God knows how many outlay increases in the area of aid and public expenditure on hospitals, infrastructure, tertiary education, Aboriginal housing and police. Those opposite just have no credibility unless they promise what their own—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Evans is now flouting your rulings once again. The question was whether the Labor party would deliver Keating's promised tax cuts or not. I ask you again to direct Senator Evans to that question.
—Order! I made the point before and I ask the Senator to keep to the point, although I did say quite clearly that canvassing options is a legitimate form of answering a question.
—I have completed my answer.

—I ask a supplementary question. Does the government have the unmitigated gall, the cheek, to say on the one hand that the economic crisis in this country is so serious that it has to contemplate both a mini-budget and tax increases—and will not even rule out Senator Kernot's amazing shopping list—and yet on the other hand that somehow it can deliver on l-a-w, law, tax cuts. Who has been running this place for the last decade?

PARA.TAB: Government senators—We have!

TALK.START.PARA: —Who has been responsible for the situation we have now got into? Whose fault is it that interest rates are rising, that the government has to contemplate tax increases, that it needs a mini-budget? Why can the government not face up to the fact that it has completely lost the plot?

—I do not think too many Australians think we have lost the plot when we have a growth rate of 6.4 per cent and an inflation rate to go with it of 1.1 per cent. The last time those opposite had their hands on the wheels of this economy, the last time there was any pretence of any growth in the Australian economy, there were inflation rates of over 10 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite showed that they were utterly incapable of producing any sustainable growth. They produced for the Australian community a depression that we inherited and a series of structural impediments and such hopelessness that we had to recreate the Australian economy.
—Order!

—Australian people know very well which side their bread is best buttered on. They have been voting accordingly for 11 or 12 years and they will continue to vote that way, so those opposite can eat their hearts out.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order—only because Senator Vanstone has raised the matter of language in this chamber so often. Mr President, I ask you to ask Senator Vanstone to withdraw her interjection. Normally I do not intervene, but Senator Vanstone is always on her feet in a pompous way talking about other people's behavioural patterns. She should apply her own standards to herself.
—I did not hear what Senator Vanstone said, but if she did say something that was out of order I would ask her to withdraw it.

—I am not of the view that I did. I am happy to come back here at a later time. If the Hansard shows that I said something that you think is inappropriate, Mr President, I will withdraw it. I think if the cap fits, he ought to damn well wear it.

—Order! I will have a look at the Hansard. I was going to intervene before calling the next question to remind people that this is the Senate chamber of the Australian parliament, not a bar room at some downtown bar.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins. The minister will be aware that the Prime Minister visited Charleville this week to officially sign the south-west Queensland strategy. He will also be aware that primary producers have hailed this agreement between the Commonwealth and Queensland governments while the opposition has described it as a stunt. Can he advise the Senate of the importance of such an agreement and whether the New South Wales government will enter into a similar agreement?

—The bush, of course, is another area of Australia where the opposition now has absolutely no credibility at all. I say that, Mr President, because, to the great aggravation of the rural community in this area, the opposition described this agreement as a stunt. I will tell those opposite what primary producers said about it. I do not think I could sum up the agreement that those opposite described as a stunt better than the President of the United Graziers Association, Larry Acton, when he said—
—I thought it was Rick Farley.

—Oh, really? The President of the United Graziers Association is also on the hit list now, is he? The President of the United Graziers Association said that the agreement was the culmination of thousands of hours of work by community, industry and government representatives. He correctly described the $15 million south-west strategy as a blueprint for a regional community approach to structural problems faced throughout Australia. The strategy targets the long-term economic environmental and social viability of the region. The Queensland government is to be congratulated for immediately accepting the Commonwealth's offer to share the funding of this strategy.

PARA.TAB: I have been polite about this publicly to this point in time, but I am not going to be from now on. Over three months ago a similar offer was made to the Fahey government of New South Wales—the government that is continually complaining about the Commonwealth's drought response. We have yet to receive a response to a similar $15 million package for the droughted farmers of the western division of New South Wales. This leaves many droughted farmers in New South Wales in a ludicrous position. Their neighbours across the Queensland border can now start rebuilding their future in a sustainable way while the New South Wales farmers, who have the same problems on the New South Wales side of the border, are waiting for the Fahey government to stop twiddling its thumbs and respond.

I have pressed the New South Wales government on a number of occasions over the last three months to give us a response. We still have not got a response, which is why I have not raised this publicly before. The Fahey government is paying a lot of pre-election lip-service to the drought, but its position is not unexpected. The actions of the Fahey government speak a lot louder than its words.

As honourable senators would be aware, the Prime Minister announced in the September drought package that interest rate subsidies under the exceptional circumstances provisions of the rural adjustment scheme would be demand driven—a major policy shift. This means that, if a farmer is eligible for a 100 per cent interest rate subsidy—and we have identified many farmers who are—then the Commonwealth will provide sufficient funding to ensure that they receive the full 100 per cent; in other words, they have got an interest-free loan. That is not, I regret to say, happening in New South Wales.

Under the scheme, state governments are required to match dollar for dollar any interest subsidy over 50 per cent. The Queensland government did match our offer and its primary producers are now reaping the full benefits. The New South Wales government, however, only chose to match the subsidy up to 80 per cent to save its own money. As a result, the Fahey government is withholding from droughted farmers in New South Wales up to $5 million that could be made available for droughts. It is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I thought he had responsibility, supposedly, for federal matters. How can that become a licence to bag a state government? We all know that there is a state election coming up, but I ask you to direct him to areas of his own responsibility.

—On the point of order: the responsibilities I have are in providing assistance to droughted farmers in New South Wales. We have provided an offer of money which the New South Wales government is refusing to match.
—There is no point of order.
—I notice today that Mr Fahey has put out a press statement attacking the Prime Minister for cancelling the COAG meeting.
—What has this got to do with it?

—It has everything to do with drought. Mr Fahey has accused the Prime Minister of adversely affecting drought affected farmers in New South Wales because Mr Fahey wants to discuss provisions in February that we are taking to cabinet—
—Sit down.
—I beg your pardon.
—The minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to yesterday's GDP growth figure of 6.4 per cent, which creates major economic management challenges for Australia. Does the government now admit that its 1992 One Nation tax cuts were unfunded, badly targeted and badly timed? Does it recognise that these cuts have worsened the budget deficit, added to surging imports and contributed to the pressure for higher interest rates? Does the government now openly acknowledge that its choices are interest rates higher than necessary or tackling the budget deficit? In tackling the deficit, does the government plan to take up the opposition's only solution of putting an axe through spending programs impacting on ordinary Australians or does it acknowledge that there are reasonable, responsible revenue options available that do not impact directly on the vast majority of honest ordinary Australians?
—There is one thing we need to say to put this question and other questions in perspective: growth in an economy of 6.4 per cent is not a bad thing; it is a very good thing.
—You have just said it is unsustainable.

—It generates jobs. It is based on investment. When we said in the budget that we thought growth might be at 4.5 per cent, these people derided us and said it would not be so. When we said private business investment would be about 15 per cent, they said it was unattainable. Now it is running at over 20 per cent and they wish it was not so. That strong growth needs to be moderated and sustained so that we have continuing growth for a very long time.

PARA.TAB: Nowhere else in the Western world would people complain that their economy was growing too quickly. It is true that a high rate of economic growth does create economic management issues, but they are much better issues to have to deal with than the issues of not enough growth. If the Australian people had to choose which they would prefer—having to manage growth that might be too high or having to manage growth that might be too low—they would always choose to have growth that was too high because that means creating jobs; it means creating wealth.

These people point out that Australia is now growing faster than any other OECD country. Let us take the budget situation into account. Fiscal tightening is already occurring. The deficit is projected to fall by over two percentage points of GDP over the three years from the 1993-94 budget.

As Senator Gareth Evans said, the tax increases announced in that budget are still coming through. Not only will they help with the budget deficit, they will also dampen consumption and help get the growth at a sustainable level. This is a significant plus. We have the growth factor bringing the deficit down more quickly. As a percentage of GDP, it will come down even more quickly because it will be part of a larger GDP. So it is a significant plus.

The Treasurer has said that, on current trends, it is possible that the 1994-95 budget deficit will be under the private sector speculation of $11.3 billion, let alone the forecast of $11.7 billion. The Treasurer has said that we will not rule out the option—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is confusing, Bob. What about the mini-budget?

—The Treasurer has said that we will not rule out any action or taking early action. If the ordinary mid-term review of the economy, which takes place at this time every year—it occurs in December this year—creates a circumstance that requires some sort of further economic action, we will take it.
—We hear this at this time every year.

—Fortunately, it has been 11 years since you found out about that so you have probably forgotten. That mid-term review which happens every year will occur again this year. If it says that in the year we need to take alternative economic measures, we will. That is all the Treasurer has said.

PARA.TAB: One thing that Senator Kernot has said that is correct—the recent University of Canberra survey made this clear—is that slashing expenditure so that tax cuts can be funded is a fundamentally regressive thing to do. The process of collecting taxes to fund expenditure is a redistributive measure, and the recent University of Canberra report made that clear. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister is talking about management and timing. In Laura Tingle's recent book, she says that the government handled this very badly last time; that it kept on saying, `This is just a little increase and this is the last one,' whereas that is not what happened. Would it not be better for the government to act decisively and as quickly as possible, possibly within the next couple of weeks, to give some sort of indications to the market?

—The government has a more orthodox approach to policy making than that. We like to get the facts in first and then judge them rather than make a policy decision and then get the facts. The facts will come in in the next few weeks. We will assess them and act accordingly. If the facts say some action is required, the government will take it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and refers to the conflict in Bosnia which is now well into its third year. In recent weeks the fighting has intensified and the Bosnian Serb army has occupied much of the UN declared safe area of Bihac. What has happened to the international, and particularly the UN, efforts to protect the civilian population and to help secure peace in Bosnia?

—As will be evident to anyone following the news, the situation in Bosnia has deteriorated very markedly in recent weeks from the situation which prevailed for most of 1994 where there had been grounds for guarded optimism. Overall the intensity of fighting had eased and the international humanitarian relief operation had been working effectively and the lull had improved prospects for a negotiated settlement, with the contact group, comprising the US, UK, France, Germany and Russia, presenting a constitutional plan for Bosnia based on a roughly equal division of territory. Regrettably, the Bosnian Serbs have repeatedly refused to accept the proposal, notwithstanding additional pressure imposed upon them including, in particular, the embargo by Serbian President Milosevic. All that is behind us and, unfortunately, things have been spinning potentially right out of control, producing disastrous consequences for the civilian population and for UNPROFOR personnel. The most recent diplomatic setback occurred yesterday in Sarajevo when Bosnian Serb leaders declined to meet UN Secretary-General, Boutros-Ghali.

PARA.TAB: The events around Bihac, including the NATO air strikes, launched in response to the missile attacks on the safe area, which did not deter Bosnian Serb military actions, have obviously placed the UN and the international community in an extremely difficult position. The problem for the UN, and indeed for NATO, is essentially twofold. On the one hand there is the need to avoid taking sides in the conflict and to adhere strictly to UN resolutions specifying the conditions under which a response to violations of a safe area may be considered. But, on the other, there is the difficulty of identifying suitable targets for air strikes in a combat situation close to civilians where UN troops are very lightly armed and where both would be at serious risk.

Even while UNPROFOR is being criticised—often, it must be emphasised, for not achieving things that it was never intended or expected to be able to achieve—all sides, particularly civilians, do benefit from UNPROFOR's presence in ameliorating the worst effects and excesses of the war and improving the climate for negotiation. We must not overlook that UNPROFOR is making possible the delivery of humanitarian relief, which has saved thousands of lives, and we should not overlook its successful and effective role in other parts of the former Yugoslavia, in Croatia and, in particular, as a preventive deployment exercise in the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

Despite these problems and the very serious setback in Bihac, I do not think it is time for the international community to despair. The issue remains one of trying to bring the war to an end. That can only be achieved sensibly by a negotiated settlement. The contact group on the UN has this week re-doubled its efforts to broker a cease-fire and contact group foreign ministers are to meet again tomorrow, 2 December.

While Australia has not played and does not seek to play a direct role in the former Yugoslavia, we do take a close interest in developments there and we do support international efforts aimed at resolving the conflict peacefully. I say on the record that I very much applaud the efforts of the contact group in what it is trying to do to produce a negotiated cease-fire and settlement. Australia urges all the parties to end the fighting and the Bosnian Serbs in particular to accept the contact group proposal for a negotiated settlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Transport. The government's policy on Sydney airport has to date resulted in the closure of the east-west runway, a reduction in the number of aircraft movements from 65 to 55 per hour, a vastly and entirely unexpected increase in the noise levels experienced by the residents of the suburbs to the north of the airport, huge demonstrations and civil unrest. As the peak travel period is now approaching, what are the government's immediate plans for resolving this policy fiasco?
—If the shadow minister for aviation had bothered to turn up at the Senate estimates committee hearing he would have had about four hours to have had a detailed—
—Where was he?

—He was rabblerousing in Sydney instead, misleading people about his views on the third runway. Had he turned up at the Senate estimates committee hearing he would have had that explained to him. A number of factors in the misinformation that has just been delivered in the question would have been revealed. For example, when a brand new runway configuration is established at any major airport a period of time is required, and would always have to be required, I am pleased to say—
—For the residents to get used to the noise.

—I would have thought that as a passenger on aircraft Senator Kemp would not have minded listening to this instead of interjecting. The passengers on aircraft in Australia would have expected that there would have been an interim period to allow the pilots, and in particular the air traffic controllers, to get used to the new traffic patterns. This is the furphy that the opposition is continuing to run on. That would have to have happened irrespective of when the third runway opened and irrespective of whether the tower was opened or not.
—Get back to the question.
—That is the question. The slowdown in traffic movements—
—You are avoiding the question.

—which was referred to in Senator Parer's question, Senator Tambling, could not have been avoided by the control tower being open because the slowdown in frequencies would have been required for an interim period—as was explained in Senate estimates at three o'clock the other morning—whatever would have happened. There has to be a period, which is being progressed through now, where frequencies have to be slowed in order to ensure safety under the new runway configuration. Those frequencies are now gradually being increased.

PARA.TAB: Advice was given to the Senate estimates committees—in the absence of the shadow minister—that these frequencies will be back up to where they were before in time for the Christmas rush that Senator Parer has referred to. So Senator Parer's question has already been answered in his absence.

What was also explained to the Senate estimates committee in respect of the noise aspect of Senator Parer's question was that the Civil Aviation Authority has introduced new arrangements for flight tracks at Sydney airport. These maps were provided to the people who attended the Senate estimates committee hearing while Senator Parer was rabblerousing in Sydney and misrepresenting the opposition's position on the third runway once again. Opposition members are just a bunch of political opportunists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Just stick to the answer.
—They are not people who are interested in reasonable policy. That is what it is all about. As the maps that were delivered at the estimates committee show, the new procedures are working.
—That is a southerly pattern. Stop telling lies.

—Can you wait, Senator Baume? The reason that yesterday there had to be a deviation from the new tracks, which are successfully avoiding the worst affected area of Kurnell, was extreme thunderstorm activity in Sydney yesterday. It was for safety reasons, and this happens at every airport. The aircraft had to take off from a different direction. But that is the pattern which is going to be used in normal weather conditions—
—Show us a northerly map.

—Wrong again, Baume. It was only because, as Senator Baume had explained to him again by me five minutes ago, of extreme thunderstorm activity. If Senator Baume wants major jet aircraft to take off in the middle of thunderstorms in order to avoid noise on the ground then he is a mug.
—I call Senator Parer.
—Show us a northerly map and come clean.
—Order! Senator Baume, you are not asking the question.
—Well, he is being disgraceful.
—Order!

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like Senator Collins to listen to this. What he referred to were noise effects at Kurnell, which are on the southern part of the runway. What I am asking him is: what are his immediate plans to resolve the policy fiasco which has resulted in the unexpected noise levels north of the airport? Is the proposal by minister Brereton and himself that they will fine planes for deviating from their course a public relations stunt? The pilots will swear on a stack of bibles that they follow the paths set by the air traffic controllers.

—The ignorance of Senator Parer, as a shadow minister, of the irrelevance of what pilots might swear on bibles is profound. He should know that aircraft at Sydney airport are tracked by radar. It will not do pilots any good swearing on anything. What a nonsensical statement!
—So what!
—What does that mean, `so what!'? Not only are they recorded on radar, but the tracks of the aircraft are recorded on radar—precisely, Senator Parer.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister advised the Senate some weeks ago of a range of estimates from ABARE on the likely economic impact of the drought on the rural sector and the economy in general. Can the minister advise the Senate whether these estimates have been revised in light of recent reports of useful rain in some drought affected areas?

—Unfortunately, there has not been any improvement in the worst affected droughted areas in Australia. Regrettably, the reverse is the case. As a consequence, ABARE has markedly downgraded its estimates since I last reported to the Senate on this matter in September. At that time, ABARE estimated that the drought would cut the total Australian winter crop production by 40 per cent to around 17 million tonnes in total. I have just been advised by ABARE that this estimate has now been revised down to an estimated reduction in total crop production of 54 per cent to 13 million tonnes. Wheat production is expected to fall by more than 50 per cent to the lowest level since 1972.

PARA.TAB: ABARE estimated in September that the drought would result in a reduction in the net value of agricultural production of around $1.3 billion in 1994-95. The net value of agricultural production is now estimated at just under $2 billion.

The reduction in Australia's national income as a result of the drought was estimated at around $2 billion in September—equivalent to a drop, as I told the Senate at the time, of about half a percentage point in economic growth this year. ABARE has now revised its estimates to a projected national income drop of $2.9 billion, equivalent to a fall of about 0.7 per cent in economic growth. I am sure that honourable senators would agree that these figures provide a stark illustration of the economic impact of this drought, which, I regret to say, shows no sign of breaking.

The Bureau of Meteorology assessment remains that drought conditions will persist in Queensland and New South Wales until the end of this year and will be followed by poor and late summer rain, consistent with the El Nino phenomenon. It is assumed by ABARE in its forecasts that the remaining states will receive below average spring rainfall. It should be noted, however, that, if these weather forecasts are incorrect and there is an immediate return of average rainfall, this would do little or nothing to improve the situation for winter crops and the financial returns of affected farmers.

As honourable senators would be aware, it is a complex exercise to determine the overall effects of the drought on the consumer price index. Drought increases some food prices, but it reduces others. Overall, the CPI is expected to increase by around 0.2 percentage points as a result of the drought.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer the minister to the Japanese space test program, ALFLEX, proposed to take place at Woomera rocket range in South Australia at the beginning in 1996. Is Evetts Field, 45 kilometres north of the Woomera township, the location where it is proposed that the Japanese Space Agency will commence its $1.6 billion HOPE space shuttle trials in 1996? Is the minister aware that the government's recent decision to store at Evetts Field 10,000 drums of radioactive waste from Lucas Heights is of serious concern to the Japanese space authorities?

—The so-called ALFLEX program proposed by the Japanese government in discussions with the Australian government, and particularly the Australian Space Office, has not been completed, so we do not yet know whether that program will take place. The Australian Space Office and the Australian government have indicated that, if the Japanese wish to conduct the ALFLEX program at Woomera, we would be very cooperative and willing to assist in the development of that program. The latest information I have received is that the Japanese government and its space agency are still negotiating with the Australian Space Office on whether that program will take place in Australia. The Japanese indicate that, until negotiations are completed, they do not want any indication given whether there will be a program or not, and we are respecting that.

PARA.TAB: Even if it did take place—and personally I hope it does—the site at Woomera, whether it is so-called Evetts Field or the Woomera main airstrip near the Woomera township or any other area at Woomera, is still yet to be determined. I am advised that, whichever area is be used, the storage of this extremely low level radioactive material would in no way affect the testing of the ALFLEX program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the minister's response and his claim that the storage of radioactive waste at Evetts Field would not affect the program, what is his explanation for the concern which has been expressed by the Japanese space authorities regarding the storage of this waste? What impact will the dumping of this radioactive waste at Evetts Field have on other potential space programs to which the minister referred in his press statement yesterday and about which he said he was about to commence discussions? Can the minister give an assurance that the radioactive waste will be removed well in advance of the proposed 1996 space trials at Woomera?

—As I tried to explain, the negotiations with the Japanese government on whether they would use Evetts Field or the main Woomera airstrip or any other area of Woomera have not been completed. That is a matter that is still being discussed. I am advised that, whichever area they use, it will in no way be affected by the storage of this extremely low level radioactive waste which is stored near Evetts Field at Woomera.

—I direct my question to two ministers: the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. I do this because I have now asked this particular question some four times, either here or in Senate estimates hearings. I have had four different answers from both departments. I ask: will the government formally permit, either through the granting of exemptions under the Health Insurance Act or by some other means, all community controlled Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health services to bulkbill as of 1 January next year? If that is possible, can we guarantee that no Aboriginal health service will have its funding reduced by state governments, or ATSIC, or ATSIC regional councils as a consequence of allowing doctors to earn their money through Medicare rather than through the grants which are the current method?
—I will refer Senator Lees's question to both ministers.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My level of frustration is now very great. I would be extremely happy to have some indication as to which minister is actually responsible for primary health service for Aboriginal Australians. In addition when the minister refers the question, could he make the particular point that the money being spent now on doctors' salaries is urgently needed to pay Aboriginal health workers and allied health professionals in Aboriginal communities. It is not an idle request; it is one that means that money can be freed up to be used by Aboriginal health services.

—The primary responsibility for health care in Australia rests with the minister for health. But, sensibly, because of the special problems that Aboriginal people have with health, the minister for Aboriginal affairs has a strong involvement and a strong role. I will do, as I always do, what I just said I would do: I will refer Senator Lees's question to both of the ministers responsible, neither of whom is in the Senate.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and relates to environmental approvals in Far North Queensland. The minister would no doubt be aware that the already approved Trinity Inlet management plan contains provision for a marina. The minister would also be aware that on 18 November 1994 the developers of the False Cape project, which includes that marina, wrote to him expressing concern at the extraordinarily and unnecessarily long time required to complete assessments of the EIS demanded by the minister in his terms of reference. These include a nine-month time frame for approval and no action by the Commonwealth until after the state government has completed its approval. The minister responded by failing to allay their concerns and refusing to meet with them. In light of the Port Hinchinbrook disaster, which was caused in large part by the minister's indecision, will the minister now give an assurance that the evaluation and approvals can be concluded in less than nine months and that no further studies will be required at the end of that period?

—There are obviously some very significant differences between the proposal that Senator O'Chee refers to and the development at Oyster Point. As he would be aware, the False Cape proposal has been referred for assessment under the administrative procedures of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. It is important that the appropriate procedures in relation to that act be followed.

PARA.TAB: As I indicated in my correspondence to lawyers representing this developer, the Queensland coordinator-general's department has required an impact assessment study, mainly of the marina element of the proposal, under Queensland procedures. I pointed out that arrangements were entered into with the coordinator-general to conduct the impact assessment study in a manner that would generally satisfy the Commonwealth's environmental impact assessment requirements.

Under these arrangements, the consideration of additional matters was required for Commonwealth purposes, although they were consistent with normal environmental impact assessment practice for a project of the scale that Senator O'Chee refers to. The terms of reference of the impact assessment study also require that world heritage values be addressed. Those cooperative arrangements are pursued so that Commonwealth and state environmental assessment processes are not duplicated.

I indicated in my correspondence to the developer that the Oyster Point proposal is irrelevant to the False Cape proposal only inasmuch as it illustrates the problems that occur in the absence of thorough environmental assessment. I suggested to them, as a result of this situation, that a meeting was not necessary but that they should maintain contact with the Environment Protection Agency, as they have been doing, to conclude the necessary arrangements.

Senator O'Chee can draw a very significant distinction between this proposal which he mentions and the one at Oyster Point. I remind Senator O'Chee and the Senate that I did indicate in my letter of 29 September to the Queensland environment minister that, in relation to Oyster Point, studies are proposed concurrently with construction activities rather than there being proper sequential processes, where the baseline studies, the setting of standards and monitoring programs precede approvals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you try answering the question.

—I am answering it. Approvals had been issued in relation to Oyster Point by a previous Queensland National Party government, as Senator O'Chee would be aware. I suspect that the previous Queensland National Party government had never heard anything about proper environmental assessments. I can assure Senator O'Chee that the processes I have outlined in my letter and to him are more than adequate. (Time expired)

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It was the Queensland National Party government that created the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Senator Faulkner is obviously not aware of that, but he might like to address himself to the question. It is very simple. There is a lot in common between Oyster Point and False Cape because it all goes back to the minister's indecision when projects come before him. Will he give a simple answer right here and now? Will he let those approvals go through or get concluded in less than nine months? It is going to cost $600,000 to put these studies together and it will take three months before they are submitted to him. If they spend $600,000 in three months, will he undertake to get the approval in less than nine months and will he undertake that they will not be asked to do another set of studies at the end of that period? That is the question. Can he give us an answer?

—I have indicated that the development Senator O'Chee refers to has been referred for assessment under the administrative procedures of the Commonwealth's Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. I have outlined the processes to the developers. I am sure they are very comfortable with the response I have given.
—They are not; that is why I am asking the question.

—Proper processes have been followed. As I have said in this place time and time again, the Oyster Point development has not been stopped but I have insisted on a situation where the development does not affect the Great Barrier Reef world heritage area. That is the responsibility I have in this regard, and obviously there is an unsatisfactory situation with—(Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I refer to a report in the publication Inside Canberra concerning the most recent Small Business Forum, and in particular the comments claimed to have been made, including by the minister, about the unconscionable conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act. Can the minister explain what happened at the Small Business Forum on this topic, and is the media report accurate?

—I thank Senator Devereux for his question. The Small Business Forum is not open to the media but, because of the very wide number of representatives there from various small business organisations—namely, over 30—it is not surprising that discussions that take place do get coverage in the wider community. Yes, there was a very vigorous discussion at the Small Business Forum when, at my invitation, a representative of the Trade Practices Commission, Mr Asher, addressed the Small Business Forum about the operation of the unconscionable conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act.

PARA.TAB: Several small business organisations have expressed disappointment in recent years since the act was amended to allow for unconscionable conduct to be taken that no case has been taken under that provision in the business community. Many small business organisations believe there have been plenty of cases available. Mr Asher, who represented the TPC at the Small Business Forum, said that, in his view, the Trade Practices Commission had not yet received enough evidence that would warrant a case being launched that, in its view, would be successful.

This was hotly disputed by some representatives of the Small Business Forum, and in particular by Mr Delaney from the Motor Traders Association of Australia. He believed that there were cases available that should be taken and that the Trade Practices Commission would, therefore, successfully establish some case law as an example of the business activity in this area.

I also pointed out that when I was a member of the Senate legal committee a few years ago, I, along with other members of the Senate committee, was lobbied by the Trade Practices Commission Chairman, Mr Fels, to actually put these provisions into the act to strengthen it. I think most members of the committee agreed with that position. It was subsequently accepted by the government and the legislation was amended.

Therefore, I do have an interest not only as the minister responsible for small business but also as a former member of that committee in seeing these provisions take effect. When these cases are successfully prosecuted—if we can get a case—it will immeasurably enhance the opportunities for small business to protect itself against the stronger economic influences of big business in commercial arrangements.

As a result of those discussions, I got agreement with Trade Practices Commissioner Asher that there would be a subcommittee of the Small Business Forum, chaired by Mr Delaney, to have ongoing consultations with the Trade Practices Commission, to see whether evidence could be collected that could lead to a successful case being launched by the Trade Practices Commission on behalf of an allegedly injured small business partner. I believe this is another example of the successful working of the Small Business Forum on behalf of the interests of the small business community in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Vanstone requested an explanation as to why she had not received an answer to question Nos 1739, 1740, 1741, 1742 and 1743 which were placed on the Notice Paper on 5 October 1994. I have sought a response from the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) to Senator Vanstone's request for an explanation.I am advised that the questions to which Senator Vanstone refers are, in the words of the Attorney-General's Department, phenomenally long, running to 6 1/2 pages of Hansard and, of course, incorporating enormous technical detail. Although there are only five questions, they contain a total of 52 component parts, many of which have several parts. It is a bit disingenuous to make out that answering such questions is an easy task. The Attorney-General's Department is working through these questions in consultation with the ASC and the Australian Stock Exchange. The Attorney-General expects to be in a position to table his response shortly.

PARA.TAB: I note Senator Vanstone's criticism of the department's consultation with the Australian Stock Exchange. However, given that a number of the questions specifically ask for information about the arrangements of the ASX, consultation is entirely appropriate and, indeed, essential. I think Senator Vanstone should recognise that. For instance, to give an example of the sort of question that the Attorney refers to, paragraph (7) of question 1740 states:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation the Australian Stock Exchange and each such self-regulatory organisation: (a) what procedures will it have in place to ensure that persons advising investors in such products have the necessary expertise to do so; (b) will such a body have in place a system for the registration and examination of persons advising or soliciting orders on behalf of licensed stockbrokers equivalent to that maintained by the Sydney Futures Exchange . . .
So it is difficult to imagine how one could answer a question such as that without the advice of the Australian Stock Exchange.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Knowles asked me to table some documents with respect to the North Perth Migrant Resource Centre. I table letters from the Maylands Action Society; the Australian Asian Association of WA; Ms Jan Widdess; the Cambodian Welfare and Cultural Centre of WA; and the City of Wanneroo. I also said yesterday that we had a phone call from someone from the Vietnamese community. In fact, there was a letter, which I now table, from Dr Nguyen van Phat JP, from the Vietnamese community in Western Australia. I am told that he is a prominent Liberal. I also table letters from the Filipino Australian Club of Perth, and from Al-Ihsan, Green Crescent, the Muslim Health and Community Care Services of WA.

PARA.TAB: In respect of that question, Senator Knowles asked me the other day a question which implied that, because Ms Romeo was alleged to have been sacked from the MRC, her contact with my wife led to the closure of the MRC. Not only did I not discuss this decision with my wife before I took it—I have got better things to do—but I did not know of Ms Romeo's resignation. In fact, we had no contact with Ms Romeo. I am also informed now that Ms Romeo left the MRC on 3 November. But the decision which I took in respect of the MRC on the papers was on 18 October, before Ms Romeo actually left the centre.
