SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) to a question without notice asked by Senator Childs this day, relating to drought.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, before I get to the matter of drought, let me just tell the Senate that the minister has told the daily double today. He has told two Richos in one day. The airport map he held up happened to be when the southerlies are blowing. The real map is when the prevailing winds are northerlies. The minister misled the Senate. That is one misleading effort.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! Don't rely on advice from Michael Baume.
—Let me hear you say `Rubbish' to this one.
—Which question are you noting?

—I am noting the minister's answer to the question on the drought. I am pointing out that the minister tells Richos. He has done it twice today. That was the first one. I am getting on to the second one on drought now. Let me forewarn the minister that, if he keeps telling lies about this matter—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—You do not have to take a point of order. Senator Tierney will withdraw that remark.

—We have rung the Premier's office about the answer that the minister gave today on the drought. We have the real answer on what is happening in New South Wales and the way in which he has misled the Senate today. His dishonest answer about New South Wales Rural Assistance Authority support for drought affected farmers does not take into account the following aspects of interest rates.

PARA.TAB: The minister was lauding the Queensland government for providing an interest subsidy package on existing debt. This does not take into account the fact that Queensland farmers that entered into new borrowings are only getting the subsidy on existing debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.

—The Premier's office has stated that, `Collins is dishonest because he's slating New South Wales by not comparing apples with apples.' In New South Wales the Fahey government has extended interest subsidies to existing debt and—and wait for it, minister—new borrowings. That is a point that the minister very conveniently omitted. This allows struggling New South Wales producers to keep their farm business units going. They can borrow for seed, fodder, fertiliser and machinery to keep the farm going. They can be well placed when the drought breaks to help return the farm to profit.

PARA.TAB: New South Wales is allowing access to credit to keep the farmers in the game through this drought. This compares with the government's exceptional circumstances package, which happens to miss most of the state. The minister should admit that his government's policies have failed. We now have 5,000 farmers relying on Farmhand because his drought assistance package misses 96 per cent of farmers in the areas affected by drought. It misses all of northern New South Wales, the Hunter Valley and many other areas that do not happen to meet his very mean minded, restrictive categories.

Let us contrast the minister's inadequate, mean minded package with what the New South Wales government has provided. It has an interest subsidy scheme for small business. Let me hear the minister interject about small business. He does nothing for small business. His hope is for some sort of trickle through effect, and it is not working. Thirty per cent of businesses in rural and regional Australia are on the verge of collapse.

Let me tell honourable senators what else the New South Wales government is doing. It does not have the minister's resources, but it has put in $22 million in August and $65 million more recently. It has appointed a drought relief coordinator. In addition, it is giving local government rate relief; matching funds on the rural adjustment scheme; assisting with electricity accounts; providing more money for stock and animal welfare; establishing cloud seeding projects; providing free fodder and water trains to all drought declared regions; free cartage of charitable goods; and increasing grazing on land.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at what we have done for them.

—I am very surprised to hear that from Senator West, who comes from a drought area that is not getting very much assistance under this scheme, like most of New South Wales. The minister's record on this is appalling. I am absolutely amazed he has attacked the Fahey government. The Fahey government has come up with a very comprehensive package that is sensitive and deals with a wide range of things that affect the farmers and also affect an area which he has totally neglected—small business.

PARA.TAB: The minister is coming out with a new package next week. Let us hope he has learnt from his mistakes. Let us hope he has listened to the farmers in Australia on how inadequate the government's package is. This time when it comes out, please help all drought affected farmers and the small business that are about to collapse under the governments policies.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to express my disappointment that Senator Collins has tried to make drought a political issue and slammed a state government. That really disappoints me because I believe that drought is well beyond politics. Drought is something that should be entered into between the state governments and the federal government in such a way that people can get through some of the problems they have. It is too much of a tragic circumstance for one person to be blaming the other, whether it be the state blaming the federal or the federal blaming the state.

PARA.TAB: I endorse all the comments that Senator Tierney has made on this. The New South Wales government has done a lot to look after its constituents. Today the minister said that the winter crop is down and wheat is going to be down by 50 per cent to its lowest level since 1972. We have a real catastrophe on our hands, not just somebody being remonstrated against.

For the record, the New South Wales government has just informed me that Minister Souris responded on 5 September on behalf of CALM and Mr Fahey and said that they would be coordinating the New South Wales approach in setting up discussions with CALM, the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and the Commonwealth to make sure the package is ready to go before the New South Wales cabinet in the immediate future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they have been saying it for three months.

—Wait a second. Don't get off your bike. Just stay on your bike for a minute. In the meantime this government—and this has nothing to do with Senator Collins; it is his government—has implemented interest rate hikes so that the $160-odd million this government has given or is going to give to drought affected farmers has been rendered completely null and void. We have a $17 billion debt from the Australian farming community, so obviously a $170-odd million debt has already been added to the debt of those farmers by way of interest increases. We are just about to have another interest rate hike. Whether it be one half of one per cent or one per cent, it will mean that $170-odd million will be foisted onto those farmers in the community.

PARA.TAB: The debt this government has put on the rural communities over the last 10 years has gone from about $5 billion 10 years ago to $17 billion now. People in glass houses should not throw stones because the glass in their own houses might break first. I make the point again that, basically, this drought should not be used as a political football. I am disappointed in the minister today for attacking the state government because there is going to be a state election. That is the only reason. He is quite erroneously attacking the state government because there is going to be a state election, and this is a great disappointment to me.

This very day I have given the minister some wool that has suffered because of the high winds that have been going through the south of New South Wales—lamb's wool that was perfectly clean is now covered in dust to the extent that it has become basically worthless. For people in this place to start throwing—I was going to say the word describing what comes out of the back of cows—dust in people's eyes in this place is abhorrent. I do not think it is good for people out there in the community; I do not think it is good for Australia; I do not think it is good for the farmers; and I do not think it is good for the credibility of this place to be throwing dust, mud or whatever you want to call it at each other across this chamber on an issue that is so vital. The farmers in Australia are desperate and deserve a lot more than what we have heard here today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked this question today of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) because I am concerned that New South Wales has taken over three months to come up with a response to our proposal of a $15 million shared package. Queensland has responded within three months. New South Wales, however, is still dithering around. It took about two months to tell the federal government what its response on this issue was going to be. That is not good enough. The comments that we have heard from those opposite about the effect of the drought on the rural communities and the farmers is absolutely correct: it is a bad and terrible thing that is happening.
—Do something about it.

—We have done something about it. We are waiting for a constructive response from New South Wales. We are waiting for it to take less than three months to work out how it can get $15 million worth of assistance out there to the farmers. It has dillydallied around and it will take a lot longer than it is taking in Queensland. Queensland has done it. It has answered the call and it has been able to rise to the occasion.

PARA.TAB: I am delighted to hear Senator Tierney talking about assistance to local government. My recollection of the response of the local government authorities to that was that it was a fraud. They are going to have to repay their loans and things like that. That will not assist them one little bit. They are not at all impressed. I have also heard from small business about the assistance being offered by the New South Wales government. The words used were that it was a con job because it was not going to help them at all. This is the feedback that I am getting from the people who are involved in the industries and who know.

Senator Tierney also mentioned that New South Wales is offering free carriage of charitable goods. How many times do I have to stand up in this parliament and say, `We do not want goods being sent to areas; we want money going out to those drought affected areas so people can then spend the money in the local community'? The New South Wales government is not helping in any way, shape or form the small business people that live and work in those communities.

These small communities usually have only one supermarket. The New South Wales government is allowing the free carriage of hampers that contain goods and materials that people would have bought from the supermarkets in their small towns. The only people that will benefit out of that are Coles, Woolworths and the large supermarkets in the large communities and the large towns. The small communities will not be helped at all. With the transportation of charitable goods—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President—
—This is not a point of order.
—Are you a mind-reader?
—Order! Senator Collins, with respect, do you mind if Senator Brownhill puts his point of order to me?
—I am not going to sit in this place and see people who are doing things to help people in country areas being slandered by people on the other side.
—Order! Senator Brownhill, I take it you were claiming a right to call a point of order. If you were, that was not a point of order; it was a debating point.

—I am not being critical of those people who are making the donations. I am being critical of the types of donations that are being made and the impact that those donations are having upon those rural communities. The New South Wales state government is aiding and abetting the downfall of these communities by taking charitable goods in.

PARA.TAB: What we have to take into those communities is money. Rather than people donating hampers, if raffles, lucky door prizes and competitions are held in the areas that have the resources and the money raised is given to areas that do not, the money can be circulated through the community. It will do more good being circulated in that way than by purchasing commodities.

I have spoken about this matter on many occasions. I have spoken to many charitable organisations in these areas and that is what they want to happen. If they have the money to give people, people will be able to purchase what they require according to their needs, not according to what I think they might want or what those opposite think they want. They are allowed to prioritise.

I come back to main issue which is that it has taken the New South Wales government over three months to actually think about addressing the problem and coming up with a program. That is three months that the New South Wales farmers, who are in great need, have not been able to access the program like the Queensland farmers have. For that the New South Wales government has to stand condemned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard some amazing pious claptrap from Senator Brownhill. I indicated my agreement with what Senator Brownhill said by saying, `Hear, hear!' I agree with Senator Brownhill absolutely that politics should be kept out of the drought debate. If Mr Fahey had not turned the issue into a political debate this morning I would have said nothing about it in question time today. I agree with Senator Brownhill and he knows I do. This should not be turned into a political football and that is why I have said nothing about this publicly for three months. I am hopeful we can resolve this matter. I was responding to a direct and full-blooded attack on the government this morning by the Premier of New South Wales.
—Quite right, too.

—I know those opposite want it both ways, but they cannot have it both ways. Had Mr Fahey not delivered this heap of rubbish this morning, I would have said nothing today in question time. I was responding to this attack. The Premier of New South Wales has accused the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of adversely affecting drought affected farmers in New South Wales by cancelling the COAG meeting in February next year. Mr Fahey said that he would have fixed up all the problems for the drought affected farmers in New South Wales if he could just have gone along to the COAG meeting in February next year and talked about it. What a piece of rot that is from a premier.

PARA.TAB: I notice that Senator Tierney was amazingly silent about the fact—Senator Brownhill covered it, but Senator Tierney did not—that farmers in the south-west districts of Queensland have actually known for three months that they are going to get this assistance. As I have said, this has been warmly welcomed—those opposite hate this—by the leaders of the peak primary industry groups that those opposite regard as their own and therefore treat with total contempt. I also add that I do not take very kindly to people accusing me of being a liar.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think the minister inferred that I treat the farming groups with contempt. That is quite incorrect.
—Order! That is a debating point. If there is a point you seek to make by way of personal explanation you can make it at the conclusion of the debate under standing order 191.

—Unfortunately, if Senator Tierney is upset about people misleading the Senate, the truth is that Senator Tierney—and I regret to inform him—was sadly misled in his quick phone call to the New South Wales Premier's office.
—Tell us about the loan money.
—I will tell Senator Tierney about that.
—Tell us about the drought money.
—Senator Tierney asserted that Queensland farmers—

PARA.TAB: Senator Tierney interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just be quiet. Senator Tierney misled the Senate. He should take it up with the premier's office.
—You should tell us the facts.
—I will tell Senator Tierney the facts.
—You should tell us about Queensland.

—If farmers in Queensland—and this has always been the case—take out more debt and they are assessed as needing 100 per cent support, they will receive a 100 per cent subsidy on all borrowings, both existing and new.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tierney interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tierney is wrong. He has misled the Senate. I will not hold my breath waiting for an apology. Perhaps he should get more considered advice before he stands up here on his hind legs in the Senate and accuses other people of lying to this chamber—which I do not do.

PARA.TAB: The very measures that Mr Fahey wants to talk about next year in February to help drought affected farmers I am taking to cabinet next week, and I intend to do a bit more than talk about them—that is a fact. I suggest, with the greatest respect—and if Senator Brownhill had not launched this subject this morning I would have said nothing today in question time—that, if the Premier of New South Wales wants to help farmers in New South Wales, instead of waiting till February 1995 to talk about it in Adelaide he could pick up the telephone in the next five minutes and direct his minister for agriculture, firstly, to extend the subsidies in New South Wales from 80 per cent to 100 per cent and, secondly, to announce that the New South Wales government will accept the Commonwealth's offer and implement a package of assistance for those in the western division of New South Wales similar to the package that the neighbours they have across the border in Queensland are already in receipt of. That is what the Premier of New South Wales could do.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) to a question without notice asked by me this day, relating to False Cape.

SPEECH.PARA: After question time Senator Faulkner indicated that he was willing to give me leave to table some documents referred to. I formally seek leave to table those documents and point out that they are: a letter to Senator Faulkner dated 18 November, his response, dated 23 November, and a timeline from the terms of reference, which does not come out too clearly on the facsimile copy but goes off the page and extends for another 22 weeks after that shown on the page, and that is the problem—the nine months delay in getting approvals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) to a question without notice asked by Senator Parer this day, relating to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Parer asked a good and sensible question and the answer was grossly misleading again. Senator Parer had made the point that the government's policy on Sydney airport to date has resulted in the closure of the east-west runway, a reduction in the number of aircraft movements from 65 to 55 an hour and a vast and entirely unexpected increase in the noise levels experienced by the residents of the suburbs north of the airport. Senator Collins said yesterday, `That is all rubbish; it was shown in the EIS.' I remind Senator Collins that it was shown in the EIS for the year 2010, 15 years away.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no. You are wrong again.

—I have had a look at it because Senator Collins misled us again about that. It was forecast for the year 2010, and the FAC pointed that out in a letter which I referred to in the Senate estimates committee hearing, and which he blissfully ignored. There have been huge demonstrations of civil unrest. Senator Parer said, `The peak travel period is approaching. What are your immediate plans for resolving this policy fiasco?' In particular, what is the minister doing about resolving the noise fiasco? That is an essential point. The response Senator Collins gave, very selectively, was `They are gradually increasing the take-off rates'—in other words, increasing the noise fiasco at the moment.

PARA.TAB: I asked the following question at Senate estimates. Maybe Senator Collins was asleep at the time; he was when I asked one question, and gave the wrong answer. This is a serious proposition. Why did the minister for airport noise, Mr Brereton, tell the Wednesday Sydney Morning Herald that one way to deal with the problem was to make sure planes took off from the furthest points on the runway and reached high altitudes as quickly as possible? At the Senate estimates committee hearing the acting chief executive officer said that this was not being done, that the normal procedure of aircraft taking off was from their nearest taxiway intersection, that that was continuing and that there was no intention to change the procedure.

That is what is being done—absolutely nothing. Why would Mr Brereton then say, `This is the way to help solve the problem,' if the CAA itself says that it has got no intention of changing it, and that is what they have been doing all the time. Are we having another of those public relations exercises, like the incredibly dishonest one about pretending that the deviations from the flight paths are all the problem of the pilots? That is a disgraceful stunt, which Senator Collins repeated today when he said that there is no point in pilots swearing on bibles. The radar tracks show what is happening. They surely do, and they do not show what Senator Collins pretended they show today when he presented a map saying, `Look how we are fixing up the problem.' That is a map showing take-offs and landings when there is a southerly wind blowing. The problems at Sydney airport relate to when there is a northerly wind, which is prevalent in these particular months of summer.

The fact is that when that kind of wind is blowing—and Senator Collins said, `But there was some storm turbulence that day'—that is the sort of map we get. The map that Senator Collins held up, and which the CAA presented to the Senate estimates committee, is grossly and disgracefully misleading. It does not show the problem of northerly take-offs, which is the problem facing the people to the north of the airport. This is an attempt to mislead the Senate.

The fact is that aircraft have been deviating within three miles of the take-off point instead of the five miles which is in the public noise statement; there was a different internal one to the external one. The people of Sydney were misled by the civil aviation department. I wonder whether the minister knew they were being misled at the time. SPEECH.PARA: What we have learned today is that this federal government has approved the dumping of 10,000 drums of radioactive waste on the very site where Japanese space authorities are looking to trial their space shuttle program in early 1996. Within the past two weeks, dozens of trucks have begun rolling up at the disused airfield's test shop at Evett's Field, 45 kilometres north of Woomera, to off-load these drums of radioactive waste material from the Lucas Heights nuclear reactor in Sydney.

PARA.TAB: Who approved this transfer? None other than the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook. Is it any wonder the Japanese are now feeling nervous and very apprehensive about their 1996 trials at Woomera? Is it any wonder that Minister Schacht's response to my question today was so restrained because he has been undermined by his senior minister, Senator Cook?

The minister's response to this question is that the site has not been finalised. But that response is misleading, because he knows full well that Evett's Field is the preferred option because of the sensitivity of the American military operations involving the Woomera township airfield. He knows full well that the Defence Department has rejected the use of the Woomera airfield for the Japanese space trial because of these concerns. Therefore, the only real choice is Evett's Field. We need to look very closely at the minister's reply. Firstly, he says that this radioactive waste is at an extremely low level and will not affect the proposed space operations. The Japanese space authorities are on the verge of finalising a $1.6 billion space program, conducting tests in Australia, and the minister responsible for the Australian Space Office cannot say how long the government will allow these 10,000 drums of radioactive waste to remain at Evett's Field. TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation report entitled Super Complaints Tribunal. I seek leave to have the response incorporated in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to that document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSE TO THE TENTH REPORT `SUPER COMPLAINTS TRIBUNAL' BY THE

SPEECH.PARA: SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON SUPERANNUATION

1.1 The Committee recommends that from its inception the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal establish procedures and structures to collect appropriate statistical data on claims submitted to it by superannuation fund members.
Agree

Detailed information, including statistical data on the working of the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993, will be collected and presented to the Parliament in the Annual Report of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. Procedures and structures will be established to collect information with the aim of monitoring the effectiveness and accountability of the Tribunal.

2.1 The Committee recommends that the Senate endorse the view that section 15(2) provides protection to trustees who have complied with the procedure set out in that section, as that which reflects the intention of the Senate in passing the legislation.
Noted

2.2 The Committee recommends that the Government consider introducing an amendment to section 15(2)(a)(i) to clarify whether or not the section 15 procedure protection applies where it has been utilised before the commencement of the Act, or that the Government make a statement to clarify its legislative intention.
Noted

The Government's intention is that, subject to s 22 of the SRC Act, the Tribunal should be able to deal with complaints relating to decisions of trustees taken before or after the commencement of the Act. However, to protect trustees against the risk of having to pay a benefit twice (that is, payment to a beneficiary and subsequent payment to another person who successfully brings an action to the Tribunal in respect of that payment), trustees can follow the procedures set out in ss 14 and 15 of the SRC Act (the `protection procedure').

In essence, the `protection procedure' provides that the trustee can notify a person in writing that it proposes to pay a benefit, at which point the person must lodge an objection with the trustee within the prescribed period (28 days): paragraph 15(2)(a) of the SRC Act. The trustee must then deal with the objection within 90 days: s 101 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993. The trustee can then notify the person of its decision in relation to the objection, including the prescribed period within which a person may complain to the Tribunal about the decision (28 days), and if the person then wants to lodge a complaint with the Tribunal, he or she must do so within that 28 day period: ss 14(3) of the SRC Act.

The above `protection procedure' has a limited application prior to commencement of the SRC Act. Specifically, as the Tribunal commenced operation on 1 July 1994, the 28 day notice period under ss 14(3) could not have commenced to run until 3 June 1994. Therefore, where the trustees have followed the `protection procedure' prior to 1 July 1994, a complaint from a person who establishes an interest under paragraph 15(2)(a) will only be subject to the 28 day notice period under ss 14(3) where such notice was issued by the trustees on or after 3 June 1994.
2.3 The Committee recommends that the prescribed period within which a potential beneficiary must lodge any objection to a proposed payment in section 15(2)(a)(ii) be 28 days.
Agree

Regulations have been made under the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act to prescribe 28 days as the period within which a person may object to a proposed payment under section 15(2)(a)(ii) by fund trustees.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTURE TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1994DEPARTURE TAX COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator Crowley
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Departure Tax Amendment Bill and the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill set out the legislative framework for the government's budget decision to replace the departure tax with a $27 charge on international passenger movement. The government also announced in the budget that the charge would be collected by the airlines and port authorities. The Departure Tax Amendment Bill proposes to rename the act the Passenger Movement Charge Act and substitutes `charge' for the word `tax' each time that it appears. Section 8 of the bill proposes to increase the impost from $25 to $27, and section 9 states that the increase applies to departures from Australia on or after 1 January 1995.

PARA.TAB: The Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill again renames its principal act and substitutes `charge' for `tax'. The bill also proposes to institute a number of transitional measures. The bill does not touch on the proposed alteration to the collection system. Section 10 of the Departure Tax Collection Act authorises the minister to make special arrangements for the collection of the tax. Section 11 authorises the government to make regulations concerning the supply of tax stamps to approved agents and the sale of stamps by those agents. Accordingly, it is not necessary to amend the Departure Tax Collection Act to enact the new system; it can be implemented by a special arrangement and by regulation.

The departure tax was introduced in the 1978-79 budget and was initially set at $10 per adult passenger. It was increased to $20 in 1981. The independent inquiry into aviation cost recovery recommended in 1984 that the tax should become part of the aviation cost recovery system. As a result, the Hawke government, in 1986, transferred responsibility for collecting the tax to the international airlines. The government withdrew the tax from the cost recovery arrangements in 1988 when it established the Civil Aviation Authority and reduced the tax to $10. The airlines were then relieved of the responsibility of collecting tax. So there has been a plethora of changes over a decade to the method and form of collecting the departure tax, or the passenger movement charge as it is now called.

The government raised the tax back to $20 in 1991 and increased it again to $25 in the 1993-94 budget. The government argued in both years that the increase in the tax was needed to fund an increase in overseas tourist promotion, but of course none of those funds were directed to overseas tourist promotion. It was sort of hypothecation without hypothecation, and we are having it again in this bill.

The coalition has long supported the introduction of a new collection system for departure tax. The Australian Federation of Travel Agents has described the departure tax as a nuisance at best and as a nightmare at worst. It is a nuisance to the foreign visitors who may be low on currency as they leave and are then forced to exchange more currency, often at an unfavourable airport exchange rate, or to cash a travellers cheque. It is often a nightmare for the increasing numbers of visitors to Australia from non-English speaking countries—their numbers have increased around 30 per cent during the last two years. The administration of the departure tax system costs about four per cent of the revenue collected, approximately $4 million to $5 million in 1993-94, a figure that is high by world standards. The cost of collecting the charge would be about two per cent of the revenue collected.

The government has argued that a third advantage of the new system is that the charge would be linked to the cost of customs, immigration, quarantine processing and issuing short-term visas. As I said before, a hypothecation without hypothecation. While it is related to those costs, it goes into consolidated revenue and is not the revenue received by those particular departments to pay for their operations. Of the $27 charge, $19 is notionally attributable to the cost of providing customs, immigration and quarantine services, and the remaining $8 is intended to cover the cost of short-term visitor visa processing.

The passenger movement charge, despite its name, is legally indistinguishable from the existing departure tax. It would not constitute a fee for service because Australian citizens departing Australia would be required to pay the full charge even though part of it is identified as being for visitor visa processing—a process they do not have to go through. The government itself has recognised that the charge would still be a tax by its having attempted to enact it through separate impost and collection bills. By doing so, it has ensured that it can avoid a High Court challenge along the lines of Air Caledonie v. the Commonwealth.

Senators will recall that the government amended the Migration Act in 1987 to impose a $5 immigration clearance fee on all passengers, including Australian citizens, entering Australia. Like the passenger movement charge, it was to be collected by the travel industry. The High Court ruled that the fee was unconstitutional; that it was a tax, not a fee for service. At least this time the government has recognised that its proposal is a tax and not a fee for service, but the same equity considerations that we raised in 1987 are still valid now. It is by no means clear why Australians travelling overseas should be singled out to pay a proportion of the cost of processing visitor visas for those coming in from overseas. Visa processing and checking benefits all Australians, not just those who travel.

The real test of the government's commitment to cost recovery will occur as the efficiency of Customs' passenger processing operations increases. The Australian Customs Service and the department of immigration are currently involved in examining a number of measures that could reduce the passenger processing time at the airport barriers from 55 seconds to 10 seconds. Passenger data would be exchanged through the electronic data interchange techniques while the passengers were still en route. This would allow Customs and Immigration to process the passenger names through their computers before flights arrived. The process could result in a reduction in the average processing times at the barriers from 55 seconds to about 10. This could result in considerable staff reductions in the Australian Customs Service. If the government is serious about using the charge as a cost recovery measure rather than as an excuse to raise taxes, the charge should come down, or at least remain constant, as these reforms start to take place. I indicate to the government that, with the passage of time, we will be watching this with interest.

Reforms of this sort are essential if our airports are to handle the forecast increase in international visitor arrivals through to the end of this decade. The continued economic growth of the Asia-Pacific region is laying the groundwork for a sustained increase in international visitors. According to the Australian Tourist Commission, visitor arrivals could double from their current level to about 6.8 million by the year 2000. I think even today those figures have been revised upwards. Arrivals from Asia and Japan could increase by over 130 per cent, which of course will be of great benefit to this country in respect of not only the current account deficit but also employment.

We believe that the tourism and aviation industries are intertwined. That is the reason we would, in government, have a portfolio based on tourism, aviation and customs with a single minister rather than leaving aviation as the overlooked responsibility of an overworked minister with two other full-time portfolios which have no relationship whatsoever to tourism.

Earlier this year, I travelled to Japan and Taiwan where I met with a number of airlines, tourism wholesalers and travel agents. I extolled the virtues of Australia as a holiday destination but was particularly interested in what they, the customers—the people who intend to come here or intend to direct people to come here—had to say. What they said to me was interesting. They said that our marketing efforts overseas seemed to concentrate on a relatively narrow market—what are termed in Japan as the young office ladies and honeymooners. They urged us to promote our country as a destination for other demographic groups, such as the early retirees—the silvers—and students.

They also mentioned to me that they were concerned about safety. They looked on Australia as being relatively safe—though not as safe as their own countries—compared with other countries. Things that turned them off were matters such as the increase of graffiti that is appearing on our buildings, both public and private, and public drunkenness. I raised these points in a speech I made to the Australian Tourist Industry Association's annual conference in Adelaide. The Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee), in a frivolous way in the other place, tended to ridicule those comments. He was obviously unaware—because he did not bother turning up at that conference—that they represented some of the real concerns of our customers. In this sort of business, which is so competitive internationally, we must take heed of what our customers say.

This fault is typical of not only the minister but the government as a whole. They are out of touch with real people. This is indicated by the fact that, with the recent fiasco we have had at Sydney airport, at the meeting on Tuesday night not one member of the federal parliament from the Labor Party, from either the House of Representatives or the Senate, was present. It is understandable from the Senate point of view, but the question was asked, `Where is the minister?'—a fair question. He should have been there listening to the concerns of people. The problem, if it is not corrected, will have an absolutely adverse effect on our potential for tourism development.

When the Minister for Tourism is invited to give a speech, his office rings up the peak body concerned and asks it what he should say. They all tell me this. That is exactly what he does. He regurgitates the words and walks away feeling warm and fuzzy while the people who were forced to listen make cynical asides. What he does not do, and what the coalition does do, is go out and talk to the hands-on operators. That is of course what we have been doing. One of the interesting features about the Minister for Tourism is that when he is needed he is silent. As I said, he turns up to annual conferences, wherever there is a crowd gathered, says warm and fuzzy things and walks off. But when he is needed he is invisible.

A classic example of this was when the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) put a stop to the Oyster Point resort at Port Hinchinbrook, when everyone knows that one of the great problems facing this country in regard to tourism is, in fact, the lack of accommodation. If we do not have accommodation and resorts, we are not going to gain the benefits that come from international tourists, and Senator Schacht will not collect the money he thinks he will collect through the airports if the potential for tourism is not realised because of a serious matter such as the lack of accommodation at areas such as Cairns, Far North Queensland, the Gold Coast and Sydney. It is clear that the government did not talk to the hands-on operators when it decided that the changeover date to the new passenger movement charge collection system should be 1 January next year—a date that was apparently dreamed up without any understanding of the realities of implementing such a system.

The Customs Service only supplied the airlines with the specifications for the new tax a short time ago. The government and the airlines are still negotiating about reimbursing the start-up and running costs of the necessary computer systems. It is unlikely that either the airlines or the operators of computerised reservation systems such as Fantasia and Galileo would be able to put the necessary changes in place before 1 January.

A related difficulty is the question of pre-sold, charge unpaid, tickets. Many international passengers buy their tickets well in advance of the date on which they travel—in the main, I suppose, to pick up discounts offered. I have been advised by Customs that as at 30 September, the airlines had sold about 500,000 tickets for travel on or after 1 January 1995.

The government, I understand, is aware of this complication and has advised me that the existing departure tax booths would be retained for a transitional period to deal with those pre-sold, charge unpaid tickets. For many months, then, some passengers departing Australia would have paid the passenger movement charge when they purchased their tickets. But many other passengers would be told at the airline departure counters that they would have to join a queue to pay the charge. Some passengers departing Australia would have pre-purchased $25 departure tax stamps. It is conceivable that they could be told at the airline departure counters that they would have to join the queue and pay an extra $2. This parallel arrangement would be both costly and a considerable nuisance to many passengers—a perverse outcome, given the government's stated intention of making it more convenient for them; an intent, as I said earlier, with which we agree.

The introduction of the system in the middle of the peak travel period would only increase the delays and inconvenience. It was argued in the House of Representatives that the best way to resolve these difficulties would be to defer the introduction of the new system until October 1995. The international airlines will be introducing their 1995 northern winter schedules on 29 October 1995 and it would be convenient to bring in the new collection system at that time. It was the sort of approach taken by the British government because of a similar situation.

The government has had discussions with the opposition on this matter to attempt to come to a negotiated agreement on the date. We have agreed that the introduction of the new system from 1 July 1995 would be an acceptable compromise. I might say there is not a lot of logic to it; it does not fit in with the October pattern of the airlines but it is a decided improvement on 1 January 1995. I will therefore be moving an amendment at the committee stage to defer the introduction of the new system until 1 July 1995. It should be stressed that the amendment would not prevent the government from increasing the charge to $27 on 1 January 1995. It would only prevent it from attempting to jump to the new collection system prematurely.

In conclusion, the coalition supports the introduction of the new collection system. It is, however, clearly necessary to defer the introduction of the system for a short time to avoid the chaos that would be caused if it were introduced on 1 January 1995.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Parer for his remarks. I also thank him for his cooperation in having discussions with officers from the Australian Customs Service, which he mentioned in his remarks. The government did have extensive discussions with the airline industry over several months. I was involved in some of those discussions. As a result of those discussions, we were able to make adjustments. The 1 July start-up date is acceptable to the government. I had already indicated to the airline industry some time ago that the new system should operate from 1 July.

PARA.TAB: I say to Senator Parer that it is not a totally arbitrary date. We have a contract with Australia Post to sell the departure tax stamps until 1 July next year. So it fits neatly as far as our contract with Australia Post is concerned, which expires on that date. But I accepted after discussion with the airline industry that the extra six months would be useful to it in preparing the new computer system, et cetera.

I am advised that a large number of countries have a similar system to the one we are introducing here—a departure charge being paid when people buy the ticket, as part of the ticket price. So we are not world leaders in this regard; we are following what others have already introduced—something which has been working quite adequately in other countries. I assure the Senate that, as a result of this legislation and the amendment that has been negotiated between the government and the opposition, the government will not require international air operators to collect the new charge before 1 July 1995.

I believe that the new charge of $27, which is an increase of $2 on the present charge, is acceptable in terms of the cost to the government of providing the range of services for people departing Australia, the tourist industry, and tourists coming to Australia. The services are provided by my department and by other departments such as the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

I accept that over the coming years the industry, particularly the airlines and the tourist industry, will look very closely at the efficiency of the system and the efficiency of the service they get from government departments. They will look at ways of ensuring that the departure charge is relevant to the service they receive. I think this is a reasonably fair assessment on their part. We will respond accordingly. If we did not, I am sure there would be some pretty vigorous debate from them if they thought the charge was getting out of hand compared with the service they were receiving. If they are able to identify efficiencies to improve the system, to reduce the cost, I am sure they will bring those forward to us and we will be happy to hear from them about that.

I will not delay the Senate any further. I appreciate the cooperation from Senator Parer and the opposition, having regard to the discussions which took place with my officers to reach agreement on the amendment which is acceptable to the government. I commend the bill, with the proposed amendment, to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
The bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister, in his response to the second reading debate, mentioned that there were discussions in regard to reimbursing the airlines. I would like him to advise me as to the status of that and whether there has been agreement reached in regard to the reimbursement of the cost of collecting the charge.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have given an indication to the airlines that there will be appropriate compensation for the introduction of a system. I have to get approval for the actual amount from my colleagues in cabinet. I believe I will do so. We accept that there is a legitimate cost and, subject to our being able to see the figures and have them carefully looked at, I am confident that the government will make an appropriate contribution to the cost of establishing the system for the airlines.
—When will it be finalised?
—I would hope before the end of this year, but that is subject to cabinet approval.
—Have you had any discussions with the operators of computerised reservation systems such as Fantasia and Galileo concerning the reimbursement of their costs in collecting the charge?
—No.
—Do you intend to have discussions?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot see any reason why we cannot have discussions. I would not automatically commit the government to reimbursing any of the costs of those operators: they are an international system and recoup their own costs by charging airlines. We are ready to discuss it with them, but I will make no commitment until I have discussions with them about their ability to recoup costs from the government.

—Has the minister had any discussions with the airlines or reached any conclusions on the timing of the remittance of the tax by the airlines? The reason I ask that question is that, as the minister may know, when tickets are purchased the money itself goes into a trust account in one of the central reservation systems and the airline itself does not get paid until the passenger actually gets on the aeroplane.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was raised in my discussions with the industry representatives. It is a matter still under discussion with them, but there are complexities on both sides of the argument. We have not completed the discussions on that point.
—I just make the observation that under the old system people do not actually pay until they go to the airport.

—I know the argument has been well put by the airlines. In any of these cases I am always constrained in making a commitment that could lead to expenditure unless I get it within the terms of the cabinet decision and the budget decision on the outlay side. We have to have further discussion with the airlines on that point. But I take your point. I do accept that people pay the money when they go to the airport and are about to depart. The money is in the trust fund and may be there for several months. Of course, the airlines were arguing that when people do not—
—Don't fly.

—Or the other way around, where there is a default in a travel agent in a faraway country and the money is not passed on. They have asked who should cover those costs. Those matters have been accepted by the airlines from other countries. We have had lengthy discussions, but they are not completed.

—I mentioned hypothecation in my speech in the second reading debate. I think in his second reading speech the minister also said that we had hypothecation without hypothecation. The $27 was to pay for the running of customs, immigration, quarantine and the issuing of short-term visitor visas. If the government expected efficiencies, particularly in customs and immigration, it would then be expected that the $27 would be reduced. Presumably if it went the other way it would be increased. I wonder what mechanisms the government intends to put in place to adjust the charge for changes in the costs of running the various facilities.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

—Well, it's a pseudo-hypothecation.

—Yes, there is a pseudo-hypothecation. But there is even an argument between government departments about that, at the bureaucratic level. That will be decided in the very near future as a result of a cabinet submission that I hope will be dealt with before the end of this year.
—In other words, you are putting a mechanism in place.

—If the government takes a decision not to have actual hypothecation—and, as I say, some departments want actual hypothecation and others do not—I certainly believe we would have to have a mechanism whereby the industry was able to have a forum to monitor the efficiencies of the service we are providing so that it can genuinely put the case where it believes it has ideas to improve efficiency. I would accept that as a minimum we would have to provide a forum to the industry to have its views heard and to get regular reports, which can be discussed, about the efficiencies and the management of all the services that go with the operation of people coming into and out of the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of the $27 charge, $19 is notionally allocated to the cost of customs, immigration and quarantine. Eight dollars is allocated to visa entries. I would be interested to know the breakdown of the $19 between the three functions.
—I don't have those with me at the moment. I will take that on notice. I do not have the figures from the Department of Finance.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS (1994-95 BUDGET MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1994VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 8 November, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, it is with pleasure that I lead the opposition contribution on the bills before us today—the Veterans' Affairs (1994-95 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 and the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994—because, as you would know, it is a role that I took on numerous occasions in the past when I held the veterans' affairs portfolio. I do not propose to say a great deal today on these bills. I recognise that the Senate is keen to get as much legislation through as possible at this time of the year. The coalition support for these bills has already been made clear by my colleague the honourable member for O'Connor, Wilson Tuckey, the shadow minister for veterans' affairs.

PARA.TAB: I deal firstly with the Veterans' Affairs (1994-95 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. Despite not having been the shadow minister for some time, I note that some things never change. The honourable member for O'Connor was given no time at all to consult with veterans' representatives on the budget measures bill before it was debated in the House. One has to ask why. It was only after the bill had been debated in one house of the parliament that the honourable member for O'Connor was able to consult with veterans. That is most unsatisfactory, and not just for the opposition. After all, we represent the concerns of the people who have fought to defend our country and our interests, and we are worried about the lack of courtesy and consideration given to those men and women.

The situation is particularly unsatisfactory when we recognise that a number of measures are not due to take effect until January next year, and yet the bill was rushed through the House of Representatives. Because of the lack of time for consultation, the honourable member for O'Connor indicated in his speech on the second reading in the Main Committee that the coalition reserved the right to make amendments to the bill at a later date in the Senate. The coalition will be exercising that right today.

The bill contains a number of initiatives which will be welcomed by veterans. For instance, it introduces automatic payment of funeral benefits to the estate of a veteran who was receiving an extreme disablement adjustment pension or who was a former prisoner of war. Proposals for an education entry payment, removing the waiting period for refugees eligible for service pension, and non-payment of pharmaceutical allowances for those who have been away from Australia for 12 months or more are measures which are not being opposed by the coalition.

The honourable member for O'Connor has indicated that the removal of the requirement for a proportion of the members of the Veterans Review Board to be registered or licensed medical practitioners is sensible. With the Repatriation Medical Authority's statement of principle now binding on the VRB, there is clearly no longer a need for a strict level of medical representation at the level of the VRB.

One important provision in the budget measures bill is to compensate applicants to the VRB for the costs of obtaining medical evidence after the primary decision. This is to be provided up to a maximum of $425. I believe such a provision is to be welcomed. It is long overdue. I remember receiving representations on this issue when I held the veterans' affairs portfolio. I know that this provision will be welcomed by the ex-service community.

However, as the honourable member for O'Connor pointed out in his speech on the second reading, the government seems to have overlooked the cost to veterans of obtaining medical evidence for the Specialist Medical Review Council. The honourable member for O'Connor has already circulated an amendment which will ensure that arrangements for the Specialist Medical Review Council regarding compensation for medical expenses are brought into line with those proposed in this bill for the VRB.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) was initially very cool on this amendment. The reasons offered were not convincing. Although appeals to the specialist review council are allowed strictly on medical grounds, it remains the case that a veteran would be required to pay for the appropriate medical advice. Given that the minister has conceded that there will be few instances in which appeals to the specialist review council will take place, the financial impact of the amendment would be negligible. It is therefore difficult to see what was standing in the way of the government supporting this amendment.

The minister indicated that he would go away and consider the amendment more thoroughly. I am pleased to say that the minister's office has now indicated that the amendment will not be opposed by the government. The arguments of the honourable member for O'Connor were obviously persuasive, and I look forward to the government's consent here in the chamber today.

The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 implements a number of 1993 budget announcements by the government. Perhaps the most significant is the increase in the service pension age for women. This bill will increase the qualifying age for women to receive the service pension from 55 to 60 years. The honourable member for O'Connor spoke at some length in the Main Committee debate on the hypocrisy of the government with respect to this provision. We all remember the government, before the last election, viciously attacking the coalition's proposal to increase the pension age for women, as set out in Fightback. Post-election, we are seeing yet another broken promise, yet another stealing of ideas from Fightback.

We still believe that this was a sensible measure which recognised the need for equality of treatment between men and women. Despite caucus committees set up to reverse the budget decision, the government went ahead with its proposal. Any residual caucus embarrassment at the sheer hypocrisy of introducing the policy was simply ignored by the executive.

Another pathetic measure is the increase in the maximum rate of dependent child add-on payable to service pensioners for children who have not turned 16. The increase amounts to $1 a week per child from January 1995. This

SPEECH.PARA: is the result of the government's failure to meet its promise not to increase taxes after winning office in 1993.

PARA.TAB: In the infamous Dawkins budget we saw significant de facto tax increases, adding greatly to the cost of living, especially for those on lower incomes. This increase is a token gesture addressing that cost of living impact. Service pensioners with children will see the government's increase of $1 a week, the maximum rate additional family payment, for the pea and thimble trick that it really is. Other measures implemented by this bill, such as the reintroduction of advance pharmaceutical allowance for the chronically ill, are supported by the coalition.

In summary, the coalition will not be opposing either of the bills before us. We will be moving an amendment to the budget measures bill and, as I said, we look forward to the consent of the government in doing so.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by looking at the Veterans' Affairs (1994-95 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. The Australian Democrats will not be opposing this bill. We see the initiative to align the treatment of compensation payments received by service pensioners and income support supplement recipients with social security payments as fair and sensible. It prevents double dipping and only applies to compensation payments received on or after 1 January 1995.

PARA.TAB: This measure applies only where a person receives a compensation payment which includes a component for loss of earnings or loss of the capacity to earn, and then only if the service pensioner or income support supplement recipient is under pensionable age.

I am pleased to see the automatic payment of funeral benefits to the estate of a veteran who, at the time of death, was receiving extreme disablement adjustment or was a former prisoner of war. But in this context I would say that this is the only point in this proposed legislation that has been queried with me. Our consultative process has found that the bill has the unanimous support of the veteran community, except for the following point.

I have been asked why this payment goes to the estate and not to the widow. I agree that, under normal circumstances, the widow would be the chief if not the sole beneficiary. But this is not always the case, particularly where there has been a second marriage and children of the first family are involved. In cases where the widow has paid the full funeral expenses, and can produce documentation, should not the funeral benefits go to her instead of to the estate? I would be grateful for advice from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) on this matter when we reach the committee stage.

On the question of reimbursement of the cost of obtaining medical evidence by applicants to the Veterans Review Board, I note that when the opposition asked in the other place for this to be extended to applicants to the Specialist Medical Review Council, the minister ruled it out on the grounds that individuals would generally not be making representations to this body. However, he did say that the matter might be discussed further. I am pleased to see that it will not be only the Democrats who are supporting the amendments that Senator Newman will be moving today but that the government will also be supporting the amendments.

The Australian Democrats welcome two other measures in the bill: the education entry payment, which will assist veterans under pension age to further their education and enhance their employment chances; and the removal of the waiting period for service pension for refugees. These people did not have a choice when leaving their home countries and are extremely unlikely to be able to obtain a pension from their country of origin. The non-payment of pharmaceutical allowance to service, disability and war widow or widower pensioners when overseas for a period of 12 months or more seems fair and reasonable and we will not be opposing this measure.

In the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 we see another example of this government's policy of putting an unpopular measure in with a whole lot of good news. The unpopular measure I refer to is the increase in the qualifying age for service pension for women. I am mindful of the amount of legislation we still have to get through in this place, therefore, the Democrats will not be moving any amendments and running the same arguments we did on the Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2) in this place.

I simply want to place on the record that we are opposed to this measure. We do not believe, even though a very small number of women will be affected—I understand the minister has identified only a handful of people, some 52 in all—that this is fair and reasonable. These women simply have not had the opportunities that their male counterparts have had to access regular employment and superannuation and to build up a resource, whether it be through superannuation or capital gain, to see them through their retirement.

The Australian Democrats have referred the question of adequacy of women's retirement incomes, especially the implications of raising the retirement age, to the superannuation committee for report on 28 February 1995. We will be watching the outcomes and the findings of that inquiry with interest. The other two measures in this bill—the advanced pharmaceutical allowance and the pensioner child-care add-on—are beneficial to veterans, and the Democrats will not be opposing them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 contains initiatives that are not related to this year's budget. The first of the initiatives will bring service pensions into line with the social security age pension by gradually increasing the qualifying age at which women can apply for the age pension from 55 to 60 years. This increase will be phased in over 20 years. It will affect very few women because the vast majority of female veterans have already reached 55 years of age. The second initiative restores the facility to pay pharmaceutical allowance in advance after 1 January 1995. The third initiative increases child related payments to service pensioners by $1 per week for each child under 16. This will apply from 1 January 1995.

PARA.TAB: The second bill, the Veterans' Affairs (1994-95 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994, contains the remainder of this year's veterans' affairs budget package. Together with the first bill passed in the winter sittings it certainly delivers major benefits to the ex-service community in Australia.

It is important to remember that this all or nothing package was agreed to by the national bodies of the major ex-service organisations. These groups realistically recognise that it was not possible to improve benefits to veterans and their dependants unless the increased expenditure could be offset by savings elsewhere. We agreed that we needed to ensure that the benefits are provided to those with a genuine entitlement. Clearly, the entire package will provide immediate and long lasting benefits to veterans and their dependants.

So we may all be certain about the initiatives in this particular bill I will very quickly run through them. Compensation payments received by service pensioners and income support supplement recipients are to be treated on a similar basis to compensation payments received by social security income support recipients. There will be an automatic grant of funeral benefit to the estate of a veteran who dies and who is a former prisoner of war or who at the time of death had been receiving extreme disablement adjustment.

Two measures relate to the Veterans Review Board. The requirement that a proportion of the board be medical practitioners will be removed and applicants to the board will be entitled to reimbursement for certain costs of obtaining additional medical evidence to support their application. This latter measure is expected to increase the proportion of claims finalised at this level of the determining system. An education entry payment will be payable to partner and carer service pensioners and to income support supplement recipients who undertake study. Refugees will be exempted from the waiting period for service pension. Pharmaceutical allowance will no longer be payable to persons who are absent from Australia for 12 months or more. Service pensioners whose rate has been reduced to nil will no longer have to reapply for the pension if their income and asset circumstances change sufficiently within six months to allow pension payments to recommence. The bill also contains amendments that are consequential to several of the major initiatives in the first budget measures bill.

Senator Lees asked specifically about the reimbursement of funeral expenses to widows when a funeral benefit has automatically been paid to the veteran's estate. In such a case, the widow may claim the costs from the estate. In conclusion, I thank senators for their contribution to this debate. The two budget measures bills together represent a very significant step forward for veterans, enhancing what I believe is internationally regarded as perhaps the finest repatriation system in the world.

I take considerable pleasure from my own involvement in the formulation of the package during my term as Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I know that Mr Sciacca is also proud of his involvement. He has derived a considerable amount of pleasure from seeing a very significant reform package come through to a satisfactory and excellent conclusion. I commend these bills to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: VETERANS' AFFAIRS (1994-95 BUDGET MEASURES) LEGISLATION
AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1994

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very briefly point out that there has been an inadequacy, one might say, in the legislation in that the medical expenses and the travelling expenses to obtain medical evidence were reimbursable for appeals to the Veterans Review Board but not for appeals to the Specialist Medical Review Council, which are allowed strictly on general medical grounds anyway. I welcome the fact that the government is prepared to countenance the opposition's amendments. I do not wish to delay the Senate any further so I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:

PARA.TAB: After clause 53, page 53, insert the following clause:

SPEECH.PARA: "53A. After section 196ZM of the Principal Act the following sections are inserted in Part XIB:

`196ZN. (1) The Commonwealth may, subject to this section, pay to an applicant who asks the Review Council to conduct a review as provided for by this Part an amount to cover the medical expenses incurred by him or her in respect of relevant documentary medical evidence obtained for the purposes of the review and submitted to the Review Council.
`(2)The applicant is not to be paid:

TAB.TAB: (a)if the applicant has submitted to the Review Council relevant documentary medical evidence relating to only one medical condition—more than $425 for medical expenses; or

(b)if the applicant has submitted to the Review Council relevant documentary medical evidence relating to more than one medical condition—more than $425 for the medical expenses incurred in respect of the evidence relating to any one of those conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: `(3)An amount is not payable in respect of medical expenses unless:

TAB.TAB: (a)the person who has incurred the expenses; or
(b)any person approved by that person or by the Commission;

SPEECH.PARA: applies in writing to the Commission for payment.
`(4)The application for payment must be:

TAB.TAB: (a)in accordance with a form approved by the Commission; and
(b)made within 3 months after the relevant documentary medical evidence was submitted to the Review Council; and
(c)lodged, together with any document that the applicant considers relevant, at an office of the Department in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: `(5)For the purposes of this section "relevant documentary medical evidence" in relation to an application has the same meaning as is specified in section 133.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Travelling expenses for obtaining medical evidence

SPEECH.PARA: `196ZO.(1) If an applicant has had to travel to obtain any relevant documentary medical evidence submitted to the Review Council, the applicant is, subject to this section, entitled to be paid in relation to that travel the travelling expenses that are prescribed.

TAB.TAB: (a)the applicant is accompanied by an attendant when travelling to obtain the evidence; and
(b)the Commission is of the view that it is reasonable for the applicant to be so accompanied by an attendant;

PARA.TAB: the attendant is, subject to this section, entitled to be paid in relation to that travel the travelling expenses that are prescribed.

SPEECH.PARA: `(3)Travelling expenses are not payable in respect of travel outside Australia.
`(4)Travelling expenses are not payable unless:

TAB.TAB: (a)the person who has incurred the expenses; or
(b)any person approved by that person or by the Commission;

PARA.TAB: applies in writing to the Commission for payment under subsection (5).
`(5)The application for payment must be:

SPEECH.PARA: `(6)The Commonwealth is to pay the travelling expenses to which a person is entitled under this section.

PARA.TAB: `196ZP.(1) If the Commission is satisfied that:

(b)it is appropriate, in all the circumstances, that the person should be paid an advance on account of those expenses;

PARA.TAB: the Commission may authorise the payment of that advance to the person.

TAB.TAB: (a)a person has received an advance on account of any travelling expenses that the person is likely to incur; and
(b)the person:
(i)does not incur those travelling expenses; or
(ii)incurs travelling expenses that are less than the amount of the advance;

SPEECH.PARA: the person is liable to repay to the Commonwealth:

TAB.TAB: (c)the amount of the advance; or
(d)the difference between the amount of the advance and the amount of the travelling expenses;
as the case requires.'.".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed new clause moved by the opposition would obviously make provision for medical expenses to be paid to an applicant who asked the Specialist Medical Review Council to conduct a review. The proposed new clause has similar wording to clause 34 of the bill, which deals with payment of expenses incurred by applicants to the Veterans Review Board.

PARA.TAB: The Specialist Medical Review Council has been set up to review statements of principles issued by the Repatriation Medical Authority. Those statements of principles will be issued when there is sound medical scientific evidence that indicates that a particular kind of injury, disease or death can be related to service. Thus there is an inherent difference between an appeal to the Veterans Review Board and a review by the Specialist Medical Review Council. With the VRB medical expenses relate to an individual's condition whereas with the SMRC medical expenses relate to evidence about the causation of a particular kind of injury, disease or death. It is the difference between the diagnosis of a condition and an assessment of what caused that condition.

Because of the generic nature of reviews by the SMRC, it is expected that they will generally not be sought by individuals. However, while the government does wonder about the usefulness of this amendment, as I think has been indicated previously, the government will not be opposing it.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —The citrus industry has spoken at length to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee about the problems associated with the Sales Tax (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill, which I will address in my amendments. First of all, I want to talk about the amendment that I flag I will be moving to each of the bills in this package. The amendment addresses my concern about the level of parliamentary responsibility that is usurped as a result of Australia signing the Uruguay Round of GATT.

PARA.TAB: I wish to talk about some method by which we can incorporate within this set of bills at least some modicum of parliamentary responsibility for those people who are representing Australia and who are currently usurping the interests of elected parliamentarians and the people of Australia by not referring back to us and discussing their decisions.

My amendment would effectively ensure that there is some responsibility and accountability in relation to negotiations in the World Trade Organisation on behalf of Australia. We are simply trying to say that, when such a powerful organisation is established and Australia becomes part of it, it is no longer good enough for an ambassador to disregard the democratic process and take direction only from the minister. The World Trade Organisation will be able to set regulations with which we must bring our laws into conformity, or face action. It is therefore imperative that our ambassador does not have the power to negotiate in contradiction of our laws. To do so would be to take direction from the minister to argue a regulation that would change our laws. This is a total violation of due process and a means of circumventing parliamentary process.

There is no reason that this should be permitted when, in consequence, the parliament is put in a position where it must change law or defy the World Trade Organisation. It is thoroughly undemocratic and anti-democratic. If government wishes to change our laws, then it should do so through parliament. It should not try sneaky backdoor methods to put parliament in a position where changes cannot be considered on their merits but only in the context of trade penalties if changes are not made.

We have considered the fact that there may be cases where legislation change or a general direction for change may be desired, yet it is not appropriate to put that into practice until there is a multilateral agreement for such a change in place. I can see how that can occur and why the parliament might wish change yet not wish to make a pre-emptive or unilateral change. The case of disarmament is such a circumstance, where the ability to safely disarm may be partially determined by others' willingness to do so. We understand the principle.

In our amendment we have attempted to assure that the parliament can recognise this. We make provision for the parliament to approve an approach in negotiations that is inconsistent with existing Australian law. We have said that a resolution of each house can provide such guidance. We recognise the principle that change can be worked towards. What we do not recognise is the ability of such change to be pursued in the World Trade Organisation without account gained from the parliament.

This obviously becomes a means of circumventing parliament. If a direction of change is appropriate, it should attract parliamentary support without the threat of trade sanctions or exclusion from the World Trade Organisation. That is why we will be moving this amendment. That is why we will move this amendment to each bill. It is a simple amendment requiring some accountability to parliament.

We believe the Australian Democrats are prepared to support our amendment. We hope that the opposition, or at least the National Party, will support this amendment since it really does nothing more than what it has been calling for.
