The amendment says that negotiators cannot argue against Australian laws in a forum that can put substantial pressure on parliament to change those laws without prior approval. It says that the negotiators cannot agree on our behalf to such changes as go against our laws without parliament's general approval for the direction of such change. We think this is entirely appropriate and a minimum requirement of accountability and ministerial responsibility to the parliament and people of Australia.

I have spoken to many people over the last few weeks who believe that everything will be okay. I was speaking to a journalist just a few minutes ago. People believe that those circumstances that have existed under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will continue, that if they have not been challenged under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, they will not be challenged. They believe all of the reassurances from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that it should be okay.

There is no reason to believe that the Foreign Investment Review Board will not, for instance, be able to continue to regulate the trade that we have in Australia and the conditions upon which we accept investment. The Foreign Investment Review Board is not involved with the basis upon which we accept imports. That is mainly controlled through the ministry and by certain regulations. We find now that we have fewer of those regulations.

It is certainly not enough to put our faith in the Foreign Investment Review Board. At last count—and it may be less than this now—there were 18 people working in the Foreign Investment Review Board in Australia. When I last looked at its activities outlined in its annual report I found that it mainly chased around—and fairly ineffectually—trying to keep an eye on what kind of real estate speculation occurred in Australia.

There is no way that the toothless Foreign Investment Review Board will be able to fight for the level of Australian ownership. Someone said to me a few minutes ago that if what I say is true what was the point in having those huge arguments about the level of ownership in the media. That is a very good point. What was the point in having those huge arguments about the level of ownership in the Australian media if in time, through these kinds of bills which have regard to the World Trade Organisation, for instance, our print media can, and I assume will, be subject to up to 100 per cent foreign ownership? That is just one example. People believe it will not happen. Why will it not happen? Not because it cannot happen under the World Trade Organisation, but because we have a Foreign Investment Review Board and it has not happened up to now under GATT.

I would like to believe that world corporations worked on those principles. If the general push under the World Trade Organisation legislation means there will be less control and fewer restrictions on the level of ownership in major corporations and major industries and corporations have a greater ability to gain monopoly control of particular industries in Australia, then it will happen. It may not necessarily happen tomorrow, but it may happen in times to come.

I am not just talking about multinationals. I am talking about the push to make sure that we export rather than produce for our local economy. Industries have to get bigger to survive. Smaller industries—family industries, family farmers and those in the citrus industry—will go under if this happens. If honourable senators do not believe me, then they should talk to the banana growers who have already gone through this process.

The Chiquita banana is now fairly common in Australia. United Fruit has a fairly large stronghold in an industry that was largely controlled by Australian interests. I know that we have been talking about the citrus industry. We are talking about what in time will happen to our entire horticultural industry. In this debate we have talked about a number of other industries.

This is still primary industry we are talking about. Primary industry was supposed to be the big benefactor under this proposal. What we are talking about in this amendment is the ability of this parliament to know and be able to scrutinise the arguments being put on behalf of Australian industries and citizens in country regions of this country in relation to the environment and the future environment of Australia.

If we are saying that we have to have bigger citrus producers, they have to have lower costs to survive and they need more irrigation, which has been talked about today, what is going to happen? We need to think about that. If the prices stay the same for five years we will have to produce more for the same price. What is that going to do to our water systems, our environment and what amount of fertiliser will we require? We are talking about one industry.

We have people negotiating on behalf of Australia who do not have to report back to parliament and who can even push for much more than what our current legislation allows. That means they can, on our behalf, agree to change our laws or agree to push for something that will, in effect, change our laws not just now but in the future. What we are saying is that there should be some accountability on the part of those people who negotiate on behalf of all Australians.

This legislation is not just about taxes, it is not just about specific industries, it is about changes that could have an impact right across Australian society. I have heard of incidents where local governments have been told that they have to change their by-laws or their by-laws cannot be used because they would be considered to be GATT-inconsistent. Therefore, we have to think now whether we want a fall back so this parliament can be consulted about the line that is being taken.

I remind the Labor Party of the decisions that were taken at its national conference which related to labour conditions. Does the Labor Party know or can it find out—can anybody find out—whether or not those people who are negotiating on behalf of Australia will be negotiating, for instance, in line with the decision that was made at the Labor conference? Has that been taken into consideration? Has that been discussed? What line is being taken on that question? What kind of accountability can we expect?

Senator Spindler may have something to say on this issue. I would be keen to know from the minister how we can be sure what line is being taken—whether the concerns of the Australian industry are being taken into consideration or whether a strong line of free trade is being taken by the negotiators on the basis that those who do not benefit from GATT suffer collateral damage. That is the kind of accountability that I am interested in. That is the minimal request that we are making in amendment No. 1 to the Sales Tax (World Trade Organisation Amendments) Bill 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are disposed to support this amendment. I have been extremely concerned with the way our international trade negotiations have been carried out without regard to the social and environmental consequences. We have the example of NAFTA where a side agreement was concluded on environmental matters. Yet when I suggested to the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) that we should push for these matters at both GATT and APEC, the answer was, `No, we cannot do that. We are concentrating on trade. We do not want to jeopardise free trade. We cannot at this stage introduce side issues.'
—Stop making it up. That's not what I said at all.

—If the minister can tell me that he will push for side agreements in the APEC negotiations or that he has or will push for a subcommittee to be established at APEC to deal with social and environmental issues which will arise as a result of the liberalisation of trade, then I will be very happy. My distinct impression was that our government was not prepared to raise or push these matters.

PARA.TAB: As a result of that, we are now putting ourselves in a position where we are becoming part of the worldwide race to the bottom, where capital will be chasing the lowest costs. And the lowest costs do not stop simply at legally low wages. They go as far as child labour, which I have had occasion to put on record in this parliament. The Senate passed unanimously a motion for the government to take any action. Even if the government decided that it was prepared to take some decisive action, in line with Senator Harkin's bill in the United States, to prohibit imports of goods produced by child labour I wonder whether under the World Trade Organisation agreement, under the GATT agreement, we would be able to have such a law without it being challenged by countries that do not want to be hampered in this way. The minister might wish to address that question.

Looking at the amendment that Senator Margetts is moving, I certainly applaud the spirit of it and support it in substance. I have some difficulty at line 4 in agreeing to `may not take any action and enter into any negotiation'. It is difficult for parliament to put the condition on initial negotiations, initial actions that may lead later to any number of agreements or conclusions.

To make this a practical amendment, it may be useful to take out four words in line 4, `take any action or' and take out the word `negotiation'. Then it would read that we do require the agreement of parliament before any agreement or arrangement is concluded by people who are negotiating on behalf of Australia in these trade negotiations.

It may then be an amendment that the government will seriously consider—certainly one that the opposition should seriously consider. After all, the opposition has told us that it is concerned about the government concluding treaties without the approval of parliament, that this is an infringement of the sovereignty of the Australian parliament. Here is an opportunity for the opposition to show that it means what it says. I would like Senator Margetts to consider the amendment I have suggested. She may wish to amend her motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be happy to consider that if I could get a clarification of the words Senator Spindler would like to change.

—I would suggest that in line 4 Senator Margetts take out the first four words, `take any action or', and then take out the word `negotiation' in the middle of that line so that it reads: `may not enter into any agreement or arrangement'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be happy to seek leave to amend my amendment accordingly, and that would go for each time this amendment is put, which it will be on each of the bills.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.After clause 1, page 1, insert the following clause:
"1A.(1) This section commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.

"(2) The provisions of this Act, other than section 1 and this section, are not to take effect before the commencement of an Act which provides that persons representing the Commonwealth in or before the World Trade Organisation may not enter into any agreement or arrangement which has or may have the object or effect of altering or overriding any law of the Commonwealth, unless that object or effect or a class of such objects or effects has been approved by a resolution of each House of the Parliament.".

TALK.START.PARA: —(4.59 p.m.)—There are several issues I want to deal with. I might use this as the one occasion in this debate in which I will address some of the general issues that are raised. We could deal with them on every amendment, but I do not intend to. This amendment is being moved to every bill. I hope we are not going to debate it every time. I will try to range across some of the general issues, the misconceptions and the fundamental flaw in the amendment and then, even if I agreed with what it was trying to do, the problem I would have with putting it as an amendment to this body of legislation in this way.

PARA.TAB: I shall start from the end; let me deal with that issue first. If we move this amendment—even if the government agreed with it, which we do no not—it means that this act does not come into effect until the parliament comes back next year and carries another piece of legislation. So first and foremost it means that Australia cannot be a founding member of the World Trade Organisation. That is what this amendment means first and foremost, because by 1 January we will not have passed another piece of legislation in accordance with subclause (2). It means that maybe one day we will be a member. We might have to renegotiate our entry; that is not absolutely clear. Certainly all the benefits are put at risk. That is No. 1. It is a fairly fundamental problem. I think that ought to knock the amendment out by itself but let me use the opportunity to debate the two broader issues.

I find it repugnant that people come in here and assume that they are the only people concerned about the consequences of actions that are being taken. I accept that people are entitled to disagree with what we are doing. It is a democracy. People are entitled to get up and say, `You are wrong and the consequences of what you are doing are adverse.' I accept that people are entitled to do that and that they think that sometimes. Maybe sometimes they are right, maybe sometimes they are wrong. But I find it absolutely offensive that they think they are the only people who care about the consequences, that the people who go overseas to represent Australia do not take any cognisance of the social and environmental consequences of their action or that the government, which gives them the negotiating brief, does not take into account the social and environmental consequences. Those opposite might think we are wrong. They might think we made a miscalculation. They might think we are so dumb we cannot see what they can see with great clarity—that this is going to cause all sorts of disastrous consequences. Of course they are entitled to that view and to express it as forcefully and forthrightly as they wish, but to pretend that they are the only ones who are concerned about it and that we are blithely pursuing a course of action without considering its consequences, or perhaps even consciously pursuing something which has adverse consequences, is something that I find continually offensive.

There is only one other generality I want to deal with, the great myth of the race to the bottom. If the race to the bottom was correct, the great mass of the world's investment would be taking place in Sudan. Sudan has the lowest wages in the world and no environmental laws. Everybody would be going there. Nobody would be investing in Singapore because wages are very high there and they are starting to develop strict environmental laws. But the truth is that everybody is investing in Singapore and no-one is investing in Sudan because life is more complicated than the opposition's conspiracy.

If you want to take it closer to home, why is there no investment in Burma, which has very high tariff walls and high protection and does not let any of this alien Western consumer influence in, but everybody is investing in neighbouring countries as they open up? It is not the case that we find some inevitable correlation between where corporate activity takes place and where the wages are lower. I am not saying that is not a factor in decision making. If it were not the case, the poorest people in the countries who are growing would be much worse off. That is why countries can grow out of poverty if they get the right policies. People do go and invest there and provide jobs to the people there. All the underdeveloped countries that have emerged from that to have very high living standards have essentially done it based on that strategy. The truth is that you do not find the lowest wages in the countries with the lowest protection. You find that the lowest wages are in the countries with the highest protection and that investment does not follow.

I do no want to pursue all those rabbits down all these burrows. I just think that in relation to the myth of the race to the bottom some facts need to be pointed out. I am not going to enter into all that at any other stage during this debate.

Let me deal with the substance of this amendment. Once the passion of the Greens' and the Democrats' concern about GATT passes, they will think about the consequences of this amendment for other pieces of legislation and for the international negotiations into which Australia enters. The Greens and the Democrats generally welcome and support the application of the international negotiations into which Australia enters. Sometimes they think we are a bit soft about them, but our three parties tend to have a more common view than does the coalition. If we were ever to accept this proposal—we are not going to—I do not think the people the Greens and the Democrats support in the overwhelming majority of issues would welcome it.

But it seems to me that the amendment is flawed for other reasons. That is a matter of political comment and a matter for their judgment. It does not really matter whether it is right or wrong. What worries me about it is that it is entirely unrealistic in its sense of how international negotiations take place and it flies in the face of the relationship between the executive and the legislature under the Westminster system.

Of course the law of Australia should not be able to be changed without a decision of this parliament. That is what we are doing now. The so-called attack on our sovereignty is actually an expression of our sovereignty. We are making a sovereign decision to join this organisation. If it undermines the sovereignty of nations, it is very hard to understand why more and more countries are battling to get into it. People are not striving to get out; they are battling to get in. There are 140 member countries and 22 applicants—all the big, new emerging economies. China, which has never been renowned for not having concern for its sovereignty, is desperate to get into this organisation—understandably—and is arguing very hard about why it should be in it.

In Australia, under the Westminster system, legislation is initiated by the executive, brought to the parliament and is approved or not approved. Parliament may decide not to approve it. That is why this is the legislature. The executive cannot legislate of its own initiative, and it should not be able to.

TALK.START.PARA: —When they don't approve it you should take the umpire's decision.

—We do not always take it with good grace, but we always take it. There is no law that says that we have to like it—only that we have to accept it. As I was saying, that is the way legislation is initiated under the Westminster system. The negotiating brief for people who go overseas to represent Australia is approved by ministers and, where it is a major issue like this one, by the cabinet. That is an act of the executive government. We send people overseas when we know and have analysed and assessed the consequences for Australian legislation. It is no different from the Australian government making a proposal that any other law should be changed. We sit in the cabinet. We say, `This proposal means a change of law X.' We propose that change to the parliament. We bring it into the parliament, and the parliament decides whether or not it wants that law changed. We do that because, on the balance of evidence, we think that is what is in the national interest, and the parliament can decide whether we have got the balance right or wrong. Sometimes that decision arises as a result of discussions with other countries, whether it is about a big treaty like this, bilateral negotiations with another country, or some other form of relationship to do with the International Civil Aviation Organisation—whatever it is. In that range of things, from time to time we come to agreement and we legislate. We would never have had an international civil aviation organisation if we had not had an initiative that overrode Australian legislation and came in with an executive proposal that we should have a law to regulate those things. The executive initiated it; the parliament approved it. It is the way in which our parliamentary system does, should and must work.

PARA.TAB: I have not got time to debate at length the question of business and industry consultation on these matters, but I can tell senators that there were more than 300 meetings between the Australian government and business and industry groups and associations in the negotiation of this legislation. At the end of negotiations, the group responsible for coordinating industry consultation, the trade negotiation advisory group, said that the negotiation and the consultation in this process was a model for consultative process between government and industry. So let us put those things in perspective. We can argue at another time about whatever people on different sides of the chamber think about other negotiations we have been involved with.

For the three reasons I have outlined, we are opposed to this amendment. The most profound reason for that is that it is—as it is designed to be—a measure which prevents Australia from joining the World Trade Organisation on 1 January, because this bill would not have come into effect by that time. Also, the amendment is fundamentally misconceived and it cuts across, in a very important way, the way in which the Westminster system can and must operate.

TALK.START.PARA: —We need to rectify a number of points made in the statements of the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan). I put on record that we are not against Australia joining GATT. What we are concerned about is the conditions under which we join GATT and the consequences of our joining GATT. The government will have made its point if the minister can tell me when the government put before this parliament the detailed conditions of joining GATT, the consequences of so joining and the agreements that the government is making by joining GATT.

PARA.TAB: What I am objecting to is simply being confronted with a batch of bills which alter our laws so that we can join GATT, yet the obligations that Australia is entering into have not been detailed and put before this parliament to be debated and accepted, rejected or modified.

We are very conscious of the benefits that will accrue to the agricultural industries in Australia as a result of GATT. What we are querying is: what is the price the government has agreed to pay? Should it have been different? Should there have been additional safeguards? Should there have been side agreements and conditions to protect other people in our community and to make sure that Australia can continue to meet its international obligations under the conventions to which we have acceded?

If the race to the bottom is a figment of my imagination, perhaps the minister can explain why our stores now carry jumpers, trousers, shirts, et cetera—textiles—that are made in China. In a Chinese textile factory, the wage is now the equivalent of about $25 for a 48-hour week. There is no regard for work safety and there are no environmental safeguards. About seven years ago only one-third of all articles of clothing and shoes in our stores were imported; two-thirds were made in Australia. Why is it that that proportion has been reversed? Why is it that two-thirds of such items are being imported and one-third—and getting less; it will be much less after GATT and APEC—are made here? If that is not a race to the bottom, perhaps the minister can explain what is.

All that is being asked is that our government become more conscious of the consequences of its actions and of its obligation to put before the parliament the commitments that it intends to make on behalf of the Australian nation in treaties of this kind before it signs them. If ever there were a treaty that needed careful scrutiny by this parliament, it is this one.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was at least one question I asked which the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) has not answered. I will clear up another point that the minister made first before I re-ask the question. Senator Spindler said we were very conscious of the benefits to the agriculture industry. I need to put on the record now that there is a difference in degree between the Democrats and the Greens. We have both been very concerned about the implications of the GATT. People in this chamber may be very aware that the Greens did not wish Australia to sign the Uruguay Round of GATT because we had received information at the time about the problems with the agreement. We are very concerned that, if we signed the agreement and were so gung-ho about it, with all its problems that were so clear to a growing number of people last year, we would be facing these kinds of problems, being put under pressure to ratify the agreement and change our legislation.

PARA.TAB: I want to put on the record that the degree of difference here is that the Greens did not wish Australia to sign the Uruguay Round of GATT because we saw it was such a flawed agreement and because we believed that many of the supposed benefits to the agriculture industry may well prove to be illusory. If they prove to be illusory, there will be other collateral damage, such as the way the government is tending to treat people—like the women currently in very poor conditions in the footwear, clothing and textile industries and other industries in Australia—and that those people will have been betrayed in the grossest sense.

The $1 billion that is meant to come to the agriculture industry is supposed to come over a matter of years. We are already seeing the impact of climate change on our agriculture industry now. If we continue to have serious impacts from El Nino, reverse El Nino and drought as well as destructive weather patterns associated with El Nino and which are predicted under the climatic change by thousands of scientists, the markets to which we are hoping to gain access may well not be able to be filled by Australian producers. It is very clear that there is no loyalty amongst friends or former friends when it comes to filling those gaps in the market.

Therefore, our current vulnerability to climate change may well have an impact on the benefits we are hoping for. Already the estimates from this year's drought are considered to be in the range of about $250 million. It does not take much mathematics to work out that, if we are hoping to make $1 billion benefit over seven years, and this year the impacts of climate change are something in the region of $250 million down, we could well be moving in the other direction at the same time.

It might also be significant that many of the benefits that we are hoping for come from an assumption that the prices for commodities via GATT will increase. I believe that some of these assumptions are flawed. I believe they are flawed because they assume that there will not be a flooding of the market at any one time. They assume that people will be able to regulate the amount of agricultural produce from their particular countries. They assume that other countries will not be able to fill a niche at any particular time or flood the market at some other time. And they assume that the dumping provisions under the current international trade rules will actually work.

One of the things that has come out on a number of occasions during the hearings that we have had is that there are serious concerns about whether Australia will be able to take effective action on anti-dumping. Therefore, we may well be operating under false assumptions, because the ability for transfer pricing becomes greater under the Uruguay Round of GATT. So people can appear not to be dumping when in fact they are. They can go through a second country, leave the profits in a country where they get the least tax, then sell on and claim that they are not dumping because they have just upped their price by a certain percentage and then sold to some of Australia's traditional markets.

Whilst there are certain expectations and dollar signs in a number of people's eyes and the expectation that over something like seven years we will get $1 billion worth of benefits, it may well be that other provisions within the Uruguay Round of GATT, and enforceable under the World Trade Organisation, may work against the proposed benefits. That is not even counting the impact on employment. Employment is not really talked much about. There is an assumption about jobs, but if what we are doing is moving into the areas where we have a so-called natural advantage—in Western Australia, the Western Australian government talks about mining, forestry and those kinds of industries—we will continue to be a hole in the ground, a quarry for the world, and the prices of those commodities will go down and down over time, even with a so-called freer market.

Therefore, if we become more and more dependent on commodity prices—the world commodity price is going down—what does that mean for our economy? What does that mean for the people who can be employed in that industry? Capital is freely moving around and does not have a tariff on it. So it is very easy to replace it in lots of industries—labour for capital—and it is happening more and more.

We are going into a model where every country is being told to get rid of people and put in capital—structural readjustment. It is not suitable for each country, but that is the model that is being pushed into each country as a result of this new internationalisation of trade. First of all, I think we have to be very concerned that in our assumptions of the overall benefits we are not putting the value we should on people who will otherwise be considered as collateral damage. Those people will feel considerably betrayed.

The reason I asked about the outcome of the ALP national conference is that I know a number of unions believe that as a result of the outcome of the national conference in relation to wages and conditions the government, which is negotiating on behalf of the unions, will be arguing for the ability for us to make decisions on behalf of, for instance, child labour in other countries, importing products of child labour. What I would like to ask the minister is: have our negotiators taken a strong stance as a result of the ALP national conference to incorporate the concerns of child labour into the World Trade Organisation agenda?

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to say a couple of things to make sure they are on the record. The coalition does not propose to participate in any detail in this committee debate on the bills. We believe, as coalition speakers have said in their speeches on the second reading, that the World Trade Organisation agreement that has been signed—following very detailed, very tortuous international negotiations extending over many years in which, I must say, Australia has played a continuing and important role—ushers in a new era of hope and opportunity for world trade and therefore for the prospects for an improvement in the living standards of all people in all countries, including in particular those countries whose citizens are suffering the greatest misery and hardship today.

PARA.TAB: We are debating the seven bills, amendments to existing legislation plus one new bill, being the trade marks bill, to make our legislation accord with the arrangements of the new international trade regime. We need amendments to get our legislation into line. The overwhelming majority of those changes are of a relatively minor nature. The proposals that Senator Margetts in particular has already floated—I must say I am somewhat surprised and disappointed to hear Senator Spindler support those remarks—are designed to stop the passage of this legislation. That is what she is really all about.

I do not know the motivation for that, but I can only say to Senator Margetts and others of a like mind that, if that is done, they are causing great damage to Australia. They are trying to take away from the huge area of opportunities for the improvement in living standards of all Australians from wherever they may come and from whatever industries overall that they may be in.

I will not say much more in this debate. I wanted to get that point on the record. A few of my colleagues may wish to comment on some of the specific amendments. Our general thrust is that we very much believe that this package of bills ought to go through as promptly and expeditiously as possibly. It is not as though something has been suddenly sprung on us. In most cases, relatively minor amendments are required to put into place in the Australian legislative scene a range of agreements that have been in the full light of public debate here in Australia for many years.

It is unfortunate that it looks as though we will have to go through a very long period of debate, if the last half hour or so is any indication. I believe that it is counterproductive. For those reasons, I will not detain the chamber on this occasion. We believe that these bills should go through unamended.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of courtesy, although it does not directly relate to this bill, Senator Margetts asked me a question. I can assure honourable senators, including Senator Margetts—I am sure that they are all breathlessly concerned about it—that we will implement the decisions of our national conference.
—I would like to clarify that. This is directly related to the amendment.
—It has nothing to do with the sales tax bill.
—It has to do with the accountability of Australia's negotiators to—
—It has nothing to do with the sales tax bill.
—I want a clarification. Does this mean that the line being taken by the negotiators on behalf of Australia—
—There are no negotiations going on. I don't know what you mean. We will implement the conference decisions, but there are no negotiations.
—Can the minister please outline how this conference decision will be implemented, as there are no negotiations at the moment.
—This decision does not relate to the negotiations. But I will implement it. When I am ready to implement my party's policy, I will announce it, but not to you.

—What I have asked relates to my amendment, which is that the Commonwealth be given some ability to scrutinise what is being negotiated on our behalf. I know that there are people within the minister's party who believed that, when they made a decision at their conference, some action would be taken as a result of that decision. I believe that a number of those people would feel bitterly betrayed if that decision simply means that we are no longer currently in negotiation. It is not quite true, because a number of bodies are not part of the GATT but are part of the World Trade Organisation, of which Australia plays a part. He is saying that that decision is going nowhere because currently we are not in negotiation. Is that what he is saying?

—No. It is not what I am saying. I am saying that I will implement the conference decision. I support, and will implement, the conference decision, but I am not going to announce what I am going to do with it here and now.
—The minister has claimed that Australian laws are made as a result of changes decided in the executive.
—No, I didn't.

—In his discussion, he said that that is the way the laws are made in the Westminster system. He gave a description of the Westminster system that he said I obviously did not understand. Therefore, he felt it necessary to explain that laws are made by decisions through the parliamentary executive that go through the process of consultation and so on. He did not explain what I would like him to explain, which is that if a currently existing Australian law is considered to be GATT inconsistent what would happen if we, the parliamentary representatives in Australia, decided that we did not want that law to change?
—If the parliament does not wish to change a law of Australia, the law of Australia stays in effect as passed by the parliament.

—What would happen in relation to our obligations under the World Trade Organisation if the parliamentary representatives of this parliament refused to change a law that was considered to be GATT inconsistent?

—It is hypothetical, because the detail of what would happen would depend upon the nature of the law, the nature of the perceived inconsistency and the degree of concern of the people challenging our law. But, if we enter into an agreement and we do not meet the requirements of that agreement, it is possible that people would take trade action against us.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts has to realise that one country that most frequently challenges the laws of other countries in the GATT is Australia. We have been frequent users of the processes of the GATT, in the interests of Australia, to challenge laws in other countries that have been against our interests. It has been a profitable and worthwhile pastime on behalf of this country which we intend to continue to pursue. However, there cannot be a system whereby Australia can complain about what other people do but they cannot complain about what we do; the world does not work like that. But other countries continue to have the right, as we do, to legislate as we choose. We need to be conscious of the consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —In as far as the minister has gone, one consequence could be, as he mentioned, trade sanctions against Australia if a legal challenge in the World Trade Organisation court were lost from Australia's point of view. Is that not the case?

—I feel like sending a written apology to all the other 74 senators for taking their time. There is no World Trade Organisation court. I am not quite sure what Senator Margetts means. If there were a challenge, a decision could be made that our laws are not consistent with an agreement that we have signed. It is not unlike any other agreement that people enter into; if those who enter into an agreement do not honour it, the other parties to the agreement are likely to be a little unhappy.

PARA.TAB: It was certainly said during the debate that one of the most important things which has to happen now is that we make sure that people honour their commitments under the legislation. We will be very vigilant in making sure that everybody else honours their commitments, because we are of the view that they are overwhelmingly in the interests of Australia and the world. It is fundamentally in the interests of people in small to medium sized countries, including Australia, and particularly in trading nations such as Australia. That is why we will be vigilant.

We cannot expect the world to stand idly by while we vigilantly pursue it and not have it vigilantly assess us. It will. We think we have always stood up to that scrutiny in the past, and we think we will in the future. But it is a great plus for Australia that we have the capacity, through this mechanism, to challenge the discriminatory measures that other people take which disadvantage us.

There are some actions of that nature which we are contemplating now taking—we are in negotiation with other nations—that could well win major trade benefits for Australia. There is no way that we could do that without the capacity to challenge other people's laws within the GATT. We can, we have, we do, we will and we accept that other people may do the same to us, provided that we continue to legislate as we have until now. Since the 1940s, when we first entered into GATT, Australia has consistently legislated in accordance with our agreements, as I think the Australian people expect us to. I think they expect Australia to keep its word, and we will.

TALK.START.PARA: —I obviously used the wrong word but it does not change the fact that there is a dispute resolution panel. The minister did say that other countries can challenge Australian laws. I do not think many people understand this at the moment. If another country challenges Australia's laws or trading practices and the dispute goes to the dispute resolution panel, could the minister explain to the committee what that process is and who is on the panel?

—Off the top of my head, I cannot give Senator Margetts all that detail. There is nothing stunningly new about it. It is not being affected by any legislation before the parliament at the moment. Fundamentally the processes under the WTO, as they relate to this, would be the same as those of the GATT.

PARA.TAB: There are some changes that do not affect our domestic legislation and, therefore, are not incorporated here. Essentially, they are changes which we support, but the core processes are the same as they have been since the mid-1940s. I have distributed information about the World Trade Organisation in the past to people in the parliament. If it will help the committee, I am happy to supply more. I can assure the committee—if it is not immediately evident to everybody—that it has nothing to do with this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has everything to do with this bill because we are talking about what the consequences will be, and the implications for Australian sovereignty is exactly to do with what my amendment to this bill is about. I will help the Minister for Trade Senator McMullan) out. It is a disappointment that he does not seem to know and that he thinks it is a bit complicated.

PARA.TAB: There are three trade experts on the dispute resolution panel. These trade experts—the minister can correct me if I am wrong; if he says this is too difficult, he might have to check with his advisers—are chosen by a mutual decision of the disputants; the choice of the three is by mutual decisions of the disputants. Am I right so far?

TALK.START.PARA: —You have missed a bit, but it has nothing to do with the bill. Senator Margetts is entitled to make a speech, but I do not wish to extend this debate any further.

—The minister, after saying that this was too complex, obviously was misleading the committee. It is not terribly complex to explain to the committee what the dispute resolution panel is—that is, what degree of sovereignty Australia is giving up. There is a difference. I know, as a lot of people who have looked into the GATT know, that Australia has been involved with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade for many years. Most people who have looked into it also know that the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has changed over the years from being an association which was largely concerned with getting a fair trade deal for the newly independent nations after independence to an agreement which is now working towards the World Trade Organisation.

PARA.TAB: The very big difference between GATT and the World Trade Organisation is that the World Trade Organisation has power that the GATT did not. To say that things are not going to happen under the World Trade Organisation that have not already happened under the GATT is not quite giving the correct information to the committee. As we know, the World Trade Organisation is the type of organisation which was aimed for right at the beginning—some organisation and structure was aimed for right at the beginning—and which has not come into being until now.

Therefore, there is a major difference between the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and what we are getting into under the GATT in terms of our sovereignty. If Australia were asked or required to change its laws if some of them were disputed by another country as being GATT inconsistent, or if a decision we made to trade or not to trade or to invest or not to allow investment were challenged by a country—it could be a corporation which asks its country to take a dispute to the dispute resolution panel—a decision could be made by those three trade experts which, as I said, is by mutual decision of the disputants. If that decision is made, it is extremely difficult for it to be overturned. In fact, it would require a unanimous decision of the members of the World Trade Organisation to overturn such a decision. Is that not the case?

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear the last part. Could you say it again? I missed what you were saying about overturning.

—If a decision were made by the dispute resolution panel, which was an adverse decision to Australia and which required us to either change our laws, to cease a particular trading practice or to cease restricting a particular investment from an overseas corporation, would it not require a unanimous decision of the members of the World Trade Organisation to overturn that decision?

—I did say I was not going to extend this debate any further because it has nothing to do with the legislation. Some part of what Senator Margetts has said is right, but she has missed out a stage. If interested senators would let me know whether they would like a document outlining all this, I will send it to them. In all the matters to which Senator Margetts refers, the WTO will operate in the same way as the GATT has traditionally operated.
—Can I just get this on the record, finally. The minister denies that it requires a unanimous decision of the members of the World Trade Organisation?
—I said you have missed a stage, but I am not going to go into it. It is a waste of the committee's time.

—I do not believe it is. The people in the chamber ought to know that, if three members of the dispute resolution panel find against Australia and ask Australia to change its law or trading practices, it would require a unanimous decision by all members of the World Trade Organisation to overturn that decision. Could the minister's unwillingness to answer this be because he does not wish people in the committee to know or to understand that if a country brings a dispute against Australia and if it is a member of the World Trade Organisation—which is a requirement if it brings a dispute against Australia—it would be impossible for that decision to be overturned because it would require the disputing country to vote against itself.
—If I wanted to keep a secret from the people of Australia, I would not try to do it about something that has been operating, and which Australia has been acting under, for about the last 40 years.

—It may well be that the dispute panel operated in that way for the last 40 years, and, as I mentioned before, the difference between the World Trade Organisation and the GATT as it has been operating over the last 40 or so years is that now these decisions are enforceable and can have taken action on them by trade sanctions.
—You're wrong.
—If it is wrong, I suggest that the minister give the information to the committee to prove that to be true.
—All this conspiracy is wrong, that has not changed.

—The ability of the World Trade Organisation to take sanctions against a particular country is wider than its ability to take sanctions on a particular item. The disputed action may involve wheat, wool or exports of beef, and, if we are found to be in breach of the World Trade Organisation, the punishment that could be meted out to Australia as a result of a lost case in the dispute resolution panel could be wider than trade sanctions in the beef industry. It could involve all aspects of Australian trade. Could the minister state whether or not this is the case?

—I referred to the advisers; because Senator Margetts was so adamant, I thought perhaps I had failed to remember the circumstances correctly. But as I have said several times, and I hope I am now saying it for the last time, the World Trade Organisation's processes in the matters that Senator Margetts referred to—there are some significant positive changes but they do not affect the issues that Senator Margetts is raising—and the capacity of other contracting parties to take action in response, are unchanged between the GATT and the World Trade Organisation. I know there are conspiracy theories about it around the world but they are untrue.
—I would like to direct a question to Senator Margetts.
—Don't you want to go home?

—I think the question might clarify the problem that Senator Margetts has with the legislation. Senator Margetts said that the effect of the legislation was to deprive Australia of sovereignty. My understanding of sovereignty—it is shared by most people who are involved in one form or another with international law—is that sovereignty means the right of a government to act in respect of its own country. I do not think Senator Margetts is suggesting that, as a consequence of an action which is brought before the World Trade Organisation, another country, a complainant, could make legislation in relation to Australia. It would merely be that the complainant would receive a declaration that Australia was in breach of certain provisions of the agreement. On the basis of that declaration the complainant country would then take legislative action to have effect within its own boundaries—to take action against Australia. Surely, that is what Senator Margetts is suggesting, is she not?

—No, that is not the case. I thank Senator O'Chee for the question. What I meant was that under the World Trade Organisation—which does have considerably more power than the GATT, and that is why people are pushing for it to be signed—if another country finds a complaint, which is found in favour of the complainant under the dispute resolutions panel, against a law or a trade practice in Australia as being GATT inconsistent or World Trade Organisation inconsistent, they can require that Australia change that law or trade practice. If Australia does not change that law or trade practice, sanctions can be placed against Australia under this new regime. Those sanctions do not simply have to be tit for tat—a beef sanction for a beef sanction. It can be a wider sanction. So, if Australia were considered to be GATT inconsistent in relation to beef, the sanctions that could be imposed could be across a number of sectors.

PARA.TAB: That is what I am saying. That is what is being said by a number of people who are looking carefully into the implications of the World Trade Organisation. It is possible, via the loss of our sovereignty, for a complainant to take that complaint to the dispute resolutions panel. If it is found against Australia, we can be required to change our laws or trading practices. If we do not, the outcome can be sanctions or we can choose to withdraw from the World Trade Organisation. That is the considered opinion of a number of people who have written about this new organisation. In the United States a number of laws have already been challenged under the GATT and they have been made to change those laws.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is under the existing process.

—Under the existing process. However, because of the concern of the United States in relation to the World Trade Organisation, if the minister does not believe that it can be stronger than the Uruguay Round of GATT, can the minister tell us why he thinks the United States placed a `three strikes and you're out' provision in relation to disputes—that is, if there were three successful disputes against the United States, they could withdraw from the agreement.

—I suggest that, if people want to ask me questions about trade policy that do not relate to the bill, they should ask me a question during question time. I have strong views about that matter. I am happy to make them public—but not here, not now. Let us get on with the business.

—Considering the very strange and contradictory information that the minister has given us, if there is no problem with our sovereignty, if there is no capacity at all for this dispute process by another country, if it is successful, to cause us to change our laws and if there is no extra power in the World Trade Organisation than has ever existed under GATT, can the minister explain what the need is currently for us to change this or any other law as a matter of urgency?

—I have not got the faintest idea as to what is the connection between those two assertions. We have entered into an agreement which is different, not because of the powers of enforcement but because we have won tremendous concessions in terms of market opening opportunities for Australia. The terms of the agreement were agreed in December last year. If we are to implement our part of that agreement, we need to pass this legislation so that we can join the World Trade Organisation on 1 January. So it has got nothing at all to do with the powers of the WTO to act on appeals and disputes.

PARA.TAB: I reiterate that, with regard to the power of the WTO in matters relating to appeals which Senator Margetts has raised, the powers will be the same under the WTO as they are under the GATT. We welcome that; we want this agreement to be enforceable because there are benefits to us in it. There is not much use in our signing it if no one else takes any notice of it and there is nothing we can do about it. Australia will gain benefits from it. The way in which we can make sure that those benefits flow is to ensure that we have a mechanism for redress if people do not honour the commitments that they have made. We think that is a good thing, not a bad thing.

It is a recommendation of the Australian government to this parliament that, in our national interests and as an act of our sovereignty, we make a conscious decision to join. If we do not wish to, then the legislation should be defeated. That is our right. But we think it is an agreement that is in Australia's interests. We want it to be enforceable. That is why we support the dispute mechanism. That is why we have always supported it and always participated actively in it. We will continue to do so. I think it is in the national interests and that is why we want the legislation passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the minister has just confirmed many of the things I have said. He said that we need to change these laws so that we can join. I have said that the reason we have to change these laws is that it is required by the World Trade Organisation. I have also said that another nation, by dispute, can require us to change our laws in the future. The minister said we can act independently according to the democratic process brought about by the elected members of this parliament. But he also said that there will be consequences. He claimed, however, that the World Trade Organisation has no more powers than the Uruguay Round of GATT, or previous rounds. But at the same time he said that we want to be part of the World Trade Organisation because we want it to be enforceable. It is either one or the other, Minister.
—The previous rounds were enforceable, too.

—It either has a great deal more powers than the previous Uruguay Round of GATT or it does not. There must be some reason why there is an urgency for us to pass these laws and why there are a number of laws that we cannot change. We have already had some discussion about whether or not something is GATT consistent or GATT inconsistent. The minister has said that we can act independently and take the consequences. If we go through this process, pass this legislation, ratify the GATT and become a member of the World Trade Organisation, what are the consequences if we break the agreement?

—That was so rambling and incoherent, I do not know what it was about. If somebody thinks it is a secret that we are passing this legislation so that we can join the World Trade Organisation, I do not know where they have been since December last year. In the middle of December last year we announced that we wanted to join the WTO and we announced that we would be legislating in conformity with the agreement at that time. We are proceeding in exactly the manner we have been announcing since 15 December last year.

PARA.TAB: It is true that the World Trade Organisation, or the Uruguay Round agreement that we signed at Marrakech, is enforceable in exactly the same terms as all the previous rounds were enforceable. We signed those at different stages. Governments of different hues in Australia have agreed to them over the last 40 years and the parliament has legislated accordingly, and the process was the same as it is on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry. The question was not answered. I asked: if we break the Uruguay Round of GATT after it has been ratified, what will be the consequences for Australia?

—I do apologise to the rest of the chamber. The circumstances are that we have three choices. They are no different from the three choices we had under the GATT as a consequence of the Tokyo Round, which this supersedes. Nothing has changed, and it certainly does not relate to this legislation, but in the faint but fond hope that it might help pass the legislation, let me say this: the process is more complicated than Senator Margetts explained, but let us not worry about that. If our legislation eventually is found not to be consistent with the legislation, we have three choices. We may not take legislative action. It depends on what the event is, but we may wish to remedy the situation by legal or administrative action, as the case may be, to bring it into accord with the agreement—and we might wish to do that because we consciously might not have wished to do it; it might have been inadvertent and then, of course, that is what we would wish to do. Or we might, as a matter of our sovereign legislative responsibility, choose so to do. If it is an executive action, we would do it at executive government level; if it required the law, the parliament would do it.

PARA.TAB: There may be the capacity for us to pay damages or compensation to the people concerned if we have taken action adverse to their interests in breach of an agreement into which we entered, which is not an unusual thing to do. If you enter into an agreement with someone and you breach it in a way that has adverse consequences for someone, that person usually expects you to do something about it, as we would expect. Or, some form of equivalent trade response may be taken against us. It is not trade sanctions in the sense that we understand it in relation to apartheid in South Africa. It is not that sort of trade sanction. They may withdraw some of the benefits that were offered to us under the GATT, say a tariff reduction that was offered on zinc, or market access offers to Australia that were made that operate under the World Trade Organisation may be withdrawn.

So those are the sorts of sanctions that are available. Nobody would wish them to happen; it is not World War Three. It is something that we would not wish to happen, as we would not wish to be found consciously and deliberately to have breached an agreement into which we knowingly entered. I think that is the same circumstance that a citizen would expect to be in with regard to an agreement into which he or she entered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the minister may have made a very important point. It is that all the countries that enter into this agreement are free to set whatever conditions of entry on goods coming into their country that they wish, which is consistent with the fact that they are sovereign nations. My understanding of the minister's point is that they agree, by going into the World Trade Organisation, to restrict the conditions of entry, in exchange for which other countries offer them similar access; that if they successfully obtain a declaration that a country is in breach of that obligation to them, then they are free to exercise within the realms of their own sovereignty the limitation of a right of entry on goods coming from the country in breach.

PARA.TAB: Is that the case, minister, and is that therefore consistent with the fact that each country is capable within the limits of its own sovereignty to act as it wishes and that the agreement is really a concessionary arrangement, rather than an international restriction on a country's sovereignty? Is that the case?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct. That is not a bad summary.

—(6.01 p.m.)—Minister, in regard to the bill before us and the other bills that are going to be before us, is it not the case that we, as a member of the World Trade Organisation, will not have available to us the ability to distinguish the means by which a good is produced?

—That is not exactly right, but there are some limitations on our capacity to distinguish between products. Each country that enters into the agreement has agreed that it will not use its tax system to discriminate directly or indirectly—that is not the formal wording of the agreement, but that is the impact of it—against the products of other countries.

PARA.TAB: We do not want other countries to pass laws that will prevent our citrus growers from being able to sell their products to other countries. The exports of citrus by Australia is very important for the future of that industry and if it were possible for countries, within their tax system, to discriminate and say, `The tax on oranges from country X will be five per cent, but the taxes on Australian oranges will be 50 per cent,' we would lose. We do not want them to be able to do that, and we do not want them to be able to do it by some ruse by which they pretend to be distinguishing on some other basis when they are in fact discriminating against imports. We have in the past objected to people doing that to us, so we have entered into an agreement by which we constrain our right to discriminate against others. That is what happens in agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, if a local council were to implement a by-law which prevented it council from purchasing timber which is produced in a rainforest area because it is against the principles of the council to use that timber, would that by-law be GATT inconsistent?
—If people said that they would not allow rainforest timber from whatever source to be used, I cannot see that that would be GATT inconsistent.

—Is it not true that it is not possible to distinguish like products on the basis of production? For instance, if there were a choice between timber that was created in a plantation and like timber that had been obtained from a rainforest, and if a local council were to implement a by-law which said that it would not allow the purchase of timber that was obtained from a rainforest, how could that be, considering like products are not able to be distinguished under the Uruguay Round of GATT?

—There is nothing that I am aware of that would lead to that conclusion, although I am checking to confirm that. There is a trade and environment committee of the World Trade Organisation—that is one of the things that distinguishes it from GATT, which did not deal with those matters—and it is properly looking at how we reconcile the legitimate international concern about environment issues with the legitimate international concern about trade issues. At this stage we do not think that anybody would succeed in an appeal to the WTO because of a shire council by-law of the type to which Senator Margetts refers—that is if anybody ever found out about it.

PARA.TAB: Although I think the proposal is a bit absurd, there is a legitimate core concern—which is, I think, what is motivating Senator Margetts—not to see the interpretation of international trade measures undermine the capacity of countries effectively to protect their environment or to implement international environmental agreements into which they have entered. We do not want to see that any more than we want to see an interpretation of environmental agreements in some way misused to cut across legitimate economic purposes. Misuse of one at the cost of the other is not something we would wish to see.

That is why the WTO has established a committee on trade and the environment. There are legitimate concerns to be pursued there. I do not think the example is a good one. I reiterate that it has nothing to do with the bill before us—but it is a cause of continuing concern that will need to be addressed. Sooner or later, however, we will have to deal with the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the two members of the council who came to see me yesterday with this particular concern were to go to the minister, would they be able to get an assurance from him that they could go ahead with this action and that it would not be GATT inconsistent?
—I have no idea of the facts of the particular case but the citizens are welcome to come and see me. I will cross that bridge when I come to it.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Margetts's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. After clause 3, page 2, insert the following clause:
"3A. Schedule 1 of the Principal Act is amended:

TAB.TAB: (a)by inserting the following item after Item 71 in the Table of Contents:
`71A. Not-from-concentrate juices'
(b)by inserting the following Item after Item 71:
`Item 71A: [Not-from-concentrate juices]

SPEECH.PARA: Beverages consisting of not less than 100% by volume of fruit or vegetable juices not made from concentrates.'.".

This amendment removes sales tax from `not from concentrate' fruit juice—that is, fresh juice. The bill as it stands removes from Australian citrus growers—and they are the ones mainly affected—the concessional tax rate which has applied so far to juice which contains at least 25 per cent local content. The evidence that the committee has had from the industry shows quite clearly that hundreds, if not thousands, of citrus growers will go out of business in this situation.

PARA.TAB: We have had a long history of imports of frozen orange juice from Brazil at a fraction of the cost that our growers—and our growers are efficient—can produce their fruit. We have had a history where Australia has successively reduced tariff protection against Brazilian orange juice. We are now at 10 per cent, reducing to five per cent, whereas the United States has retained its protection at around 47 per cent. The tariff protection in place can be retained so the United States will be able to continue to protect its orange growers. Australia has reduced its tariff protection and under the GATT agreement, which Australia has agreed to, we are not able to retain the concessional tax rate. This is the reason for the government's removal in this particular bill.

Having received the evidence before the committee and having talked to the organisations of the citrus growers who are concerned with the survival of their industry, it is clear that, at a cost of revenue of, say, $20 million, measured against, as the minister has said previously, $4 billion, we can ensure that the citrus growing industry in Australia does not fall victim to this particular arrangement.

The government has offered a package of $9 million over a number of years. It is quite clear that these funds, which are to be used to generate and increase export activity, will assist some growers, mainly medium and large growers, but they will not assist the small growers who are battling on their 10, 20 or 30 acre lots.

It has been said that the industry should rationalise; that these people, in other words, should get off the land. The committee has received evidence from a representative of the organisation Women in Horticulture that this process will not be easy, that it will be at the cost of unemployment, marriage breakups, suicides and a range of social ills and dislocation in the rural community. I wonder whether the government in its calculations has, in fact, allowed for those social costs in the Riverland and in the Sunraysia district. Is it really aware of what the costs will be? Does it think that $9 million over a number of years of export assistance will overcome all these problems?

The Australian Democrats are approaching this in an extremely responsible way. We are saying that we welcome the benefits of $4 billion to the primary industries across Australia and we do not wish to damage this prospect. However, there are obvious losers and we want to make sure that these losers do not finish up being the ones carrying the can for the government. This amendment is one that the government, the Liberal Party and certainly the National Party should support. Senator Boswell should lead his National Party colleagues into supporting this particular amendment, if the National Party's commitment to its country constituents means anything at all.

We have heard the evidence. Senator Boswell was at the meeting and we all were at the committee meetings. We know what will be the effects on the industry of the amendments the government has in its bill. This amendment I am moving on behalf of the Australian Democrats will assist that industry to survive and will help overcome some of the social disadvantages which will inevitably follow. If this amendment is rejected, I am offering to senators an alternative amendment on the same sheet which will remove sales tax from both fresh juice and frozen orange juice concentrate. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler's amendment—

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. I did not want to interrupt Senator Margetts. I am sorry; I meant to rise before. I just wondered if, procedurally, we can expedite things without restricting anybody's rights. Senator Spindler has an alternate amendment and Senator Margetts has a very similar amendment. When I say `similar' I mean it is about the same issues. Obviously, they need to be voted on separately, but I wonder whether, with your leave, we could debate all the amendments in the one debate. Then it saves the parliament having two debates.
—No. They are different amendments.

—I understand they are different amendments. I understand they need to be voted on separately, but the issues are fundamentally the same. It seems to me that the chamber wants to have one debate—not two. If nobody will cooperate with that, so be it. I suggest that we might see whether the chamber would agree to that proposal. If it does not, we will proceed in the normal way. I am quite prepared to participate in that debate.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Childs)—Is there agreement to a cognate discussion on the amendments?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, there is no agreement. Senator Spindler's amendment is the first opportunity that the government will have of putting itself on the line with respect to what is GATT consistent and what is GATT inconsistent. There are two choices: the first is to be able to listen to the concerns of the industry and be able to find in favour of the industry; the second is to say, `No, we can't do this because we're not allowed to do it under GATT,' which relates to a decision based on whether or not we should buy orange juice in a frozen concentrated form with mostly water added from overseas or whether we should pay the same price for fresh juice that is produced from oranges grown locally.

PARA.TAB: This is the first opportunity that the government will have to put itself on the line to say whether or not we have lost the ability to operate on behalf of the industry, health, commonsense and ecological sustainability. Sending oranges halfway around the world in a frozen form is not ecologically sustainable, especially when one considers that the source of most of this frozen concentrated orange juice is an area that has been ripped out of the Brazilian rainforest. The people who are benefiting from the ripping out of the Brazilian rainforests are generally multinational corporations from America and Europe.

We are saying to our small farmers that what we are hoping for under the World Trade Organisation is much more important than being able to make any differential on the basis of how a product is made or whether it is right to not be able to distinguish between products that destroy the ecosystem and leave the benefits in fewer and fewer hands. This is the first opportunity that the government will have of putting any principles on the line and clearly outlining what we are getting into with this new agreement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on Senator Spindler's amendment. I have some sympathy for the citrus growers who will be affected by the Sales Tax (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill. As I said in my speech during the second reading debate this morning, the National and Liberal parties have been placed between a rock and a hard place. If we try to amend the bills in some way and hold up the legislation, then we put at risk the $1 billion worth of trade advantages that Australia will get.

PARA.TAB: The NFF has asked that these bills go through speedily. If we hold the legislation up, then we could be putting at risk huge trade advantages for the whole of the agricultural industry throughout Australia. It could affect wheat, wool, beef and many other industries. The fact is that a $9 million package—or $15 million over five years—is not very successful. Some of the smaller industries have not received the compensation benefits that they deserve.

As I pointed out in my speech this morning, in Japan—a wealthy country but one which is not a big agricultural producer—the government of the day compensated its farmers with a package of $83 billion. When we compare this figure with that received by the smaller industries in Australia, we see that it is not a great deal.

I have sympathy with Senator Spindler's amendment, but I do not see how we could put at risk this huge trade benefit to agriculture. I hoped that the government would have given a compensation package of around $40 million. That would have allowed the citrus producers to take out the valencia trees and change over to navels. This would have given them access to the whole fruit market, which is opening up. It would have enabled them to remove the trees. I think it takes seven or eight years for new trees to produce. I would have thought that $40 million was an adequate compensation package. But $15 million over five years is not going to get anyone out of trouble.

All I can say is that I am very sorry that the citrus industry in particular—the tobacco industry will probably get some relief, not so much from the government package but through an agreement between the manufacturers and the growers—did not get a package that was much higher than the $15 million that was given.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the remarks of my colleague Senator Boswell. We on this side of the chamber are concerned about the situation in the citrus industry. I will not go over the arguments. Most of us raised them in some shape or form in our contributions to the second reading debate.

PARA.TAB: Like Senator Boswell, I have a certain sympathy with the general thrust of Senator Spindler's argument, but the coalition thinks that the prime aim must be to get these bills through the parliament in order to meet our obligations. More importantly, it will provide us with the opportunities that the World Trade Organisation agreement gives us. So we will not be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendment. I wanted to put those comments on the record to remind the chamber of the remarks made by coalition speakers in the second reading debate in relation to the citrus industry.

I would like to put a question to the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), although it does not relate specifically to the bill. It relates to the government's plans for the taxation write-off of expenditure on new horticultural plantations. It is a matter involving the Income Tax Assessment Act rather than the Sales Tax Act. There is a lack of clarity in the government's proposals.

I ask this question on behalf of the coalition, particularly Senator McMullan's good friend Senator Watson. I refer to the write-off of new horticultural plantations that has been announced. The government has also said that there are complex issues that still have to be resolved. I ask some important questions which I do not think ought to be held up by the complexity of the issue. Firstly, does the write-off mean that growers will get the deduction in the year in which the expenditure is incurred? If they will not get it in full in the year in which it is incurred, how many years write-off are envisaged? Secondly, is the write-off provision planned to be a permanent provision or a transitional provision?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should Senator Short be the only person to ask a question that does relate to the bill? It is very relevant. Because the support of the opposition for the legislation is not contingent on this, I will get the information to Senator Short and Senator Watson in writing, but my clear recollection and understanding of the cabinet decision is that it was endorsed in principle, with the detail to be worked out by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins). I do not think that level of detail has been finalised. If there is anything to add, I will get a written advice to Senator Short and Senator Watson.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the amendment and its impact has been outlined by others, so I will not waste the time of the committee duplicating that. One thing to remember with regard to the situation in the citrus industry is that as well as negatives there are pluses for it in this Uruguay Round. There are export opportunities opening up and I think more will open up as a consequence of the accession of new countries to the World Trade Organisation. It is not a one-way street. There are pluses as well as minuses. We cannot get all the pluses without the minuses.

That goes to Senator Spindler's point. While we disagree about the detail, I accept the principle that, when we enter into an agreement from which the overwhelming majority benefit but there are some who are disadvantaged, the majority have an obligation to use some of the proceeds to assist those who may have been disadvantaged. I do not disagree with the principle. We diverge on how we ought to implement that principle. It is a matter of public policy, not a matter particularly relating to the World Trade Organisation, and as such it is a reasonable premise from which to start. It is not always capable of being implemented, for all sorts of reasons, but it is not a bad premise.

That is what underpins the package of support that the government outlined and which Senator Boswell and others referred to. That support will be implemented over the years. If at the next election the opposition and other parties want to put forward a proposal that the package should be doubled, trebled or more, then it is up to the voters. If they choose that and they get elected to implement that, then the compensation package which we have outlined will be enhanced by the new government. That is the way the democratic process works. The government thinks that the package it has put up is reasonable. Whatever one's views about the rest of the WTO are, it is a sovereign decision for the government to decide how much money it is going to spend on certain compensation packages.

Senator Sherry spoke articulately about the problems of the industry and why the sales tax concession measures were pursued. This is in addition to the problems with the GATT—and I am not going to shy away from that—and in addition to the revenue implications. Both of those issues are serious.
