He put the case better than I can because he has been so closely involved with the industry. While the wish behind Senator Spindler's amendment is to assist the citrus industry, it does not go very far to solving any of the problems the industry has. A very small actual increase will flow to the growers out of a very substantial cost to the revenue, assessed at $24 million. That is of the order that Senator Spindler speculated. It is difficult to be too precise, but the best estimate the government can make is that it will be about $24 million.

There are three problems. The government thinks it is a measure that does not really address the problems confronting the industry. The government believes the industry would be much better off taking advantage of its compensation package and those sales tax measures which it has undertaken. Senator Harradine was talking about increasing the revenue from orange juice. We anticipate that this package of measures will reduce the amount of sales tax we get on various forms of orange juice because some of it is taxed now and some is not. The rate is going down for that which is currently taxed and the government's assessment is that the revenue from orange juice and related products will go down, not up.

I do not shy away from those two serious revenue concerns. It is a very difficult time to be talking about reducing the revenue. It is a difficult time to be talking about increasing expenditure, but the government has proposed some. The government does not think the amendment addresses the serious problems confronting the industry. We think the adjustment package we are talking about will better position it for a long-term viable future as an industry. But, quite clearly, there is a problem with the consistency of what is proposed in the agreement into which we have entered. The government's obligation is that there should be no less favourable treatment of like foreign and domestic goods in the administration of internal taxes and charges.

That is a principle that the government has sought to have applied to others in the past and therefore needs consistently to apply it to ourselves even when it is uncomfortable. We cannot have all the pluses and not accept that the same principles need to apply to us. I freely and directly address the fact that one of the constraints upon our capacity to do this is the constraint imposed by the nature of the agreement into which we are seeking to enter through this legislation. We think it is probably not the right way to go even if that were not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was adverting to the government's horticultural task force which recommended that `not from concentrate' orange juice be exempted from sales tax to encourage growth of the fresh juice sector. It is only a debating point. I do not know whether I actually said—
—If I misheard you, I am sorry. I thought that is what you said.

—I do not rise for that purpose and I apologise to the committee and the Minister for Trade if this question has been asked, but he would know that a motion of the Senate took us away from this very vital debate to another committee. Is it the government's view that fresh fruit juice is a food? If so, does that mean that there is a tax being applied to food?

—We could have a metaphysical debate about whether it is food, but I understand Senator Harradine's point: in terms of the sales tax legislation, is it food? Beverages have always been in a different category—not only alcoholic beverages but also carbonated drinks and so on. The government considers it more comparable with those products than with bread, so it has proceeded accordingly. It will be taxed at a lower rate than those other drinks.
—Are tea, coffee and milk—
—They are exceptions. They do not have a side effect.
—They do not have a sales tax, do they?
—No, they do not.

—I do not think we can let the coalition parties get away quite as easily as they have tried to do, saying that they do not want to hold up the bills. If the coalition parties, the National and Liberal parties, were to support this amendment, it would be passed. The House of Representatives is coming back next week. There would be no hold-up. The bill could proceed with that amendment intact. Our citrus industry would be saved. On the basis of orange juice being classified as a food, the argument that the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) is putting forward that it is not GATT friendly does not stand up. So I do not see why the coalition parties should be allowed to get away with the excuse that the bill cannot be held up.

PARA.TAB: I would like to ask the minister two questions. One of them is: what exactly are the problems of the industry? Does the minister say that there are too many smallholdings and that therefore this is one way of getting rid of them and getting people off the land? If that is the case, so far they have been able to subsist. They have been able to fight their way through, despite protection rates that are much higher in other countries than our own. We have arrived at five per cent now. The United States is 40 per cent plus. Brazil is 35 per cent. Israel is 120 per cent. South Africa is 20 per cent. Japan is 25.5 per cent. Yet we cannot find a way to ensure that our citrus industry continues.

I would like the minister to address the following: what exactly are the problems and how does he propose to address them? Am I right in saying that the argument is that we have too many smallholdings and we need to get rid of them, we need to rationalise the industry? The other question is: how much government revenue will flow into the government's coffers from the $4 billion worth of extra exports or extra benefits that the government has said will be the result for the primary industries, mainly, under the GATT package?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a short contribution on the citrus industry. There is no doubt that we are aware of the benefits of GATT. We are told that some $700 to $800 billion annually will be pumped into the world trading market and that Australia will make gains of about $2.5 billion. It is very much a wait and see situation as to whether those figures will be brought home, but there is no doubt that Australia does under the theory have comparative advantages, particularly in primary industry. I think of the beef industry, which we are told will benefit the most. But there are industries at the same time that are not helped by GATT in its most pure form.

PARA.TAB: There is doubt the citrus industry is one such industry. It needs help, and the package is unsatisfactory. A measly $9 million is going towards the restructuring, the market diversification, of the industry and it is just not enough, particularly as the industry has the potential, I am told, of some $1 billion to $2 billion in the export market. So the government has failed the citrus industry and, again, the many family farmers. But it will be very quick to tax them by way of fuel tax. Even the mooted wealth tax is back on the agenda in the upcoming budget.

More is needed to support this industry, and the government has failed. It sent Senator Sherry out on a two-year excursion around the industry. Senator Sherry did a good job. But the government has not taken up his recommendation for a zero sales tax for this industry, which was the preferred position. In cabinet it has treated him like the office boy. Senator Sherry's career has taken a severe setback. He must feel that he has wasted his time on that committee.

I have a question for the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan). Was he a friend of Senator Sherry's inside cabinet? We have an industry now that will be brought to its knees because the government package is not satisfactory. Why did the minister not help Senator Sherry, give him a kick along? Truly he has wasted his time over the last two years, or however long this committee has been going around the countryside. He has been making a good fellow of himself but he has not been able to deliver. He should not think that he can ever turn up to the citrus areas again, because he has been a great disappointment. It is not his fault; he has been treated like the office boy.

We are in a difficult situation. Senator Spindler knows that the party I represent that holds the seat of Mallee in Victoria has great difficulty in supporting the GATT bills under this form, but we know that under the principle of GATT there is a chance for primary industry to benefit as a whole. We are not walking away from the citrus industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the losers? They are the losers. Why don't you help them?

—They are going to be sadly affected by the government's package because it just does not shape up. That is why it is essential that this side of the house get into government because that is when the real changes can be made.
—You won't do that on this basis, if you don't vote for this.

—I do not want to talk about your performance when it comes to tax. As Andrew Peacock once said, as sure as night follows day, fuel taxes will be on the agenda in the next budget. I would like to get a commitment from the Democrats that they will not support an increase in the fuel taxes that will help the citrus industry.
—It is an essential part of their policy.

—So I am told. So there are contradictions all around. But Senator Spindler can rest assured that the coalition is not going to walk away from those industries that will be affected by GATT. We will be monitoring the situation closely. I would hope the government would monitor it closely. I would hope within six months or 12 months it would give some commitment to review this package to see if it is enough because we can be sure that it is not. Will the minister make a commitment to review this package within the next 12 months?

—I will respond firstly to Senator Spindler's points but in the process try to pick up what Senator McGauran said. In opening I shall respond to one thing that Senator McGauran said. I understand the frustrations of life as a parliamentary secretary. It is a matter in which I have some personal expertise. I am sure Senator Sherry would prefer life to be otherwise and I am very confident that after the next election for him it will be. But he has done an excellent job. Let me deal with Senator McGauran's questions first now that I have got halfway into it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry will be chairing a task force continuing to look at these issues. So we will not be waiting 12 months. The task force will be set up. As a result of the cabinet's decision, Senator Sherry will be chairing it and it will have an ongoing brief to look at the implementation of the package. It is not on the basis that we expect him to come back to cabinet in 12 months needing some further change, because we do not think that will be the case. But there is a task force and if it finds that circumstances have changed he, through the minister for primary industry, has the capacity to respond to it.

Let me not pretend, in response to Senator Spindler's question, that I come before you as the world's expert on the citrus industry or the government's expert on the industry. The package and the elements that have been chosen fundamentally have been driven by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) and his parliamentary secretary in consultation with the Treasurer (Mr Willis), and that is as it should be. So I do not bring these bills forward in the sense that I am the world's expert on the citrus industry. Senator Sherry said it better than I could. In terms of a serious response, I would suggest to those who wish to pursue that that they should have a look at his speech in the second reading debate.

The concern that I was referring to when I said that this did not meet the major problem is that this is an industry that is highly—perhaps we should say excessively—dependent on the domestic juice sector, and the sales tax concessions which might lead it to focus even more on this sector actually lead it in the wrong direction. That is what we mean when we say that the tax concession does not solve the problem. It is not to do with how many people are in the industry, or whatever.

Senator Sherry spoke about those sorts of issues; he has expertise in that area. That was not the matter to which I was referring when I spoke about the major problems. I was trying to be brief, and that is why I did not go into detail. It is not possible to assess the revenue implications for the Australian government of the WTO package, but it is incontrovertible that if it adds to economic growth and incomes are therefore higher the government's tax revenue will be higher. Without trying to put a number on it, it is incontrovertibly true that that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow up some comments made by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan). The minister has just said that the citrus industry is excessively dependent on the domestic juice sector. In giving evidence to the committee, the industry indicated that that is the nub of the problem in that, as a result of these changes to the trade arrangements, we will find that the juicing industry in Australia will all but disappear. That will be with the exception of companies such as Sunburst which, in order to make the most of the capital that it has recently invested in Australia, will continue to use the juice from Australian growers. I wonder whether that situation will last until the capital needs replacing and whether that part of the industry will then go. Basically, it looks like the juicing sector of the Australian citrus industry will go down the toilet, apart from those companies which, to make the most of recent capital investment, will continue to use it until they are either bought out or find that they need to replace that capital; and then perhaps they will make other decisions.

PARA.TAB: It was recognised during the committee hearing that we cannot compete with the juice prices of the Brazilian industry. For the reasons that have been mentioned, the Brazilian industry is a capital intensive industry. The labour it uses is a great deal cheaper than Australian labour, and it uses land in a very unsustainable way. It is using the land as a resource that can be depleted. That is the price that we are paying for this particular thing.

The exports that we are talking about are largely exports of whole oranges, and that is a limited portion of the market. The imports that we are talking about are the value added component of industry, that is, the fruit juice. So that is the scenario we are talking about. I did not think that was the way Australian industry was meant to be going—taking action that destroys our value added industry and places greater reliance on primary industry.

Another issue relates to the nature of the changes. It is important that we realise that these changes will basically change the industry forever. I was quite saddened to see that there are still people in the citrus industry who feel that taking out trees within their industry will enable the prices to go up sufficiently so that the rest of the people in the industry will be able to survive. From their point of view, I would like to believe that that was the truth but, sadly, because products such as fruit juice will now be priced internationally rather than domestically, the ability to remove trees within the industry to push up the price will not be there in the same way that it was before. So pulling out the trees simply means that those people who are left become more and more marginal if they are trying to produce for the fruit juice market.

I am very sorry to see that the government is endorsing a situation which will inevitably lead to the situation where we have a small industry which perhaps produces export oranges, with some for the local market—but even fewer, because a number of growers grow for both. A lot of the oranges we buy when we go to our local fruit and vegetable shop are actually from dual growers—growers that grow for both purposes. So, in reality, whereas in recent times it has been frequently very difficult for me as a consumer to buy locally produced oranges, it will become more and more difficult to do that in Australia if the juicing sector is damaged in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister did not answer one of my questions. He said it is very difficult to estimate the revenue that the government could obtain from some $4 billion additional benefit from sales that could accrue to the primary industries. I think it would be a fair assumption that about 30 per cent of that would become government revenue. The minister is shaking his head.
—Much less.
—Twenty per cent, $1 billion?
—We tax the profit, not the income. There will be income.

—I am not particularly fussed whether it is $1 billion or $1.5 billion or what, but it is of that order. In this amendment we are talking about $24 million. Yet the government is not prepared to support that amendment. Let me read a letter from Mr Ron George, one of the citrus growers along the River Murray, who says:

SPEECH.PARA: My long time ambition has been to develop a citrus property on the River Murray as a retirement plan. I have invested all of my available income in this venture, only to find imported juice concentrates are making this difficult. This has taken my wife and I 20 years to have what we believe is our wonderful retirement future. . . We have no wish to rely on a pension, but to continue working to help Australia and ourselves.
A letter from Mr Shaun Whitworth states:

The 900 Riverland citrus growers I represent underpin the working efforts of 6930 Australians, most of whom live in the region. That is, twenty one percent of the total Riverland population and forty-four percent of the regional workforce. . . Without the tax exemption, the Riverland could expect to contribute over three hundred growers [to those forced out of the industry], so threatening the living of over 2500 workers.

I think this sort of evidence that the committee received surely must make the government sit up and take notice. When we look at the disparity of revenue, when we look at the future of citrus growers, we realise that the export efforts are going to be hampered on two fronts. A high proportion, or a reasonable proportion at least, of oranges are not of the quality that can be exported as fruit, so there will always be, no matter where a grower is or how efficient a grower is, some that will need to be sold for juice or be left to rot. Alternatively, if a grower is going to export juice, the grower will be met by the Brazilian competition.

PARA.TAB: I put it to the chamber that the government's position of spending $9 million over five years to develop an export industry for citrus growers is really not terribly realistic. As the industry has shown and has said, it does not help those growers who are now being forced to the wall. I ask the minister to reconsider, in view of this evidence, the position the government is taking and to consider supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government conducted a long review and made an informed decision. None of the facts which Senator Spindler raises are new.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—I remind Senator McKiernan that as long as I am in the chair I expect jackets to be worn in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. After clause 3, page 2, insert the following clause:
"3A. Schedule 1 of the Principal Act is amended:

TAB.TAB: (a)by inserting the following Item after Item 71 in the Table of Contents:
"71A. Pure juices"
(b)by inserting the following Item after Item 71:

SPEECH.PARA: `Item 71A: [Pure juices]
Beverages consisting of not less than 100% by volume of fruit or vegetable juices.'.".

This amendment is an alternative which might be easier for everyone to support because it is GATT friendly. It does not make any distinction between fresh orange juice and orange juice concentrate. We are suggesting that the sales tax should be removed right across the board. We are told by the citrus growers that this would still give them some assistance because they can market their fresh orange juice as a product. Everybody would agree that it is health giving and far superior to the products made from concentrate.

PARA.TAB: While this second amendment is certainly a second best alternative—the growers would have preferred my first amendment—they think that it would still enable most of them to survive. I call yet again on the National Party and the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Senator Boswell, to rethink their position. I note that Senator Boswell is present in the chamber. I am sure he is now thinking very hard about his responsibility and his party's responsibility to orange growers and to people in rural Australia. This provides a good benchmark with regard to the government's attitude and the coalition's attitude to people in the country who are being pushed around because the government thinks we need to join GATT, without looking at the consequences and without compensating the losers.

I place on record again the fact that we are not against GATT. We are mindful of the benefits that are to be gained by primary industries—$4 billion, we are told, a substantial amount of which will go into government revenue. Yet apparently the government cannot spend some money out of that revenue to compensate the losers. We thought these things should have been discussed before; they should be discussed now. The bill should be deferred until we are perfectly clear as to what damage the government is doing to people in the country.

I repeat: we are not against GATT. This amendment gives the government and the coalition parties another chance. We are suggesting that sales tax should be removed from beverages which are 100 per cent, by volume, fruit or vegetable juices. I commend the amendment to the committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that this is exactly the same amendment that was moved last time.
—No, it is second best, but it is still a good amendment.

—Let me reiterate what I said last time: Senator Spindler has said that he is not against GATT. The fact is that whether we like it or not—and I do not—the amendment that Senator Spindler has moved is not supportive of GATT. In fact, it is GATT-illegal. If he wants to move GATT-illegal amendments, he is putting at risk, in his own words, $4 billion worth of trade and $1 billion worth of primary industry trade. I have a great deal of sympathy for Senator Spindler's view—I have even raised it—that we should block these bills until the government gives a decent compensation package to the citrus industry. But if I did that, I would be exposing every wool grower, every wheat grower, every beef grower, every navy bean grower and just about every primary producer other than those in the citrus industry.

PARA.TAB: I said that the National Party was caught between a rock and a hard place. We are. We have the greatest sympathy for the citrus industry, but we have nowhere to go. If we help the citrus industry, we blow the rest of the primary industry out of the water. That is the position that we are in. If we crossed the floor to support Senator Spindler's amendment, we would be putting our GATT obligation at risk. Every farmer would rise up against you.

I support a decent adjustment package. I have said time and again that the citrus industry has not been looked after; the tobacco industry has not been looked after. They have made great contributions over the years but now they are being neglected. There is nowhere for us to go. If we block the bills, we could put our world trade obligations at risk. The beef growers, and most primary industries apart from the tobacco growers and the citrus growers, would be very annoyed with us. There is a benefit to Australia of $1 billion a year in primary products and I believe there is $4 billion a year in secondary industry benefit. Therefore, the government should have compensated the losers and guaranteed that the winners gained access to this large world trade market. But what it has done is to give guarantees to the winners without compensating the losers. I am at a loss as to where we go from here. I have sympathy for the 2,500 to 3,000 primary producers of the citrus industry. I feel great sympathy for them, but if I try to help them I will wipe out the other 100,000 primary producers.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—Yes, I do, but I will wipe out 100,000 primary producers. I will have the Cattlemen's Union up against me. I will have the UGA up against me. I will have the wool industry against me.
—The wheat growers.

—I will have the wheat farmers against me. I am here to help as many people as I can. As I have said before, I would love to help the citrus industry. But if the government wants to do this and thinks it will get great benefits out of it, it will get annihilated out in the bush because no primary producer that wants access to that world market, that needs access to that world market, is going to thank it. No-one in the sugar or beef industries is going to thank Senator Kernot.

PARA.TAB: Senator Woodley is being misled. I know that he has great sympathy for these industries but he is being misled by his colleague Senator Spindler and he is not helping Queensland primary industry at all. In fact, he is exposing it to a great loss of markets. Having said that, I will not speak again but I put the National Party position firmly on the table. I believe that Senator Spindler's actions are not helping anyone.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should respond to that speech by the Leader of the National Party in the Senate (Senator Boswell) because it comes from his heart. Everyone will notice he did not read one note. He really meant what he was saying. The problem is that it is not me who is being misled, unfortunately. I want to paint a scenario for Senator Boswell. Under GATT, we have many promises. However, under the present situation in Australia we have GATT forcing industries to go down the tube industry by industry. It was the tobacco industry last week. It is the citrus industry this week. Next week, according to Ian MacFarlane of the grain growers in Queensland, GATT may bring some benefits but if they come out even he will be satisfied. I think people like the grain growers are starting to get nervous.
—That's not true, and you know it.

—It certainly is true. I quoted the exact words of the president of the Queensland grain growers to me. I thank Senator Kemp for his interjection. I needed to clarify that for him because he sometimes does not understand the things I say. I want to put on the record that our primary industry is disappearing industry by industry. We need to draw a line in the sand.
—That's nonsense—absolute nonsense.
—Oh, I see. The citrus industry is not going to disappear with this.
—No, you said the industry is disappearing—the primary industry and our wheat markets.
—No, I said the primary industry is disappearing industry by industry. It was the tobacco industry last week. It was the citrus industry this week. Which one will it be next week?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very important to rectify some of the misconceptions that Senator Boswell appears to have. First of all, he says that if that amendment were passed it would in some way endanger the GATT bills. But it will not. If that amendment were passed right now, and since the House of Representatives is back in Canberra next week, that amendment could be incorporated in the bill. The bill would be passed and we would accede to GATT in January.

PARA.TAB: There is really no problem. We need to be quite clear about that. The Australian Democrats are not about stopping Australia's participation in GATT. We want to have our participation on fair grounds. We want to make sure that the conditions we are party to are well known, that we know the consequences. If the consequences adversely affect certain sectors of the population, certain

SPEECH.PARA: sectors of the community, they should be either compensated or allowed to survive.

TALK.START.PARA: —But properly compensated. I totally agree with you.

—Senator Boswell may not wish to allow them to survive, he may only want to have them compensated. But, in this particular case, we have a budget figure of approximately $44 million, somewhat higher than the previous one, that would assist citrus growers to survive. That is against a benefit to the Australian community of $4 billion. We want to ensure that it really arrives and that it helps the Australian economy and Australian industries. That is not the argument, as Senator Kemp and Senator Boswell tried to insinuate before. That is not the argument. We are supporting them. We simply want to make sure that what is being done is being done fairly and that the people who are addressed, who are the losers, are compensated.

PARA.TAB: The other point that was made by Senator Boswell is that this is not valid under GATT, or not permissible under GATT. That is not so. We have legal advice—I am happy to provide it to Senator Boswell and I will get the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, to confirm it—that if this amendment were passed it would be GATT legal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler said that the Australian Democrats were not against GATT. I draw to his attention a statement by Senator Coulter in the 1993 Hansard on page 1167. He said of GATT:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the 1993 equivalent of the 1893 gunboats to China; gunboats to force Chinese trade into the hegemony of European dominance. If it is less physically violent, it is nonetheless the instrument by which the economically powerful seek to dominate and exploit the weak, to dispossess them of their resources and to ensure the unimpeded penetration of the products of rich nations into the markets of the poor.

And Senator Spindler stands up here and says that the Democrats support GATT! It is very well for Senator Spindler to stand up and seek, in a grubby way, to pretend to rural producers and the citrus people that he is their friend. I point out to anyone who reads this Hansard that it was Senator Spindler and his colleagues who supported and encouraged a massive rise in fuel prices after the last election—7c a litre—which raised well over $1 billion, much of it coming from the rural sector.

PARA.TAB: It was Senator Spindler who encouraged the government to bring in superannuation levies, which hit citrus producers and everybody else, and training guarantee levies. He urged the government to forgo its tax cuts, which it largely did at the income tax level. The government's leader is now out encouraging further tax rises on industry and telling the government, `Bring in your increased taxes.' The Democrats will be out there supporting that.

Senator Spindler is very selective. When the products of the citrus growers were held up in the recent airport strike, no-one had access to 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. Does Senator Spindler know why? It was because his party supported the removal of 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. So whether we are looking at industrial relations, tax policy or rural policy and live sheep exports, I can tell Senator Spindler that the Democrats cannot hold their heads up in rural Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already spoken on this matter and tackled Senator Spindler's challenge on the National Party and, for that matter, the coalition. So, in the words of many politicians, I will be brief. I have to disagree with my leader, Senator Boswell, on one point, which is that the Democrats will be annihilated on this matter and will not be thanked in the bush. They have never been thanked in the bush, and they have always been annihilated in the bush. Anything they may trump up in the late nights in the Senate will never receive thanks by those in the bush. As Senator Kemp pointed out, people in the bush have not forgotten—and we will never let them forget—the increase in petrol taxes, because that has done more harm than anything.
—What about live sheep?

—One could go on and on about what the Democrats have done. Imagine the tractor going up the citrus road collecting the fruit with the diesel and petrol and the extra taxes the Democrats have burdened upon growers. I challenge the Democrats on their point that the National Party does not understand the damage that is being done in the bush. The National Party represents the true rural seats in Australia. We happen to represent the poorest of all metropolitan and rural seats in Australia. We know only too well, because we are at the coalface, of the hurt that they have faced under this government and due to natural causes such as the drought. We know exactly how those people are suffering and hurting.

PARA.TAB: Today is GATT day in the Senate. The GATT bills have to go through. There is no doubt that we have terrible difficulties, but, on the whole, we want the GATT bills to go through on time. But, if we think we have difficulties, I imagine that a few United States congressmen and United States senators from the Midwest are having similar difficulties at this point. One has to take the whole of GATT; one cannot just pick and choose.

Many politicians in many parliaments around the world have had to make certain compromises for the good. We are not turning our back on the citrus industry. There is a chance down the track to further support it by urging the government, in the strongest terms, to increase that package. I have already had a commitment from the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) that within six to 12 months the government will review the package. That will be the time to push the government on. I hope that Senator Spindler is still around when that occurs.

Again, for the record, the National Party has not turned itself away. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics estimates that Australia can expect to receive an extra $330 million in beef exports, which is a rural industry; $210 million in dairy products; $320 million in wheat; $50 million in coarse grains; $30 million in rice; and $10 million in sugar and so on. They are the benefits that we can look forward to. GATT is very much a case of wait and see. If those benefits do not come through, we will return to this parliament and support the citrus growers. We will not see them pack up and leave their districts without raising it in this parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the moment, the citrus growers, if they are basically considered to be collateral damage on the basis of trying to win the bigger war, will feel very betrayed. If, after the prescribed time—we have to wait seven years for this $1 billion—we find that the industries that are making sacrifices so that they can get benefits are not getting those benefits, what will governments say? They will say that circumstances have changed and so on. There will not be time to save those people whom we have considered to be acceptable damage in the meantime.

PARA.TAB: As I have mentioned before, a number of people have already suffered as a result of the changes that have occurred in preparation for a naive approach to negotiations. A number of industries have suffered. Basically, those people will feel extremely betrayed if they have been considered to be collateral damage for some benefits that do not actually occur. That is what I felt very deeply when I heard the people who gave evidence to that hearing.

The Greens will be supporting Senator Spindler's amendment for reasons similar to our support for amendment No. 1. It is our understanding that there is the possibility that this kind of action may be challenged as being GATT inconsistent, although it is of benefit to the industry. Once again, we will have the ability of seeing the government having to choose between industry and the Australian people and the World Trade Organisation for some unknown benefit that will supposedly be seven years in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to what was said a couple of speakers ago, a number of points need to be made. The Democrats' history on the orange juice issue and on various issues in the country concerning regional development right across the range is well and truly on record and need not be defended.

PARA.TAB: The fruit growers that we are talking about need not fear any tax increases—increases which, as far as the Democrats are concerned, very clearly will be targeted to high income earners. I am certainly aware that that is something the opposition would oppose. We believe that high income earners should pay their way in order to achieve a balance in our deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I think Senator Spindler's speech is getting a little irrelevant in this case. The subject at hand is sales tax and sales tax on fruit juice. Taxing high income earners selectively has hardly anything to do with this debate. I think you should bring the speaker back to the point.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—I am sure Senator Spindler is aware that he is required to address the particular terms of his amendment and this bill. I will listen carefully to his arguments.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were discussing briefly the means by which we can achieve a deficit reduction. Rather than cut services in the country, the Australian Democrats believe that high income earners can well afford to pay a little more tax to ensure that we do not have to put up interest rates. I repeat that this amendment is valid in GATT terms. There is therefore no reason why it should be opposed.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—While I appreciate Senator McKiernan's efforts to find a jacket, I would also appreciate his finding a male's jacket before the next division.

TALK.START.PARA: —I abided by your ruling, or your direction, on the last occasion. Unfortunately, I was not able to get back to my room and get a jacket in time to make the division.
—I accept your apology, Senator McKiernan.

—I would point out, however, from my reading of the standing orders, that there is nothing there which specifies the make, the colour or the gender of the jacket that senators are able to wear in the chamber.
—I am advised that the standard of dress is in the hands of the Chairman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4, page 2, lines 5 to 28, omit the clause, substitute the following clauses:
"4. Schedule 1 of the Principal Act is amended:

TAB.TAB: (a)by inserting the following Item after Item 69 in the Table of Contents:

PARA.TAB: `69A. Fruit and vegetable juices etc.';

TAB.TAB: (b)by inserting the following Item after Item 69

SPEECH.PARA: `Item 69A: [Fruit and vegetable juices etc].

PARA.TAB: Concentrates for making non-alcoholic beverages, if the concentrates consist of at least 25% by volume of juices of fruits.
Cordials for making non-alcoholic beverages, and preparations for use in flavouring foods, if the cordials or preparations consist of at least 25% by volume of:
(a)juices of fruits;

TAB.TAB: (b)a mixture of water and concentrates of juices of fruits, being a mixture whose strength is equal to or greater than the natural strength of the juices;
(c)a combination of juices covered by paragraph (a) and a mixture covered by paragraph (b).

PARA.TAB: Non-alcoholic non-carbonated beverages, if they consist of at least 25% by volume of juices of fruits or vegetables.
Non-alcoholic carbonated beverages, if they consist wholly of juices of fruits or vegetables.

SPEECH.PARA: (5)In this Item:

PARA.TAB: "vegetables" includes herbage.'.
"4A.Schedule 2 of the Principal Act is amended:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)by omitting Items 13 and 14 from the Table of Contents;

TAB.TAB: (b)by omitting Items 13 and 14.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is simple enough. We have taken the government's definition—which, we understand, is GATT consistent—and simply put that class of things in schedule 1, making them tax exempt.

PARA.TAB: In the debate on the Australian Democrats amendment relating to fresh fruit juice only—on which we have already voted—we clearly saw from the government's actions and the opposition's response that there is a way in which GATT and the World Trade Organisation can work against national objectives. I believe that a large number of growers think that this amendment is an appropriate exemption. Fresh fruit juice differs from juice from concentrate. It tastes and feels different; it is healthier. The juice from fresh fruit makes it difficult for foreign growers because they could not easily ship tonnes of oranges used for orange juice to Australia. If they did, the expense would be horrendous, the quality would suffer, and major losses of fruit would result. So they consider it a trade barrier. The fact that it is not an intentional trade barrier does not matter. Because they say that it makes it difficult for them, we have to change our laws to make it easier for them, regardless of the reason those laws are in place.

This amendment is GATT and World Trade Organisation consistent. It simply puts all the juice products concerned at the exempt rather than a concessional rate. There is no reason that juice should be taxed at a higher level than coffee. Juice is a food and we recognise that it is far more beneficial to health than coffee is, even though some Greens are well known coffee drinkers.

This is also a means of assisting our citrus farmers. There is no need to discriminate against juice in favour of coffee and other drinks. Making juice more attractive to consumers might create an increase in demand that will partially counteract the effect of this bill. The fact that concentrate is included means that Australian concentrate source can be used, and quite a lot of Australian juice goes into concentrate.

In commending this amendment, I make it very clear that this is the first occasion in dealing with these bills that the government has been asked to deal with an amendment that is clearly not inconsistent and clearly is what the industry is asking for. The minister has mentioned a number of times tonight that there has been extensive consultation with industry. There is not much point having Senator Sherry talking with the citrus industry for over two years if we ignore what has come out of that. That is not what consultation is about. I remind the chamber that the consultation with the footwear, clothing and textile industries was overridden three times.

Consultation with industry is about listening to what industry is saying—listening to what it says are the implications of decisions. If the government can do something here that will assist an industry and will not put in jeopardy the agreement it so dearly wants, there is no excuse for it not supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment. We believe that my second amendment was GATT friendly; this one undeniably so. There is no excuse for the government not to support this amendment.

PARA.TAB: We have placed on record the reason that citrus growers in Australia deserve support. They are the losers in the GATT process. We believe that while, under GATT, most of our primary industries and some of our other industries will receive benefits, some others will be losers. There is an obligation on the government to assist those which are losers so that the community as a whole can benefit. The government must support this amendment and I look forward to that support.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem with this amendment is that it costs the taxpayer $40 million in lost revenue to give $ 1/2 million of benefit to fruit growers. It is not a very cost-effective way of providing assistance to people that we want to assist. Our package provides more assistance for less.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his information, but can he please explain how $40 million in lost revenue will come about?
—You are reducing sales tax; it costs revenue.
—So this industry that we are going to lose is so important that $40 million worth of benefits to the government is likely to be lost. It seems a fairly important industry, therefore.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Margetts's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Question put:
That the bill be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: DAIRY PRODUCE (WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I flagged in the beginning, the Dairy Produce (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill is one of the bills to which I will be moving an amendment similar to that which I moved to the Sales Tax (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill which affects the citrus industry. I move:

PARA.TAB: After clause 1, page 1, insert the following clause:

SPEECH.PARA: "1A.(1) This section commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.

"(2) The provisions of this Act, other than section 1 and this section, are not to take effect before the commencement of an Act which provides that persons representing the Commonwealth in or before the World Trade Organisation may not enter into any agreement or arrangement which has or may have the object or effect of altering or overriding any law of the Commonwealth, unless that object or effect or a class of such objects or effects has been approved by a resolution of each House of the Parliament.".

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise specifically in support of this amendment to the Dairy Produce (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994. The dairy industry is of significant importance to Tasmania. This amendment simply seeks to enable parliament to have some say in the ultimate arrangements that are likely to be made with the WTO as they affect intimately and significantly the affairs of dairy producers. As such, I think it is a reasonable amendment. I believe it is a reasonable exercise of our rights as members of parliament and the rights of parliament as a whole.

PARA.TAB: No doubt there is an argument that it may inhibit negotiations and so on. I do not see it that way. I see this as simply a break on any undue and unwise negotiations and deals that might take place and that might affect a significant group within our community, particularly dairy producers in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment for the reasons outlined before. We believe that, when a government representative negotiates on behalf of the government and the Australian community and it comes to the point that a binding agreement or an arrangement which vitally affects trade and economic matters is made, it is appropriate for this parliament to vote on the agreement that is proposed to the extent that it changes the existing legislative position in Australia. That should be done before an agreement is made to join a particular treaty, convention or agreement. It should not be done as part of this package of bills which is being placed before the chamber without substantive debate on the actual GATT issue.

PARA.TAB: I state again that, every time the Democrats vote against one of these bills, we are voting not to exclude Australian support for these bills or the accession to GATT; we are voting to register the need to defer consideration of these bills until we know and the Australian community knows exactly what the benefits and the disadvantages are. These have not been placed before the Australian community.

As I said before, the Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment. Before I conclude, I wish to briefly comment on the bill before the chamber to which this amendment is being moved. The Dairy Produce (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994 is an example of where the government has managed to maintain the support for dairy producers in a different way. It simply has restructured the support that dairy producers receive, but essentially the support remains the same. If it was possible with this bill, why was it not possible with some of the other bills where losers are quite clearly defined?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of time limits I have not participated in this debate, but I must state my own point of view. Along with the Speaker and Leo McLeay, I represented this parliament at the IPU conference in Copenhagen in September. I spoke about GATT and the effect it would have on Australia and developing countries. I supported the government's position, and I still do so.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the comments made tonight about the dairy industry. I normally agree with my colleague from Tasmania Senator Harradine, but dairy producers have restructured their industry themselves; they have opened up markets all over the world. If people are so concerned about the dairy industry, why is there so much investment in dairying in Tasmania, for example? Many New Zealand companies have come into Woolnorth. I went to the opening of one of its dairies last Friday afternoon. One dairy alone is milking 1,500 cows in three hours. The company intends to open another four or five dairies like that which have the potential to hold 20,000 dairy cows.

I suggest that, if the industry was in such dire straits and in need of so much assistance, these people from New Zealand and others who are investing in dairy cattle, like UMT, would not be investing so much money in that area. They know the future for dairying and the markets that are emerging, particularly in Asia. They know the markets. They know their cost structures. They know what the government is doing. They know what the effects of GATT are going to be. These negotiations have been going on for years. They know the effects it will have upon them. They have every confidence in this industry. I believe any efforts by senators to alter what has been known to everybody for quite some time would certainly not work in their favour.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an interesting precedent, I would think. I have not heard the opposition say in the past that, if the government were to take an action which is likely to impact on a particular industry which happens to be doing well at the time, that means that it should be less liable to ask for some kind of compensation for the damage that is being done. I certainly know that some dairy producers in Western Australia are doing quite well.

PARA.TAB: If the arrangements under the World Trade Organisation do impact on the dairy industry, then I do not see that that would actually mean that we should not be asking that if there is damage that damage should be compensated. I am not sure what precedent we are setting if we say that if an industry is doing okay and there is damage done to it then it should be ineligible for assistance. There was a strong call for assistance to the mining industry in relation to the fuel tax debate last year. I did not actually hear many opposition senators say that because the mining corporations are quite well off that should be a basis upon which that industry is not compensated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for Senator Margetts. The amendment as circulated does not contain the amendment that she, at my suggestion, moved to the Sales Tax (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill. We should make sure that all Senator Margetts's amendments have been altered accordingly.

—When I first agreed to my amendment to the first bill being amended, I did ask that the amended version be moved to the subsequent bills. Unless there is any problem with that, any time I move amendment No. 1 to the other bills I would like it to be taken that the words `take any action or' on the fourth line after `to' and the word `negotiation' and the comma have been removed. For the other bills will that be done?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Childs)—I believe that has already been done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge some of the points made by Senator Calvert and indicate to him that it is not my intention to vote against this measure. The measure does include the extension of the support payments to the dairy industry to at least 30 June 2000. There are certain other measures in the legislation in that regard. All we are dealing with at the moment is amendment No. 1, which states:

PARA.TAB: The provisions of this Act, other than section 1 and this section, are not to take effect before the commencement of an Act which provides that persons representing the Commonwealth in or before the World Trade Organisation may not take any action or enter into any negotiation, agreement or arrangement which has or may have the object or effect of altering or overriding any law of the Commonwealth, unless that object or effect or a class of such objects or effects has been approved by a resolution of each House of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that is probably a reasonable exercise of parliamentary power. I know the government has a different view on this and that this may inhibit its abilities to expedite negotiations and other questions. I support this amendment, but if it is defeated I will be supporting the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 4, page 2, at end of clause, add the following subclause:

"(2) This section is not to take effect before the commencement of an Act which provides for a scheme of market support payments to be payable to the manufacturer of dairy produce in respect of that dairy produce.".

The dairy industry arrangements are another potential casualty of the World Trade Organisation. They are arrangements that government, industry and parliament have spent considerable time on to establish and get right in terms of the dairy industry and the public interest. Yet, again, they are World Trade Organisation inconsistent. Why is that? Australia is already a very low tariff nation and we have in place commitments to cut our dairy export support program substantially from 22 per cent in 1992-93 to 10 per cent in the year 2000. This is a decline of 55 per cent over the term of the adjustment set by the Uruguay Round.

PARA.TAB: We are only required to cut the value of support by 36 per cent over that period. So what is wrong? It would seem that once again our negotiators are so keen to act as the purest of the pure in these negotiations that they are prepared to go further than the industry or the World Trade Organisation felt was necessary.

It is there that we run foul of the requirement to reduce the quantity of export subsidies that must also decline by 21 per cent. So back to the drawing board. It does not matter that we are a low tariff nation already committed to surpassing requirements in many respects; we are still in violation according to the government. I wonder how many other nations will be as scrupulous as we are.

I also wonder why there is such a hurry to put everything right immediately, even if it means pushing this legislation through before any alternative provisions have been put in place. The government has said it will put alternatives in place. Unfortunately, while it can push all kinds of other bills into the Senate as matters of urgency, it does not feel the same urgency in regard to these measures.

Why not, especially since in agriculture it appears that there are transitional arrangements? Improvements must be made but not necessarily before the World Trade Organisation is even established. The export subsidies must be reduced but only bit by bit over six years. It seems there may be time to get the new arrangements through. The government insists that the bills must be pushed through and our arrangements become perfect before we even start.

I point out that, in relation to the agricultural subsidies, the World Trade Organisation imposes a proportional reduction on every member. It does not recognise that nations are starting at very different levels. Australia can end up with almost no export support but may be competing, even at the end of the round, with nations having more subsidies than we started with. It seems that there can be no leeway for a nation like Australia, which is far ahead of most nations, to provide proper alternatives in the next year when there is something wrong.

Certainly in the committee hearing on these bills, the dairy industry expressed concern that the new arrangements were not in place or even drafted and tabled. It is left in the invidious position of having to give up its arrangements and any negotiating powers it may have and simply trust the government to do the right thing by it. It is willing but worried.

We believe that putting this sort of pressure on the dairy industry is improper. We believe that the removal of one set of provisions on the promise that the new provisions are in the pipeline is inadequate. The government has shown, and shows in these bills, that it is willing to sacrifice various sectors of the community such as the citrus growers, the rental people and so on. There is no real assurance that it may not decide that the dairy industry can be sacrificed or partially sacrificed or that that damage that the dairy industry has incurred will not be fully compensated.

The major issue of concern to the dairy industry was that there should be a smooth transition between the existing and the new provisions. Since the new provisions are not even on the table, there already seems to be a hitch. Hopefully, this will not translate into a major disruption of the dairy industry.

Our second amendment makes the action of this bill and the termination of the existing regime conditional on the provision of alternative arrangements. We believe that the passage of this bill with these conditions should demonstrate good faith and a commitment to the changes required, even if the bill was not commenced with the WTO start-up date.

The bill is not set to commence in any case until at least 1 July 1995. It has six months to get its legislation in place. If it cannot do so by the passage of this bill as amended, it can at least demonstrate to the WTO that it will put it in place at the earliest possible date. This will also assure the dairy industry a smooth transition between regimes and create some security for that industry. It will relieve the pressure to pass legislation hastily to avoid harming the industry, although the legislation should be considered important. We believe this is a reasonable amendment and should not pose a problem for World Trade Organisation entry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two things need to be put on the table factually. I just had confirmed that the details of the dairy industry package are public. They were announced. They have been reported. Most importantly, the dairy industry supports the approach adopted by the government. It has been closely involved in the formulation of the new support mechanism. The dairy industry wants this legislation passed. So let us not try to protect it more than it wants. Let us get the package it wants passed. Dairy is one of the big winners out of this package, out of the World Trade Organisation agreement. Let us get it passed in the terms that the industry supports and get on with it.
—I thank the minister. What date was the package announced and made public?

—I have not checked the date on the press release—I did just try to do that but I could not put my hand on it—but I understand it was released yesterday. It was confirmed in cabinet on Monday and was released during the week. I understand it was yesterday and was in the paper this morning, but I cannot personally vouch for that. I have not seen that date, but that is my understanding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. On that basis—and I am pleased to see it—if the industry is happy with the package I am also happy to withdraw the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.
Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: PATENTS (WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The bill.
Amendment (by Senator Margetts) proposed:
After clause 1, page 1, insert the following clause:

SPEECH.PARA: "1A.(1) This section commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.

"(2) The provisions of this Act, other than section 1 and this section, are not to take effect before the commencement of an Act which provides that persons representing the Commonwealth in or before the World Trade Organisation may not enter into any agreement or arrangement which has or may have the object or effect of altering or overriding any law of the Commonwealth, unless that object or effect or a class of such objects or effects has been approved by a resolution of each House of the Parliament.".

TALK.START.PARA: —I put on record that, for reasons previously outlined, the Australian Democrats will be supporting that amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Patents (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994 and my amendments. In this bill we are being asked to extend our patent rights in a variety of ways. The move has certainly not come from parliament. I have not heard any calls or received constituent letters calling for these changes or asking us to support this as an issue. In fact, the only representation from industry I received was from the Australian Biotechnology Association and it was unfavourable. However, many aid and development groups expressed strong objection and asked that we oppose the bill.

PARA.TAB: There are several issues at stake here and they will probably not be debated on their merits. As with all of these bills, the overriding consideration is that we must have this legislation to join the World Trade Organisation. Yet we have the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) and others insisting that the World Trade Organisation does not affect our sovereignty. When we start acting to pass legislation on an issue not because the issue is important or needs to be addressed but because we need to accomplish another objective like selling beef, then where is sovereignty? When there is no independence or ability to look at issues on their merits there can be no sovereignty. When our desire to sell beef and coal forces us to change our patent regime to reverse onus of proof I do not see a great deal of independence. Our actions in respect of an unrelated issue are conditional on the requirements of others.

So why is this bill an issue? Most basically we see an agenda of the GATT and now the World Trade Organisation is to extend patent rights. TRIPS, the trade related intellectual property regime, was a major regulatory issue pushed by the United States on behalf of transnational industry. Besides the very great implications for control of genetic and other living resources, there are many ethical issues here. These will not be examined and the amendments are only to slavishly bring Australian law into line with the World Trade Organisation.

There is a major issue in relation to patenting and its effect on free scientific information. I am sorry that Senator Coulter is not here for this debate. I know how strong his concerns on this issue are. In pushing for patents we are basically establishing a stronger and stronger regime of what is called proprietary information—knowledge that is owned. That is exactly the opposite of what science has striven for with its emphasis on free scientific information.

International patent law has been a highly contentious issue. The reason and rationale for granting patents and the validity of subjects of patents are not consistent. The ethics are not clear; nor is there any clear regime as a model, although the United States proposes its law as the global standard. There are strong implications for transfer of technology to developing nations—human rights and other implications in terms of other international agreements, both those relating to intellectual property and others, such as UNCSD for climate change and biodiversity agreements.

In terms of the morality and the outcomes of the TRIPS regime, TRIPS purports to protect discoverers and inventors. In fact, it protects corporations capable of gaining patent rights. The recent death of the Philippine discoverer of the drug erythromycin after having unsuccessfully fought for years for some control or return from the drug company that patented it highlights the situation. Patents have been granted in the United States in courts for basic monoclonal antibody technology using development of most modern vaccines in spite of the fact that the innovation was made by two British scientists and published as free scientific information. The discoverers have received no benefit. The issue of assuring any benefit to the real discoverers or inventors is conveniently ignored under patent law. The level of proper compensation has also not been addressed.

Granting of exclusive patent rights grants corporations monopoly control over that product. Companies can determine what rate of monopoly, rent or super profit they receive by price setting. They can determine the availability and the cost of licensing. They are not obliged to allow anyone else to produce it, even if they do not. In this sense it also allows companies to hold monopoly control of technology. If a company decides a market is too small, as drug companies do, there is no obligation to make the drug available in a country and no obligation to issue a licence to allow others to do so; likewise with technology such as the Sarich two-stroke. An invention can simply remain unavailable in Australia because of marketing considerations. In fact, there is no obligation to produce an innovative device at all. Many patents are bought and held by corporations to prevent others from making similar products.

This is granting a totally unethical control to others. It is also unproductive, particularly when patent rights control the ability to build on basic design innovation. There are certainly strong grounds to question extension of these rights. No-one was allowed to speak on the issue at the hearing, although there was at least one person who would have liked to have spoken. The haste with which such hearings are put together reduces the ability to discover the full and complex issues associated with things such as patents. The implications of patents on these various issues that I have talked about require much greater and in-depth consideration. This matter could have done with an entire inquiry all of its own under intellectual property. The committee has done itself a great disservice in the amount of time and consideration that has been afforded these important considerations.

Section 135 of the principal act on patents sets out the reasonable requirements of the public. This is an excellent provision in this far-thinking legislation and it establishes some measures of public responsibility that patent holders must meet. The primary purpose of section 135 is to assume that a company granted an Australian patent does not use its monopoly right to exclude the Australian public from that innovation, that it does not prevent others from making an innovation available if it does not make it available in Australia itself, and that it does not charge monopoly prices for its goods, that is, it must set a reasonable price. If such companies do not do these things, under section 133 they can be taken to court, and compulsory licence for someone else to develop the innovation can be issued or, under section 134, the violator can have his patent taken away. We think these are reasonable measures to protect the public from some of the worst abuses of industrial patents. I now wish to seek advice on the amendments which I will be moving.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I want to raise something for the minister to consider. Mr Temporary Chairman, in your previous position as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, you will recall that in 1990 that committee was considering the Patents Bill 1990. At that time, Mr Kevin Andrews, who is extremely competent in this area of patents, wrote to you noting that the bill did not appear to preclude the possibility of grant of a patent in Australia for biological processes for the production of humans, their components, or higher life forms. He said that the absence of such provision appeared to leave open the possibility that property rights in human beings might be granted by way of patent in Australia were the bill passed in its current form. Mr Andrews then detailed various High Court decisions and decisions of international courts relevant to this question. As a result of that, Mr Temporary Chairman, you will recall that I moved an amendment to the Patents Act to prevent the patenting in Australia, under the Patents Act, of certain human life forms. That was agreed to by the Senate and subsequently agreed to by the House of Representatives and, of course, it was agreed to by the government. I ask the minister how this legislation will affect the prohibitions that are now contained in the Patents Act, particularly with respect to that specific matter? The minister may be able to answer that now or at some later stage.

—I do not pretend that I have any great expertise in this matter, but I checked on it and confirmed that there is nothing in the TRIPS agreement that interferes in any way with our right to sustain and maintain that explicit exclusion that is in the bill, and it will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 11, page 4, before paragraph (a), insert the following paragraphs:
"(aaa)by omitting the section heading and substituting the following section heading (but without affecting the operation subsection of 13(3) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901):

SPEECH.PARA: (aa)by omitting subsection (1) and substituting the following section:
`(1)A person may apply to a prescribed court, after the end of the prescribed period for an order requiring the patentee:

TAB.TAB: (a)to grant the applicant a licence to work the patented invention; or
(b)otherwise to satisfy the reasonable requirements of the public (an `order of public satisfaction').".

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clause 9, pages 3 and 4, OMIT THE CLAUSE.
4.Clause 10, page 4, OMIT THE CLAUSE.

"13A. Section 134 of the Principal Act is amended:

TAB.TAB: (a)by omitting the section heading and substituting the following section heading (but without affecting the operation of subsection 13(3) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901):

SPEECH.PARA: `Revocation of standard patent after grant of compulsory licence or order of public satisfaction';

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendment to reasonable requirements of the public

PARA.TAB: "13B. Section 135 of the Principal Act is amend ed:

TAB.TAB: (a)by inserting in subparagraph 135(1)(a)(i) "and make available in Australia" after "to manufacture";
(b)by inserting in subparagraph 135(1)(a)(ii) "and make available in Australia", after "to manufacturer";
