SPEECH.PARA: We think that these amendments are reasonable measures to protect the public from some of the worst abuses of industrial patents. This set of amendments is designed to allow a person to bring a patent holder to court for the same breaches of the reasonable requirements of the public and seek a more general order that the patent holder should meet those reasonable requirements or have the patent revoked. The major difference is that the person making the complaint does not need to be someone wishing a compulsory licence. It can be a member of the general public, a representative of a consumer group, or the Prices Surveillance Tribunal.

PARA.TAB: The bill further amends sections 133 and 134 of the act to stipulate the court's powers in a number of respects, such as the length of time required for redress. It also significantly weakens the power of redress. We do not feel that this is appropriate. Given the increasing difficulty of obtaining redress through compulsory licence, it is entirely appropriate to seek a means for the public to directly demand of the patent holder that the reasonable requirements of the public be met.

During the minimal debates we have had in this chamber some aspects of the problems of research and knowledge were discussed. A lot of that discussion was about public interest and the need for us not to be moving away from the benefits of research and what can be done about the move that is pushing more and more into corporations controlling the research that is being done in this country. It seems that if we totally commoditise knowledge in our country, we are leaving it open for the owning of knowledge to become much more important than actually producing, creating, and sharing knowledge.

I will relate to the chamber one example that springs to mind which is happening right at this moment in Western Australia. Scientists who wish to study the flora and fauna in our state forests—that is, forests that do not belong to anyone in particular; they belong to everybody—are required to obtain a licence from the Department of Conservation and Land Management. That department has made a bit of a name for itself because it has tried to lead the world in the commoditisation of genetic material by allowing the patenting and the selling of a subproduct of a species—the smoke bush—as a cancer cure, on the basis that we will get $2 million or $3 million worth of benefits. Some pharmaceutical company will make a great deal more. We have given away—in reality, we have sold—a piece of our natural environment.

As part of that, the requirement to gain a permit to study in the forest requires a person to sign an agreement with the Department of Conservation and Land Management which says that the information the person gains from the study is owned by the Department of Conservation and Land Management. This means that it claims proprietary right for any information that that person gains on any species. The department requires the right to patent it before anybody else does and can stop that person publishing any material as a result of the studies. The material could be something that is not to do with things that CALM is doing at the moment, because it is not doing much in relation to conservation. It could actually have something to do with saving the forests. It is to do with patents but it is also to do with copyright, and we will get to that as well. It basically means that CALM can stop that person publishing the material.

This is the kind of thing that is possible under the new rules. We can buy and sell species. We can hold the benefits of information. We can even stop it from being published if it is not in the interest of those people who are co-owners of the copyright. I think it is really important that we begin to see what it is we might be leading into when we strengthen the ability of patents to withhold information and stop the free flow of the scientific information and ideas that are so necessary for where we have got to in the world today. I commend my amendments Nos 2 to 9 to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are moving into a very complex area. Senator Margetts has made a lengthy contribution in two parts: firstly, about the general issue of patents and then, more specifically, about these amendments. I appreciate that dealing with the amendments in bulk is an attempt to get things done more quickly, but the amendments cover a lot of different issues and I do not want to traverse the detail. If we look at amendment No. 2 first, it strangely seeks to go beyond what is required for the purposes of the act. At the moment our view is that the bill makes reasonable provision for the recognition of reasonable requirements of the public. The added proposal in the amendment is unclear; it makes the situation uncertain.

PARA.TAB: If I can look at amendments Nos 3, 5, 6 and 7 together to expedite proceedings, we think there is a problem with these with regard to issues like burden of proof. While on the one hand we could say there is a problem with these because the amendments probably result in our failing to meet our World Trade Organisation obligations, this is not a circumstance in which, as I am advised, we are having imposed upon us policies we would not otherwise have adopted. My advice is that these are essentially in a form that we would have wished to do ourselves as a matter of domestic policy. Although this comes in under the World Trade Organisation package, patents do not come under my personal portfolio responsibilities, so I do not deal with them in a day-to-day way. My advice from those who do is that this is the manner in which we would, in any event, have dealt with it.

I am a bit surprised why there is a proposal to oppose clause 4, because that is the clause which preserves natural justice principles in respect of infringement proceedings. I do not understand why we would want to oppose that. That seems to be something, even if one were opposed to the general thrust of the legislation, that one might wish to maintain. I do not want to pursue it clause by clause too much. I think we should deal with it in bulk.

The problem with amendment No. 8 is that it causes some transitional problems. That is essentially what it is dealing with. I do not think that enhances the bill in any way, in fact, to the contrary. Clause 9 goes a bit beyond what we need to do for the WTO. Compulsory licences, which in some ways are the vehicle for dealing with some of the concerns that Senator Margetts has raised, seem to me to be an inappropriate way of handling this problem.

To deal with it cryptically because of the time, we do not support any of these amendments broadly because they either go beyond the thrust of what is needed for the World Trade Organisation or cut across the policy approach that the government would wish to take or, in one particular instance, take out what we thought would wish to be maintained in terms of protecting the natural justice rights of parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wondering whether the minister could explain the process by which the government's policy on patents has been developed so that it is clear as to where it wants to go and the reasons why.

—I am not sure this goes to Senator Margetts's point. The continuing thrust of policy has been and is to maintain a balance between the incentive to innovate by giving rights to the innovator and the protection of the public interest. It is always a difficult balance to strike. To pretend there is some magical objective measure, I think, is a bit ambitious. That is the balance we are going to strike. If that is what Senator Margetts is looking for in terms of what the principles are, that is the most thumbnail description I can give. Perhaps the question was more about process as well. If that is what Senator Margetts wanted to know, perhaps she could clarify it and I will come back to it.

—I feel I ought to make an apology here. Amendments Nos 3 and 4, as the minister has rightly pointed out, relate to the onus of proof. I would be happy to isolate those two amendments, by leave of the chamber, so that we can move those separately as they are an issue separate from the one I was originally dealing with. I could deal with those at the end.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Childs)—You do not have to move amendments Nos 3 and 4 because the clauses are being opposed, not amended.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting both brackets of amendments moved by Senator Margetts. It is our view that it is necessary to strengthen the public good aspect of patent law, that we must ensure that patent holders do not profit at the expense of benefits that should be obtained by the public. Without going into further details, we believe that balance needs to be shifted a little to the direction of the public good. It is on that basis that we will be supporting the amendments.

—Did I understand the minister to indicate that some of the provisions in this bill would have been desirable notwithstanding TRIPS? I might not have heard the minister correctly. Some of the provisions of this measure would have been considered as being desirable, from the government's point of view, notwithstanding the contributions.
—That is correct.

—How does the minister then explain the extension from 16 years to 20? Is that a desirable feature? It seems to me that from a number of points of view it is important that the government keeps a wary eye on that aspect. It might be in many instances an inhibiting factor. How does that square with the government's micro-economic reform policies which are directed at greater, open access to essential infrastructure? I use the term infrastructure in the broadest sense because I think these innovations are part of that infrastructure.

—I am sympathetic to Senator Harradine's point, but the bits that I was referring to which were policy initiatives for which the Australian government had sympathy related to some things covered by this amendment in particular—not that clause. If there had been no other factors we probably would not have made this change, but it is a necessary element of getting an international regime so that the international patent rights of Australians are protected. We therefore wish to participate in this regime.

PARA.TAB: My private view, and I think it conforms with the view of the minister and the government, is that had we not needed to meet that desirable international harmonisation objective so that we participate in and protect the international patent rights of Australians we probably would not, of our own initiative, have made that extension.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I asked the question about the process, I began to wonder—I think it is embodied in what Senator Harradine was saying—what weight the government puts on the information from various bodies that it may have consulted. From what I was saying before, it seems that with regard to those people involved in research, be it university research, CSIRO research or other areas of research in which people are deeply committed to what they are doing, not just to making money, there is a contrary opinion about the kind of direction taken by the current Australian policy in relation to intellectual property, which seems to be pushed in this way by the new trade relations. Is equal weight given to the concerns of research scientists and those people working to try to improve the environment, our lifestyles and so on, as is given to the current demands of industry, especially of those industries involved with international trade?

—I did not conduct the negotiations, but I have been reassured that there was extensive consultation with a range of bodies, with an opportunity to gather the views of people in the research area, and particularly those institutions that have had a history of a large number of patent applications. Of course, when we gather people's views, it does not always mean that we agree with the views that they put to us. That is an inevitable consequence of broad ranging consultation—one cannot agree with everybody. But I am assured that there was wide ranging consultation with those various interests that have a particular, active interest in this matter—the patent attorneys, industry, research institutes, et cetera.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 10.After clause 13, page 7, insert the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "13C Section 135 of the Principal Act is amended by adding the following word and paragraph after paragraph (1)(a)(c):

`;or (d)if a reasonable level of return, as determined by a prescribed court, is not being provided as a portion of profits to the actual innovator, and embodied in a contract between the innovator and the patent holder.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment seeks to impose an additional requirement of the public. It is to ensure that the actual innovators in patent applications receive some benefit from their work. This is the rationale for patents, after all. Instead, we see, for example, the huge pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly patenting the work of a Philippine researcher who discovered erythromycin. Eli Lilly made billions and the innovator got nothing. What makes this situation more sad is that the researcher asked Lilly to pay a royalty into a trust to fund medical research and researchers in the Philippines rather than into a trust for himself. After nearly four decades of fighting for some payment in recognition, Abelardo Aguilar died recently without ever receiving anything from the drug giant.

PARA.TAB: Stories abound of big companies using their corporate and economic muscle to exploit the effort of workers or to crush small innovators. They can put pressure on to exclude them from markets. If the big companies are the customer, they can often demand either the patent or the exclusive rights as part of the price they pay.

Employees may have signed contracts giving their employers full rights over innovations, including patent rights. Some employees have even signed contracts giving their employer not only rights over any innovation during the term of their employment but rights over any patent during the term of their life. This is especially the case when the employee comes from a developing nation.

So whilst we have had the debate—and whilst many people are under the impression that in supporting bills like this they are supporting those people who innovate, who invent and who are involved in scientific research for the benefit of all and are protecting them because of this innovation—what we are seeing appears to be the opposite: the owners of that knowledge are benefiting and the innovators are not necessarily protected. In order for people to put their opinions where their mouths are, shall we say, I would urge the support of my amendment No. 10 to make sure that we in Australia do act to make sure that some equitable sharing of the benefits of such innovations do go to the innovator and to the patent holder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like some explanation. I presume that the opposition and the government are going to support this amendment because I have not heard any reasonable opposition to it. It is an amendment to section 135 of the principal act, which deals with the reasonable requirements of the public, and adds another requirement which, on the face of it, appears to be eminently reasonable and is stated in Senator Margetts's amendment No. 10. The amendment simply states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if a reasonable level of return, as determined by a prescribed court, is not being provided as a portion of profits to the actual innovator, and embodied in a contract between the innovator and the patent holder.

That amendment is to be included as paragraph (d) in section 135. I think it is a perfectly reasonable situation. The example given by Senator Margetts is one that we should all contemplate. Here is a person who was the innovator—the inventor or discoverer, I suppose, in that case—who wanted to ensure that the fruits of his discovery, his invention, his innovation, were shared amongst the people of the Philippines, a developing country.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the patent laws, he did not get to do that. He was the actual inventor, the actual innovator, but a pharmaceutical company was able to claim patent rights and receive all the payments and royalties thereof. I would like to know why anyone would oppose this particular provision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support the amendment and what both Senator Margetts and Senator Harradine have said. It seems eminently reasonable that the actual innovator should be able to obtain a due share of the profits arising from the innovation and that he or she should determine what should happen to them. It is an eminently reasonable amendment. I add my request to the minister to either support it or to provide us with an explanation as to why the government will refuse it. The same request goes to the coalition parties. At this stage, we have not heard their position enunciated. I wonder what reason the coalition parties could have for not supporting it.

—I cannot answer the last question. Perhaps I cannot answer as sweepingly as Senator Harradine asked his question either. Although there are some initiatives which, as I said before, the government may as a matter of policy wish to implement in any event, we are seeking to bring this piece of legislation—which the parliament dealt with recently in the way that Senator Harradine outlined when he asked me a previous question—into line with the international body of patent law for the reasons that we discussed when he asked me the previous question.

PARA.TAB: This goes beyond what that requires. In the first instance, I have concern about a process of legislating that involves an amendment which none of us has previously seen. We are concerned about dealing with a bit of legislation that we have only had for six weeks. This is an amendment that we have not had for six hours, and we are not across all the detail. Trying to make a sweeping, general amendment to deal with a particular case, however serious, is always a tricky proposition. It is not something that we ought to be rushing in to do.

We are talking here essentially about contracts entered into between innovators and the patent holder. There is protection in the act against fraud or misrepresentation in obtaining the patents, so some of those problems are effectively dealt with by the existing subclauses of clause 138. I do not think, therefore, we need to dash in and pass this, which would involve the government establishing a process to determine the reasonableness of contracts freely entered into, with the protections that exist in other parts of the legislation. I do not think it is a direction in which we should go.

But, if there is a broad problem in the operation of the Australian legislation that suggests that the sort of problem referred to in the Philippines might occur in Australia, it would be a bit more useful if we had a committee of the Senate or some such body look at it and come up with a considered proposal to apply, in Australian circumstances, the Australian law. That might deal with the problems that are outlined. We should not pluck this off the shelf. On the face of what was described, it sounds a very serious problem. But it is not something that either this legislation was ever intended to address or that we are confident this amendment addresses without creating unintended consequences of which we are not aware.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the committee. I understand the minister's problems with it. In fairness to the mover of the amendment, Senator Margetts, it should be noted that this bill and the other bills were referred to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee. That committee sat a few days ago very briefly and reported only today. There was a considerable rush over that matter. I do not think it ought to be inferred that Senator Margetts was somehow not diligent enough in bringing forward the problem.
—I was not being critical; I was simply explaining the problem we have.

—In all the years I have been here, I have found that it is unfortunately a difficulty we face at the end of the year every year. That is one reason why I felt that part of this package should be the subject of delay and further consideration. But I will not go over that argument, because we have had it.

That the amendment (Senator Margetts's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 13, page 7, insert the following clause:

TAB.TAB: `; or (e)there is no concessional level of maximum reasonable licence payment for developing nations for the purposes of their domestic production, consistent with Australia's obligations under technology transfer provisions embodied in international agreements, for example the United Nations Agenda 21 program, climate change conventions, and social justice conventions.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: Before talking about the substantive issues involved in amendment 11, I would like to make a couple of comments in relation to the subtle and less subtle pressures that have been applied to me in the last however long about the time being taken for this particular debate. I would like to point out that, in my opinion, and in the opinion of a number of other people whose opinions are important to me, the debate on this series of bills is probably the most important debate to have occurred in this chamber and will be for many years to come.

PARA.TAB: The necessity to take the time to deal with these issues is not just to put on the record the concerns of those people who have not been heard to date; it is also to hear the government's responses to those concerns. This may be the only time that such responses are put on the record.

It will be of no great joy to me if, in years to come, what we are saying is proven to be perfectly true, but it is extremely important that the debate takes place and that the substantive issues that we are addressing go on the public record. The calling of divisions is not for the sake of enjoying myself. I would rather be anywhere than standing here in this chamber at the moment. Like anybody else, I would like to be at home, but I believe that these issues are so important that we must take the time to debate them correctly and we must go on the record as to where we stood on them.

I want to talk now about my amendment 11. A major issue of concern regarding the trade related intellectual property regime has been the impact on developing nations. There is a wide variety of concerns in relation to intellectual property. A major concern for developing nations is the impact of trade related intellectual property on technology transfer. There are many cases where nations feel that they are effectively denied technology. From the perspective of the South, in the old days the North used tariffs to keep trade dominance in manufactured goods. Now that these goods are made in the South and knowledge intensive goods are produced in the North, the North is pushing for low tariffs and strong protection for intellectual property.

This is probably somewhat naive but while it is true that at present a lot of knowledge intensive industry is found in the North, that is not exclusively the case. Major developments, such as the Indian Silicon Valley, show that knowledge based industries can be located anywhere. The point is that, although these industries might be located in India, the result is not necessarily a great rise in wellbeing for Indians, a reduction in poverty, or the transfer of technology. A company may develop a good and ship it out in such a way that nobody other than the workers will see much of that good. They will remain shanty dwellers and rickshaw wallahs on the edge of the city—likewise in the developed world.

We are trying to ensure recognition of the impact that changes to trade related intellectual property will make on less developed countries and that there is the chance to deal with those on an equitable basis. I remind honourable senators that there is a one-year transition period for intellectual property measures.I remind the chamber of the previous amendment, where there would be a case only when a complaint was heard and found valid. So we are not talking about changing everything that has ever existed. We are talking about equity—equity in dealing with intellectual property as it relates to less developed nations—and about taking into consideration things such as the United Nations agenda 21 program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to speak personally for a few minutes. Tomorrow at the Councils of the Liberal Party in South Australia I will make the following announcement. I state it first here in the Senate because I have the highest regard and affection for this place and, through the Senate, my first priority is to speak to the people of South Australia, whom I represent and all of whom I seek to serve.

PARA.TAB: The 17th summer—today is the first day of summer—of my first election to the Senate, 10 December 1977, comes up this month and only a few weeks ago I celebrated my 50th birthday.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're only a boy.

—Thank you. This is an available juncture to announce that I will not be a candidate for the next election. I would rather go a little early than stay on a little too long. For some years now I have been the longest serving of the 12 South Australian senators. Having been five times elected and having served in the last seven parliaments, the time has come for me to pursue with more focus some writing and research interests I have had for many years. I may have written 100 Senate reports but, to quote Brian Lara, `I am not yet a great player.'

PARA.TAB: In the years ahead one challenge will be to write a book about Australia's relations with our Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation partners and the initiatives we need to take in foreign affairs, trade and regional security to safeguard Australia's prosperity and peace. In particular, I want to write a book about China, including my own experiences during many visits there over the last 27 years.

Another challenge is for my wife and I to write a history of South Australia which builds on all that has been published about the development of our state and its distinctive characteristics as an exciting part of Australia. Also, having for two decades participated in all the education debates, I would like to make some personal contributions to our three universities in Adelaide.

I will continue to pursue the political principles and policies that I have advocated within the Liberal Party and the Commonwealth parliament. Among those principles are truth and justice, compassion, excellence, practical commonsense, equality of opportunity and the Australian sense of a fair go. I will continue to call for full employment, for a balanced budget, for tax reform that encourages exports, for realistic industrial relations reform, for micro-economic reform, for savings incentives and for wider and wider areas of international competitiveness.

My support for an Australian head of state remains undiminished and I will enjoy the wider freedom of the coming years to go on in step with the Australian people to achieve this historic change to the Australian constitution. I hope I make a positive contribution to the successful Aboriginal reconciliation, which is a currently being established by many Australians with vision.

The principal reasons for my stepping aside from the Senate at the end of my current term, 30 June 1996, are personal. My own family has from the beginning always magnificently come to terms with my parliamentary commitments and the framework that these commitments have placed on many parts of all our lives. It is time now for me to spend much more time with my wife, Kathy, and our three sons—Joshua, Matthew and Nathan. I have unreserved admiration and thankfulness for their total support of my political life over the last 20 years, and perhaps over the next 20, 40 or 60.

I also wish to spend much more time with my own parents and live up to a promise I have made to write a personal history of the Teague family in South Australia and in Cornwall. I believe with the psalmist:

SPEECH.PARA: The Earth is the Lord's and the fullness thereof: Commit your way to the Lord and He will direct your path.
To which Saint Paul adds:
the God of grace and peace will be with you.

I take this opportunity to thank the people of South Australia for electing me to represent them in the Australian parliament. I owe special debts of friendship to my personal staff, whom I thank for their excellent assistance to me. Finally, I thank all my party colleagues, my parliamentary and other colleagues for our shared work and aspirations to serve the people of Australia. I am not gone yet. I will be here at least until the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to take a few minutes of my time to respond to Senator Teague's surprise announcement tonight. Senator Teague and I entered the Senate at the same time. Right from the very beginning we struck up a very strong friendship. While it is perhaps unusual to pay tribute to people so early when they actually have not left this place, I think perhaps one of the hardest nights of his career has been tonight. So I thought it was opportune for me to add my support to Senator Teague and to acknowledge the strong family commitment that he has received from his family.

PARA.TAB: He is to be congratulated for the way he has kept the family together and brought up three fine boys. It is not easy in a situation where one is away from home so much. I can fully appreciate the reasons for Senator Teague's announcement. I would like to take this opportunity of wishing him well and giving him comfort and the support of friendship that only friends can provide on occasions like this. Thank you, Senator Teague.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a brief speech on the adjournment in lieu of Dr Michael Wooldridge, who would have made this speech in the House of Representatives if it had been sitting and if he had been here, to note on behalf of the coalition that today, 1 December, is World AIDS Day. It is a day which gives us an opportunity to reflect on a very serious disease, HIV-AIDS. It is a day when we remember those who have died from AIDS, both here in Australia and around the world; when we express our concern for all those living with HIV infections and those with full-blown AIDS; when we recognise the challenges faced by loved ones and other carers of people with AIDS; and when we recognise the achievements and efforts of the researchers, medical practitioners, other health workers, community service providers and volunteer helpers who have each made their contribution in the battle against HIV-AIDS.

PARA.TAB: In Australia we have had our share of AIDS related misery. Statistics reported in the October 1994 AIDS surveillance report indicate that, up to 30 June 1994, over 18,000 new cases of HIV infection had been diagnosed in Australia and, sadly, over 3,500 people have died of AIDS in that same period—523 of these in the period from 1 July 1993 until 30 June 1994.

If honourable senators in this chamber have not seen anybody die of AIDS, I must say that it is the worst death I have ever seen. A friend I went to university with died of AIDS. When he first became sick I thought he would die but he lived for another 24 weeks in a state that was nothing short of tragic. To think that so many other people have died like that fills me with grief—I think that is the only word one could use.

But in Australia there is reason for hope. The incidence of HIV infection has declined markedly since its peak in the late 1980s as preventative measures have been increasingly adopted by groups in the community most at risk of HIV. Consequently, it is to be hoped that the annual death rate from AIDS will fall in the next few years from its current peak. Although, as the President of the Australian Federation of AIDS Organisations, Tony Keenan, has pointed out, this is no reason for complacency.

World AIDS Day also invites to us look beyond our own shores. It is a day to look at the death and misery caused by AIDS in the Third World, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa but increasingly in South and South-East Asia. What we see there is a tragic picture. As I mentioned, Dr Michael Wooldridge, in conjunction with World Vision, has for the past week and a half been visiting sub-Saharan Africa. The stories that I have got back from his office about what he is discovering there are nothing short of tragic. I am sure he will tell us more and report more to the House of Representatives when he returns next week.

In May 1994, World Health Organisation data indicated that there are over 850,000 reported cases of full-blown AIDS worldwide, with 301,000 of these in Africa and 5,500 in Asia. Unreported cases may run into several millions. But the World Health Organisation has estimated the cumulative incidence of HIV infections in these regions as being of even more frightening proportions. In late 1993, the most reliable estimates suggested that over nine million people in sub-Saharan Africa were infected by HIV. In South and South-East Asia, it was estimated that at the same time over two million people were infected.

The worrying trend is that, while the rate of incidence of HIV infection and AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa is predicted to largely level off, the rate in South and South-East Asia will continue to rise alarmingly. Worldwide, the WHO estimates that the 14 million figure in late 1993 for cumulative HIV cases is projected to rise to 30 to 40 million by the year 2000, the vast majority of these occurring in Africa and Asia.

Australia, as part of the affluent developed world, can play its part in assisting those in the Third World who are fighting an uphill struggle against HIV and AIDS. The sheer scale of the Third World problem puts the size of our national HIV-AIDS research effort into better perspective. I also acknowledge the role of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau in its support of HIV-AIDS prevention and support programs, particularly in Asia. Praise is particularly due to the efforts of the international non-government organisations, like World Vision, which give on the ground support to people living with HIV-AIDS in places like Uganda and Rwanda where medical facilities and support infrastructure are woefully inadequate.

I note also the contribution of individual Australians, medical professionals, aid workers and financial donors to the efforts of such organisations. AIDS is a problem of our time. There is as yet no vaccine or cure for HIV and AIDS, and people the world over will continue to suffer and die. In Australia we should use World AIDS Day as a chance to reflect on the effects of HIV-AIDS not only in our Australian community but also in those parts of the world less fortunate than ours.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to the statement made by Senator Teague that he will resign from the parliament at the end of this term and will not renominate. Over a period of time, Baden and I have developed a fairly strong friendship. The first time I met you was in China back in the 1980s. I met you and Kathy and my wife was with me. Since then we have travelled together to China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Morocco, Lebanon, Syria—
—Tunisia.

—Tunisia. Again, I enjoyed your company and the company of your wife. I do not think I need to say too much about you. From a Labor member's point of view, I do not want to spoil the statement you made here tonight as a very strong member of the Liberal Party. During the period that I have known you, particularly the period when we worked on the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, of which you were the deputy chairman, your cooperation, the way in which you developed the reports of the committee and the way in which you worked as a team member of that committee was outstanding.

PARA.TAB: I should not say this, but it would have been a good decision of the Liberal Party if you were nominated the chairman of that foreign affairs committee. That is no reflection on the present chairman. I am just saying that because of your attitude and the way in which you worked during his period as the deputy chairman of the committee and particularly the way in which you worked whenever we had meetings or discussions with people. I know I cannot in any way affect your endorsement because I know you are not going to renominate.
Finally, I do wish you luck. When you talked about writing a book on China, you certainly picked the right subject. I wish you and your wife Kathy the best of luck for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments before I move on to the topic I wanted to discuss. I congratulate Baden on an absolutely fine performance as a senator. I recall that I first met him in South Australia at a Liberal student conference whilst I was still a student at university. Senator Teague was there in his capacity as a senator.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague has impressed two things upon me throughout the time that I have known him—his Christian faith and his personal integrity. They are characteristics which I think have stood out in Senator Teague's public life and they are two facets of Senator Teague that I have come to appreciate. I look forward to an ongoing relationship with Senator Teague as a colleague until he chooses to retire from the Senate. When that time arises, I wish him and his family all the best.

The purpose of my rising in the adjournment debate this evening is to respond to what I would consider to be a disgraceful media release by the Attorney-General, Mr Michael Lavarch, which is dated 29 November 1994. It relates to public comments made by the Attorney-General in relation to legislation which is currently before this parliament; that is, the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill.

It will be noted in the public record that very early on in the piece I warned that there was the very real possibility that this legislation, as it was going to be introduced and then ultimately its wording, could well provide a defence to certain types of incest. In his media release on 29 November—

TALK.START.PARA: —Say that again, Senator Abetz.
—Sorry?
—About incest in his statement.
—I said that it may well provide a defence to certain types of incest. That is what I have put on the public record. In his media release, the Attorney-General said:

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland's incest laws are in no way an arbitrary interference with privacy because they are justified and reasonable.
His explanatory memorandum reads:

PARA.TAB: Accordingly, the Bill will not affect laws such as those, for example, dealing with incest . . . where the interference with privacy is justified and reasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: In his second reading speech the Attorney-General said:
All jurisdictions, for example, make incest a criminal offence
Such laws will not be affected by this bill.

In recent times, the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee has publicly heard from people that this legislation may well provide a defence in relation to certain types of incest. I issued a media release referring to the Attorney-General's former professional colleagues in Queensland; namely, the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Miller QC and the President of the Law Society of Queensland, Mr Justin O'Sullivan, both of whom were of the view that this legislation, as currently drafted, would have that impact.

PARA.TAB: On the very next day after the Attorney-General issued the media release we heard evidence from Dennis Rose QC, the Acting Solicitor-General of Australia. An article on page 5 of the Australia of 1 December states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Mr Dennis Rose QC, told a parliamentary inquiry into the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill that the effect of the proposed laws on unusual examples of incest was unclear.
Mr Miller QC gave evidence today that it would impact—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Is it appropriate for a senator to canvass issues about a bill that is already before the parliament and has been referred to a Senate committee? This is the adjournment debate. My understanding of the standing orders is that a senator cannot debate a bill which is already before us in the appropriate forums of the Senate and under active consideration.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I introduced my comments by saying that I was addressing the question of the Attorney-General's media release where he sought to attack me personally on the basis of comments I had made about the potential effect of some legislation. He sought to attack my credibility and integrity and I am responding to that media release. I am not commenting on the benefits or otherwise of the legislation.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I have been listening very closely to Senator Abetz. I have an interest in the legislation that he is referring to. Much of his speech so far has gone very much to the guts and impact of the legislation and the deliberations of the Senate committee, of which he is a member. As a member of that committee he has participated in hearings over the last couple of days. He has been extensively canvassing a measure that is actively before the parliament. No matter how Senator Abetz tries to conceal what he is doing that is precisely what he is doing. I support Senator Schacht's point of order that we have a discussion about a matter which is under active consideration and on the Notice Paper. Senator Abetz is out of order. He cannot bring Tasmanian rules of his party to this parliament.

—On the point of order, the Attorney-General has attacked Senator Abetz in a press release bringing into question his credibility and his integrity. That press release has become a public document. Senator Abetz has the right to bring that press release before the parliament in defence of his character and explain where the Attorney-General is incorrect. That is what I believe he is doing. If you ruled against that it would not be the correct decision and would not give Senator Abetz a chance to put his point of view and explain where the Attorney-General is wrong.

—On the point of order, Senator Abetz is not canvassing the contents of the bill, he is merely reporting statements of fact which support the defence of his character. It is perfectly in order for him to give this speech. If it were not, then it would be open to any minister to attack the character of any senator by merely referring to a bill before the parliament and therefore making it impossible for that senator to defend himself or herself.

—Order! Clearly, Senator Schacht and Senator Bolkus are technically correct although a wide discretion is normally allowed in this area. It is true that Senator Abetz could have used his right to make a personal explanation to do this, but he has chosen to do it in the adjournment debate. I ask him to keep his comments relevant to the alleged statement that was made by the Attorney-General and refer his comments to that and keep as far as possible away from the legislation that is on the Notice Paper.

—I thought I was doing that, Mr President. I will endeavour to do so even more. The situation is that the Attorney-General has said in this media release that the Queensland incest laws would in no way be interfered with. We have now heard evidence from his departmental officers who gave evidence that that is clearly wrong. I made that allegation months ago and for my trouble I have been described as hysterical and all sorts of things by the Attorney-General. Then to top it all off, on 29 November he had the audacity to say that I expressed that view three months ago, which has now been supported by Dennis Rose QC, David Bennett QC, Crowley QC, Francis QC—all those eminent persons—because I wanted to undermine the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Downer. For the public record, on the very day he issued this media release I was reported in the Hobart Mercury as saying that I support the Leader of the Opposition. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak in the adjournment debate but in view of the significant announcement by Senator Teague tonight that he will not be seeking re-election, and because he and I are senators from South Australia, I would like to make a couple of brief comments. We acknowledge that you have had a long period in the Senate and that you are the longest serving senator from South Australia since you were elected in 1977 and began your term in 1978. I think you have been here for seven terms which clearly makes you one of two or three longest serving senators in this place. This gives you some idea how quick the turnover is or how rapid our mortality rate is as senators, particularly with the vagaries of politics in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I wish you, your wife and family all the best when you finish up here when the term ends, whenever that may be—whether there is a double dissolution or not. You have set out tonight what you will do—I will not say in your retirement—in your next act of life, which is quite commendable. Though we are on different sides of politics and we probably have different styles in the way we go about politics from time to time, I recognise in this parliament that you have genuinely been one of the few small `l' Liberal members of the Liberal Party—an ever decreasing number, unfortunately, for Australian politics.

In my time, people like Peter Baume, Chris Puplick, David Hamer and Alan Missen have gone. If I wanted to be cynical about it, the fact that there are diminishing numbers of small `l' Liberals in the Liberal Party enhances the Labor Party's opportunities electorally. It is bad for Australian politics that the major non-Labor Party in Australian politics is ever decreasing its breadth by the departure of such senators as yourself.

As Senator Jones has said, you have had a very distinguished career in the area of foreign affairs. It was a surprise to some of us that you did not end up as chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade recently. That is in no way a reflection on the present chairman. It was a surprise to us in view of your interest in these issues.

I hope that your public support for an Australian head of state has not led to pressure from within the Liberal Party of South Australia for you to step down. It always takes courage in politics—and this should be recognised on all sides of politics—when a member of a party chooses to stand against the majority view that exists in the party, whether it is Labor or Liberal. For that you are to be commended. It takes courage to do that, irrespective of the issue. On this issue, we congratulate you for having the courage to support the fact that Australia should have an Australian citizen as head of state.

TALK.START.PARA: —Youth and the future are with us.

—Yes. So Senator Teague, I think your departure from this place will diminish the Liberal Party, unfortunately for it. But you have chosen to go on to new careers. We wish you, your wife and your family well. You have had nearly 17 years, I think, in this place and you have made a contribution that as a small `l' liberal you can be proud of.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to rise and, not unsurprisingly, make a few comments about Senator Teague's announcement earlier this evening. Senator Schacht talks about mortality in this place. I remember when Baden Teague was a student union councillor and adviser and I was a student at Adelaide University. I can remember his ascension to the Senate and thinking that it was a pretty important place to go to. After a few years here I suppose you get those sorts of misconceptions straightened out.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague has been here a long time. From time to time we have issues that we fight about and argue out across the chamber. His contribution will be remembered in a raft of areas: foreign affairs, aid, education and generally in terms of social issues. As now, I suppose, the equal senior senator from South Australia with Robert Hill—I think that is right—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rob came in with you, three years after me.
—That is right. I add my comments to those of Senator Schacht and say both to you and your family good luck for a great escape and good luck also in the work that you will be doing in the future.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to reflect on your party and politics in terms of your departure and make the very strong point that particularly from my portfolio's perspective, where I am in contact with thousands of people monthly in the broader community, there is a need for recognition of the importance of social issues and of the question of the identity of Australia. The question of a republic which comes with that is very much alive and kicking in our community. As you said by way of interjection, it is to the young and to the future that those issues will be left, but I do not think it will be all that far down the track or we will be all that much older before those issues are addressed because of the changes in our community.

I think politics does need some small `l' liberals on your side, a viable group to put pressure not just on this side of parliament but also on your side of parliament. In many ways the public is frustrated at the moment by the dereliction by the conservative side of politics of that huge area of small `l' issues.

It is at a time like this that we should reflect also on Steele Hall. Senator Teague, you are leaving. Steele Hall is leaving. Senator Hill tried to take over Steele Hall's seat. I was also at university when Raymond Steele Hall started the liberal movement. He did so for a couple of reasons. Firstly, he wanted a more progressive Liberal Party. Secondly, he wanted to ensure that the conservative, dry right wing—in fact, it was the League of Rights connection in South Australia—was driven out of the Liberal Party. In a sense I pity Steele Hall because he took it a long way but the circle has turned full way round. We now find him leaving, you leaving and people like Senator Hill not able to get to the lower house. It is a bad reflection and a sad reflection on politics in our state that the Liberal Party has gone so far to the right that it is vacating that very important ground, particularly for a state like South Australia, where those issues have been fundamental.

This afternoon during question time I interjected when Senator Chapman got up and made the point about how he and you were contesting votes in the preselection battle for Woomera, where my good friend Chris Schacht has had some policy intervention in recent days—

TALK.START.PARA: —A cheap shot.

—No, not a cheap shot, a much talented Schacht. That is the point I want to make. For me it is regretful, as it is for the political system, that good people like Senator Teague, with the contribution, with the capacity, with the input they have made, would have found it difficult to have retained preselection, whereas those without his talent are dominant. From time to time we find that in politics in all parties. It is unfortunate that we find it in the Liberal Party in South Australia now.

PARA.TAB: The circle has turned. To Steele Hall, to Baden Teague, to those of you who are on the outer—and I know what it is like to be on the outer of my own party, of my own faction; I do in a sense feel for you—I think the Liberal Party in South Australia is the loser for it. I think the South Australian community is the loser for it. I think the national parliament is the loser for it. We on this side of parliament can gloat in victory but we do not gloat too much because we cannot afford to, and nor should we. The problems of this country are too great. But we do need a relevant force in the opposition to bring the opposition into relevance in our community. With your departure the potential for that has decreased enormously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join other senators this evening in paying a tribute to my parliamentary colleague and friend—
—You were trying to knock him off. What do you mean?

—You cannot resist the cheap political shot. It is unfortunate that in the speech Senator Bolkus has just completed, which said a lot of fine and well deserved things about Senator Teague, even in that context—I note that he now leaves the chamber—he could not resist the cheap political shot, and I mean no play on words with Senator Schacht sitting there in the minister's chair. That was a great pity. I believe that if Baden had continued to seek to serve the party in the Senate he would have been preselected in one of the three positions we have available in the Liberal Party which will be winnable for us at the next election. I believe that three sitting senators would have been returned to serve for another six year term.
—It is kind of you to say that and I actually agree with you.

—Thank you, Baden. I simply reinforce that in rebuttal of the cheap political shots that Senator Bolkus could not resist making. The purpose in my rising this evening is to pay a brief tribute to my friend, colleague and, indeed, cousin, Senator Baden Teague, for the service that he has given the Liberal Party, the people of South Australia and his colleagues in this place since 1 July 1978. I can probably claim some credit for getting Baden involved in the Liberal Party in the early days. At university we used to discuss issues quite often and when he went on to do his doctorate at Cambridge we used to keep in touch by correspondence on the political issues of the day. So it was with some excitement that Baden became involved in the Liberal Party when he returned from his postgraduate studies with his PhD from Cambridge.

PARA.TAB: Subsequently we were involved together in the days when I was member for Kingston. Baden was actively involved in the strong campaigns we had to wage down there to retain that very marginal seat on three occasions. He certainly made an enormous contribution to the Liberal Party's success in retaining that seat, with me as the member—

TALK.START.PARA: —You won three in a row.

—Three in a row, as Baden says, in what had traditionally been a Labor seat. So in that respect Baden has made an enormous contribution to the Liberal Party and to my own involvement in politics. Part way through that period he himself came into the Senate in the 1977 election, taking his seat on 1 July 1978. He undoubtedly has made an enormous contribution, as a number of senators have mentioned this evening, particularly in his fields of interest, education and foreign affairs, where he has worked with great diligence, giving great attention to detail.

PARA.TAB: He is well regarded, I know, by a number of the overseas representatives in the city of Canberra, ambassadorial and high commission representatives from many countries, for the diligence with which he pursues foreign affairs issues and improving our relations with many overseas countries, particularly the countries of Asia, and more recently the countries of South America, in which he has taken a strong interest. Equally he has been actively involved in a number of issues relating to education over the years. Those two areas are a credit to the contribution he has made in this chamber.

So I am pleased to have been a colleague of his in these more latter years in the Senate since we were both re-elected in the double dissolution election of 1987 and I was able to join Baden in the Senate. We have remained here together since that time. So it is certainly with some regret that I hear this evening that Senator Teague has announced his intention to step down at the next election because I believe he had a continuing contribution to make in this place. I congratulate him on his career as a senator. I am sure we will have a further opportunity to speak of him when his formal retirement occurs. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 31 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Australian Government expressed concern at the treatment of feminist, Taslima Nasrin, in Bangladesh to the Bangladeshi Government; if not, why not.
(2) What was the nature of the concern.
(3) Did Australia get involved in the issue of Taslima Nasrin during the release of her book and the trouble surrounding it; if so, what was the nature of this involvement; if not, why not.
(4) What was Taslima Nasrin charged with in Bangladesh.
(5) Was Taslima Nasrin physically harmed in Bangladesh during the time she released her novel up until when she escaped.
(6) How did Taslima Nasrin come to leave Bangladesh for Sweden.
(7)(a) Which countries offered her a safe haven; and (b) did Australia offer her a safe haven.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) At the end of July, our High Commissioner in Dhaka made representations to the Bangladesh Foreign Secretary about our concerns over the physical safety of Taslima Nasrin.

(2) We were concerned about reports of death threats by certain groups in Bangladesh and urged the Bangladesh Government to take appropriate action to counter these threats. We also urged that all necessary measures be taken to ensure the physical safety of Ms Nasrin should she be apprehended by the police.

(3) The Australian Government was monitoring the situation of Ms Nasrin at the time her book was banned (August 1993). Our High Commission in Dhaka was reliably informed that Ms Nasrin was leading a normal life in Bangladesh and, although she had lost her Government job, was earning a considerable income from her literary works. We did not consider representations to the Bangladesh Government appropriate at that stage.
(4) Ms Nasrin, in her writings, had allegedly violated Section 295(a) of the penal code which deals with offending the religious sentiments of the people.

(6) Ms Nasrin appeared before the High Court in Dhaka on 4 August 1994 to apply for bail. She was granted bail and allowed to travel out of the country. Ms Nasrin left Bangladesh in late August on a private visit to Sweden at the invitation of PEN International. She has also travelled to Norway and Portugal.
(7)(a) We are uncertain if Ms Nasrin has applied for a safe haven. We understand that Sweden and some other EU countries have said they would welcome Ms Nasrin as a visitor.

(b) Australia did not offer Ms Nasrin a safe haven. If she had asked for asylum the Australian Government would have considered the request in accordance with Australia's refugee and humanitarian determination procedures.

(2) Were there any other requests from the US for any other kind of assistance from Australia relating to the occupation of Haiti; if so, what were they, and how did Australia respond.

(3) What will be Australia's contribution to peacekeeping troops in Haiti in terms of (a) number of troops; (b) number of civilians; (c) their roles; (d) the objectives of the mission; (e) the purpose; (f) the time frame; (g) how will they be armed; and (h) what equipment will accompany any mission.
(4) Did Australia support the US plans to invade Haiti; if so, why.

(5) With reference to the United Nations (UN) vote of support for the planned US invasion of Haiti: (a) did Australia vote; if so, how did Australia vote; (b) which countries voted for, and against, an invasion; and (c) what was the wording of the resolution.
(6) Does the US peacekeeping operation have a UN mandate.
(7) Does Australian involvement in the peacekeeping operation have a UN mandate.
(8) What other countries are involved in assisting the US role in Haiti, and what are the details of the assistance and role they will be providing in Haiti.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) US Vice President Al Gore asked the Prime Minister if Australia would consider providing a number of police monitors as part of a UN-endorsed Multinational Force (MNF) to intervene in Haiti.
(b) The request was via a telephone call to the Prime Minister on 14 September 1994.
(3) (a) Australia is contributing with a contingent of thirty Australian Federal Police officers.
(b) None.

(c) The role of the international police monitors is to accompany the Haitian police on patrols and be stationed with them at police posts to encourage proper, professional policing procedures. They do not perform police functions, but observe Haitian police. In essence, their role is two-fold: monitoring and mentoring the Haitian police.

(d) The objectives of the mission of the international police monitors are: (i) to monitor the existing Haitian police during the transition phase which preceded President Aristide's return to Haiti on 15 October 1994, and (ii) after this transition phase, to monitor an interim Haitian public security force composed of vetted police and new police trainees.
(e) As in (c) and (d) above.
(f) The Australian contingent is committed for the duration of the operations of the UN-endorsed MNF in Haiti or for a maximum of six months, without rotation.
(g) Members of the Australian police contingent have taken sidearms.

(h) Monitors are required to use the uniforms and accoutrements of their national contingent. The US Department of Defence is providing all other personal and logistic equipment including ground communications equipment, and will supply food for the police monitors during their training and deployment. The Australian Federal Police has provided the contingent with a satellite telephone.

(4) Australia supported a possible multinational intervention in Haiti as endorsed by the UN in Security Council Resolution 940 of 31 July 1994. The question of a unilateral invasion of Haiti by the US was not considered by Australia, given that the US was pursuing a multilateral resolution of the issue.
(5) (a) No. Australia is not a member of the UN Security Council.

(b) Voting for UN Security Council Resolution 940 of 31 July 1994 were the US, Britain, France, Russia, the Czech Republic, Djibouti, Nigeria, Oman, Pakistan, Spain and Argentina. Brazil and China abstained. There were no votes against.
(c) The wording is contained in UN's official document SCR 940 (1994).
(6) Yes.
(7) Yes.

(8) Countries and the number of police monitors they are contributing are: Argentina (107), Bangladesh (100), Barbados (8), Benin (36), Bolivia (106), Grenada (10), St Kitts and Nevis (9), St Vincent and the Grenadines (12), Poland (56), Israel (30), Jordan (150), Dominica (5), St Lucia (10), Guyana (14), Philippines (50), Belgium (34), Netherlands (16), Denmark (3), and Norway (2).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 19 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Government's 1988 Higher Education Policy Statement in which the Government stated that it was `committed to improving access to and success in the higher education system' and identified sections of the community who were disadvantaged in terms of such access, including people with disabilities, and given that the Government repeated these commitments in `A Fair Chance for All' (1990):
(1) What has the Government done since 1988 to achieve these objectives.
(2) Why have these objectives not been met.

(3) With reference to the findings of the Andrews report that `There would be few, if any, institutions providing education and training which considered they had even reasonable resources available to make adequate provision for students with disabilities who require support to undertake their study programs', what is the Government currently doing to address the problems outlined in the report, aside from appointing disability liaison officers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government's commitment to achieving equity in higher education is set out in its national plan, published in 1990 under the title A Fair Chance for All. This plan identified six groups of people disadvantaged in their participation in higher education. People with disabilities form one of these groups. Under the national plan, higher education institutions have been asked by the Commonwealth to develop equity plans which set out equity objectives and targets, strategies for achieving these objectives and performance measures to assess the progress of equity activities.

Institutions were asked to develop their plans in the light of A Fair Chance for All and institutional plans were linked with targeted funds provided under the Higher Education Equity Program (HEEP). In their plans institutions are now required to set specific equity objectives and indicate the strategies to be used in achieving them. In 1990, $3.5m a year was made available through HEEP to support measures to increase participation in higher education by disadvantaged groups. In 1994 $5m was disbursed to institutions through HEEP.

Grants under HEEP are allocated as `seed' funds to encourage the introduction of innovative developments as a means of increasing the attractiveness of higher education for designated equity groups. This funding approach reflects the Commonwealth's view that effective institutional management should place a priority on access and equity when determining the allocation of its operating resources. It also reflects a view that funding of equity activities in institutions should be met from normal operating grants provided by the Commonwealth to fund recurrent activities.

Because of the high costs of meeting the special support needs of students with a disability, the advantages to be derived from a co-operative approach have also been recognised. Since 1991 the Commonwealth has provided funding for groups of institutions to develop co-operative support measures for this target group. An amount of $544,000 was earmarked under HEEP in 1994 for co-operative support measures.

In 1993 the Commonwealth commissioned an investigation into equity and general performance indicators in higher education, conducted by Lin Martin (Flinders University). It is anticipated that the recommendations of this study which reported earlier this year will lead to a significant improvement in institutions' capacity to undertake nationally consistent monitoring of higher education participation of equity groups in the future. Performance against the proposed indicators in the study will be measured over the next three years, as a means of trialling the effectiveness of the indicators. Implementation of the indicators will enable comparisons of institutional performance to be made. The development of a standard set of performance indicators will also enable funding under HEEP to be allocated on the basis of institutional achievement of outcomes for equity groups.

(2) Through its initiatives outlined in (1) above the Government has demonstrated clearly its commitment to improving access to, and success in, the higher education system for identified sections of the community disadvantaged in terms of access, including people with disabilities.

An evaluation of HEEP conducted by my Department in 1993 found that since the late 1980s women, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and people from non-English speaking backgrounds have continued to improve their overall participation in higher education. For example, the number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students has increased from 1,933 in 1987 to 5,578 in 1993. Most of the HEEP national targets for the first two groups for 1992 had been met and, given a continuation of current trends, the evaluation report stated it was likely that most of the 1995 targets would also be met.

The evaluation also reported that, because of data limitations, progress towards meeting the 1995 target for people with a disability could not be measured. Universities provide a range of services for students with a disability through their equity programs, including special equipment and facilities and special support services, such as note-takers and interpreters. Data problems are being addressed through the Lin Martin study as noted above.

For the remaining two equity groups (people from socio-economically disadvantaged backgrounds and people from rural and isolated areas) specific participation targets were not set. These groups benefit, however, from the strategies adopted by universities under the equity program which include alternative entry arrangements and bridging and supplementary courses.

(3) The Government has addressed the Andrews report in a number of ways. The Regional Disability Liaison Officer initiative is currently being implemented and from 1994 funding of $750,000 per annum has been provided for this purpose. Commonwealth funding under HEEP was also increased by $1 million in 1994, boosting the capacity of institutions to meet infrastructure support costs for students with disabilities. As part of the implementation of their equity plans, institutions are expected to fund ongoing support infrastructure activities from their normal operating grants.

While the provision of expensive infrastructure is one means of creating a more readily accessible and sympathetic environment in higher education institutions, an additional means of assisting students with disabilities is through the Government's Open Learning Initiative (OLI). To underscore its commitment to ensuring wider access to the benefits of higher education, in the 1992 Budget $52 million was provided over the 1993-95 triennium to support the OLI. The increased flexibility of study through the Open Learning Agency offers opportunities for people whose access to higher education is restricted, either because they do not meet entry requirements or because of personal circumstances, such as, family responsibilities or disability.

As part of the initiative, an Open Learning Electronic Support Service (OLESS) is being developed which will allow students, including those with disabilities, to communicate electronically with other students and academic staff. They will also be able to access library services and administrative information electronically. Students will be able to gain access to OLESS from their homes or from community-based facilities.
The above initiatives demonstrate the substantial progress made by the Commonwealth towards meeting its objectives to increase access to higher education as set out in A Fair Chance for All.
